five nights at freddy’s sequel delayed for weird reason five nights at freddy’s creator scott cawthon takes to steam to tease a possible delay for five nights at freddy’s: sister location, the fifth game in the series. cawthon has a habit of surprising fans by releasing five nights at freddy’s games early, and it wouldn’t be all that shocking for five nights at freddy’s: sister location to carry on that tradition, despite cawthon’s post to the contrary. the next game in the franchise, five nights at freddy’s: sister location, was scheduled to release this coming friday, october 7th, but if developer scott cawthon is to be believed, the project has been delayed by a few months. something else upsetting fans is cawthon’s reasoning that the game is too dark to release, as being dark and disturbing are two characteristics that many consumers look for in a horror game. for the past couple of years, horror gaming fans have been able to look forward to one new entry in the five nights at freddy’s series after another, with four core games, one rpg spinoff, and a novel released so far. cawthon said that some of the plot elements are so disturbing that they are making him feel sick, and so he is thinking about delaying the game so that he can rework it entirely "into something kid-friendly." according to a post by cawthon on the five nights at freddy’s: sister location steam page, the game is being delayed because it’s too dark. if the game is delayed, it will be interesting to see if cawthon actually does rework it to be more "kid-friendly," or if he goes with a slightly altered version of his original vision. a more likely scenario is that this is just a weird publicity stunt meant to hype the game as being so disturbing that its developer almost didn’t even release it. alternatively, perhaps cawthon is delaying the game for technical reasons and decided to concoct this story instead of admitting that the fifth core game in the series has issues. five nights at freddy’s fans are confused and angry about this latest development, as many were looking forward to playing the game on friday. cawthon’s reason for suddenly delaying five nights at freddy’s sister location from its planned october 7th release date doesn’t make much sense. delays happen in the gaming industry all the time, but it’s rare for a game to be delayed mere days before its release. five nights at freddy’s: sister location is scheduled to launch on october 7th for pc as well as ios and android mobile devices. with october 7th just a few days away, fans will learn soon enough whether or not cawthon is serious about sister location‘s delay. source: scott cawthon source: scott cawthon source: scott cawthon fans should also consider the possibility that cawthon is just trolling in an attempt to throw them off the scent of an early release.
in finding arpaio and three of his top commanders in contempt of court on friday, u.s. district court judge murray snow said no fewer than 19 times that the sheriff or his aides had repeatedly and intentionally violated judicial orders to stop profiling latinos. "any public official who has been found guilty of racial profiling and ignores the orders of the court cannot be entrusted with the safety and well-being of the community and should step down in shame," the immigrant rights group puente arizona said in a statement friday. on may 31, snow will determine the civil penalties and examine whether arpaio, the sheriff of arizona’s maricopa county, will be referred to arizona’s u.s. attorney for potential criminal charges. in his contempt ruling, snow said arpaio and his aides failed to turn over video evidence to plaintiffs in the civil case, disobeyed orders to gather evidence and continued to profile latinos. the ruling friday was one of arpaio’s most serious defeats, but it doesn’t bar him from holding office, and he had already announced his intention to run for a seventh term as sheriff in november. in a 2011 civil case brought by latino drivers against arpaio and his aides, snow determined that arpaio had encouraged his deputies to subject latino drivers to greater scrutiny during traffic stops than white drivers typically received. arpaio apologized to snow for the investigation, but the sheriff’s attorneys also used the incident to argue that snow was no longer impartial and should recuse himself from the case. in hearings last year, arpaio, the octogenarian who calls himself "america’s toughest sheriff," seemed to wither under questioning, particularly when asked about an effort he had made to investigate the judge. a lawyer for arpaio had hired a private investigator to look into comments snow’s wife purportedly made in a restaurant, where an informant claimed she had said the judge didn’t want to see arpaio reelected. why arizona sheriff joe arpaio’s fate could hang on a single word © reuters/laura segall maricopa county sheriff joe arpaio announces newly launched program aimed at providing security around schools in anthem, arizona, january 9, 2013. chief deputy jerry sheridan was found in contempt on two counts, and retired chief brian sands and lt. joe sousa each were found in contempt on one count. phoenix — a single word — "intentionally" — could transform a court case against phoenix-area sheriff joe arpaio from civil charges to a criminal prosecution. "strong remedies are needed to protect the community’s rights, starting with internal investigations that root out and punish misconduct," said cecillia wang, director of the aclu’s immigrants’ rights project. two years later, snow found that arpaio had continued the practice in violation of the order. at a houston rally the next year, arpaio told supporters that he had violated the order "out of spite" and had arrested 500 people. "in their testimony during the evidentiary hearing, sheriff arpaio and chief deputy sheridan made multiple intentional misstatements of fact while under oath." "the court finds that the defendants have engaged in multiple acts of misconduct, dishonesty, and bad faith," snow wrote. the aclu, which brought the original case against arpaio, demanded stricter oversight and transparency from the sheriff’s office. in weighing criminal charges, snow must decide whether arpaio’s violations of his orders were intentional. snow found that arpaio hid thousands of pieces of evidence from the plaintiffs and deleted relevant digital evidence kept on hard drives. arpaio has acknowledged violating snow’s order, but said it was a mistake. in friday’s ruling, arpaio was held in contempt on three counts. he later said in court filings that he had violated the order unknowingly. "willing or not, the sheriff will be made to comply with the law." he ordered the sheriff to put an end to the practice. "the defendants’ unfair, partial, and inequitable application of discipline disproportionally (sic) damaged members of the plaintiff class," snow wrote. in the meantime, the judge had unusually harsh words for arpaio. longtime opponents immediately called for the sheriff to resign. snow declined.
as for tipping on a discounted service: stylists are split on the issue, with some suggesting a 20% tip on the original price of the service, and others saying a tip of 20% on the discounted rate is fine, since the goal is to get you back into the salon. "all the assistants are there in training to be stylists, and at many places, a lot are working at minimum wage, so anywhere from $5 to $20 is fine depending on how much they end up doing for the client, or if they have been especially gracious to you," she told instyle. as for your stylist’s assistant, that person is likely in training and may not be making much money, so michelle lee, master designer and manager at salon eva michelle in boston, recommends tipping them between $5 and $20. but knowing how much to tip your hairdresser has to be one of the more confusing tip scenarios out there, especially if you get your hair done at a salon where more than one person works on your strands. finally, if you’re unsatisfied with your haircut, communicated what you wanted to your stylist, and talked to them about how to fix it but they refused to make changes, you can definitely lower your tip. here’s how much you should be tipping your hairdresser here’s how much you should be tipping your hairdressermore remembering how much you’re supposed to tip anywhere can be hard — what do current trends dictate? if you’re a woman with shorter hair — meaning you get it cut and/or colored regularly — your stylists will understand if you offer a slightly smaller tip. you can hand the money directly to the shampooist, or give it to the receptionist when you check out and ask them to pass it along. you can always ask the receptionist at your salon what’s typical, or ask on the phone when you call to make your appointment. not every credit card machine will allow you to add a tip, and using cash will make it easier to tip the different people who worked on your mane. if they invite you back for a fix-up cut, though, etiquette expert peggy post suggests offering a tip of 15-20%. below, once and for all, is a definitive guide to tipping your hairstylist — and their assistant, shampooist, and everyone in between. and yes, it’s ok to tip even if your hairdresser is the owner of the salon. also, if your salon offers free bang touch-ups, consider bringing a few dollars to leave as a thank-you gesture. if you need a simple baseline, experts agree that tipping 20% is standard and acceptable at any hair salon. offering the person who shampoos your hair $3 to $5 is a nice gesture. if you’re in a smaller town, 15% may be the norm. after all, your annual bill is much higher than a longer-haired client’s. and what if you got a discount on the service? your stylist will look fondly on you next time you come into the salon. try to bring cash to tip, if possible. when in doubt, ask at the front desk! is there such a thing as too much? thank us later — no tip necessary.

on the other hand, some drinks, including sprite (known in china as xue bi) and a type of soda water, were found to have the opposite effect: increasing the activity of aldh and thus speeding up the breakdown of acetaldehyde. this popular soda could cure your hangovers scientists say: most of us are familiar with the pounding headaches, drowsiness, stomach-turning nausea and "did-i-get-run-over-by-a-bus" sensation that comes with that most dreaded of morning-after ailments: the hangover. chemistry world explains it this way: some of the adverse effects of alcohol are thought to be caused, not by the ethanol itself, but by ethanol’s first metabolite, acetaldehyde. the researchers are reportedly planning to conduct the tests in living organisms, but the results have already generated a lot of buzz, as people around the world celebrate the possible death of the hangover. an herbal infusion with hemp seeds, for example, was discovered to boost the activity of adh while inhibiting aldh, therefore slowing down the breakdown of acetaldehyde and dragging out the hangover effects. a group of chinese researchers say that they may have indeed found this perfect hangover cure -- and it goes by the name of "sprite." specifically, they theorized that certain drinks could impact the body's metabolism of alcohol in a way that would help alleviate hangover symptoms. after examining 57 beverages in a lab, researcher hua-bin li and his colleagues at sun yat-sen university in guangzhou determined that sprite was one of the drinks that best relieved hangover symptoms. but what if there were a miracle elixir that could chase that hangover cloud away -- and better still, what if that magic drink were something you could easily pick up at your local supermarket? the chinese researchers, therefore, decided that they would look at how the different beverages impacted the activity of adh and aldh. edzard ernst, a medicinal science expert from the university of exeter, told chemistry world that while he found the study interesting, more research is necessary before we wholeheartedly embrace the results. the team of scientists had hypothesized that what you consume after drinking booze could alter the effect of alcohol on your body. unlike acetaldehyde, acetate is innocuous and may even be responsible for some of the positive health benefits of alcohol consumption. therefore the key to reducing alcohol-related damage lies in minimizing the amount of time acetaldehyde is present in the body. ethanol is metabolized into acetaldehyde by the enzyme alcohol dehydrogenase (adh) and then into acetate by aldehyde dehydrogenase (aldh). do you have a tried-and-tested hangover cure that you swear by? some beverages were found to be terrible for a hangover. to alleviate the suffering, chugging coffee, downing advil or simply choosing to forego the wretched day altogether by returning to bed sometimes does the trick. however, experts warn that we shouldn't quite raise the victory flag just yet. tell us below.

you won't believe this stunning "harry potter" revelation about professor mcgonagall from reading j.k. rowling‘s harry potter saga, and watching the films, we know a lot about one of our favorite professors and head of gryffindor house, professor minerva mcgonagall. if you recall, one of the reasons why headmaster dippet rejected tom riddle’s application for the dada teaching position, at age 17-18 for tom, was because tom was "too young". but why would dumbledore hire a brilliant mcgonagall just as his assistant and not to a full teaching position when she first arrived back at hogwarts? after all, the dark lord was probably, "angry, vindictive, and jealous of mcgonagall, and wanted to take his revenge for what he saw as "what was rightfully his". additionally, in harry potter and the order of the phoenix mcgonagall told dolores umbridge that she had been teaching at hogwarts for "thirty-nine years this december". it seems likely then that mcgonagall started teaching as dumbledore’s assistant in december of 1956, and, at some point, applied for (and received) the dada job. dumbledore denied voldemort’s application and as a result, voldemort cast a jinx to prevent any dada professor from ‘lasting more than a year’. but, why would mcgonagall who is obviously gifted in transfiguration initially apply to be the defense against the dark arts instructor? obversa suggests that "professor mcgonagall was originally hired by dumbledore to teach defense against the dark arts (dada) in 1956. as a result of pottermore, we know a bit more about professor mcgonagall’s backstory (which is extremely similar to lord voldermort’s background). this means that if the wand chooses the wizard, mcgonagall would have been destined for a lot more than transfiguration. dumbledore then transferred mcgonagall to the transfiguration position before the term’s end, to prevent anything "bad" or "dangerous" from happening to her. obversa says, "prior to being headmaster, dumbledore served as transfiguration professor for several decades, teaching tom riddle himself as a child. however, not long after, tom riddle (lord voldemort) came back to hogwarts, seeking the dada position for himself. just as he was continually obsessed with the similarities between harry potter and himself throughout the entire saga. at the time, mcgonagall was still perhaps too young, to be a hogwarts professor in her own right. reddit user obversa made a stunning revelation about one of the most bad-ass witches in the entire hp saga. after all, as long as she wasn’t teaching dada , the jinx technically wouldn’t apply to her." stern but fair, mcgonagall expected a lot from her students, but she also cared for them deeply, even if she didn’t always outwardly express it. the wandmaker ollivander once called it the, ‘the survivor’s wand,’ because he had sold it to three wizards who subsequently passed through mortal peril unscathed. however, what if there was something about professor mcgonagall that we never thought about before? however, lord voldemort arrived to hogwarts shortly thereafter wanting to snag the position for himself. thus, when dumbledore succeeded dippet, he would have left a vacancy for the spot of transfiguration." once dumbledore refused, voldy put a hex on the position, so mcgonagall had to be transferred to transfiguration. however, dippet encouraged tom "to come back a few to several years later to apply again". therefore, mcgonagall’s official hiring would have been in the middle of the school year, very odd timing. we know that minerva mcgonagall filled this vacancy, but what led her there? how this 20-year-old died from kissing her boyfriend ctv news myriam ducre-lemay, 20, died in 2012 after kissing her boyfriend — he'd eaten a peanut butter sandwich and wasn't aware of her peanut allergy (or the severity of it) and she was not carrying her epipen with her at the time, ctv news reports. though many outlets report brushing your teeth helps eliminate the chance of an allergic reaction in this situation, the only thing that will ensure it won't happen is waiting a long time after you consume peanuts to kiss. according to fox news, ducre-lemay had recently told people her allergies had decreased in severity, but mccusker said that is only true of every 1 in 5 allergy patients. head of pediatric allergy and immunology at montreal children's hospital dr. christine mccusker told ctv people between the ages 15 to 30 are in the "risk age range" and are most likely to suffer from severe allergic reactions. after the kiss, she had trouble breathing, tried using her asthma pump, and, when that didn't work, asked her boyfriend about peanuts — when he said he'd eaten them, she told him to call 911. according to cjad, ducre-lemay and her boyfriend had been out at a party earlier that night, which is why she didn't have her medication or her medic alert bracelet on her. this is why people with allergies carry "epipen[s], even though you don't want to and even though it's not cool," mccuskey said. en route to the hospital, ducre-lemay suffered cardiopulmonary arrest, which led to cerebral anoxia (oxygen deprivation to the brain). her mother is just now publicizing the story to help others avoid the same situation. "people don't necessarily recognize it can go from that point where, 'i feel funny' to 'uh oh' very fast." emergency crews attempted to resuscitate her with epinephrine, but failed. he attempted to give her cpr before the ambulance arrived. she was taken off the respirator and died.

aerial spraying, which lasts about an hour, was recommended by the cdc and florida's department of health to reduce the population of adult mosquitoes, some of which may be capable of spreading viruses, including zika. in puerto rico, where a public health emergency has been declared due to the sheer number of cases of zika, recommendations from the cdc and the epa to use aerial spraying to control the mosquito population there have been stymied by protests. by contrast, in miami-dade county, the department of solid waste management's mosquito control section commonly sprays in response to state department of health investigations -- and when residents request the use of insecticide. (cnn) after the first locally transmitted cases of the zika virus were identified in a small area north of downtown miami, officials began to spray an insecticide over a 10-square-mile portion of miami-dade county. although spraying insecticides raises concerns about toxicity to aquatic life, policy-makers must weigh the potential costs to human health by not spraying and costs to environmental health by spraying, phillips said. naled does not pose a health risk to either people or pets when sprayed in low concentrations, according to both the environmental protection agency (pdf) and the centers for disease control and prevention. "when naled gets sprayed, it knocks out the mosquitoes, but if sprayed over water, it breaks down quickly," said bryn phillips, a specialist in the university of california, davis environmental toxicology department. those who worry that they may have come into contact with the chemicals should wash, county officials advised; any food that may have been exposed should be rinsed before eating. in fact, dibrom has been used in the united states over the past 50 years, said timothy j. donnelly, vice president, chief administrative officer and general counsel of amvac chemical corp ., which makes the insecticide. "you talk to the mosquito spraying guys, and they're all about human health, and they're ok with some impacts to the environment," he said. miami-dade county's aerial spraying alternates between naled and an insecticide called bti (bacillus thuringiensis israelensis, a naturally occurring bacterium), which targets mosquito larvae instead of adult mosquitoes. naled spray droplets stay airborne for an extended period, and the chemical begins to break down once exposed to sunlight or water. zika has been shown to be responsible for an alarming increase in microcephaly, in which babies are born with small brains and heads, as well as other hearing, vision and developmental disorders. one of these versions, dichlorvos, is quite toxic to aquatic species at the "low end of the food chain," like aquatic insects and frog larvae -- "basically fish food," phillips said. naled degrades to dichlorvos , a toxic chemical, in the presence of sunlight, and according to the eu scientific commission , this can cause genetic mutations. the mosquito control section has applied naled via an ultra-low-volume spray for many years, officials said in a news release. activists organized a june 28 demonstration outside the san juan cdc and raised concerns about the consequences for human health and their environment. since the variety of mosquito that carries zika is most active predawn and at sunset, all spraying must take place at those times. if the chemicals are rotated and managed properly, an environmental area can recover, phillips noted. florida reported the nation's first local transmission of zika from an infected mosquito in late july. sprayers produce very fine droplets that are small enough to stay airborne and intercept mosquitoes in flight. his research indicates that the insecticide breaks down into different chemical versions of naled. special precautions are not necessary, miami-dade county officials advised, though people with allergies may want to remain indoors. "it is regularly sprayed in 12 states on over 15 million acres each year," donnelly said. since concentrations are far below what is harmful to humans, symptoms, such as skin irritation or headache, are unlikely. yet some environmentalists are not ok with any effects to land and sea, he said. but what was in the insecticide, and how does it work? join the conversation see the latest news and share your comments with cnn health on facebook and twitter. the main ingredient of the insecticide, dibrom, is the chemical naled. bti has been registered with the epa since 1961 as a pesticide. during any insecticide operation, it is recommended that beekeepers cover their bees. an outbreak that began in brazil in 2015 has spread throughout the americas. very little of the low-concentration spray settles on the ground. as a result, the eu has banned agricultural use of products containing naled. what are mosquito-control workers spraying in miami? however, in its own review of naled, the european union came to a different conclusion. originally scheduled for wednesday, the aerial spraying operation was delayed because of poor weather conditions. it works by killing mosquitoes on contact. "it's a balancing act," phillips said. zika was discovered in 1947 in uganda.
as monterey bay aquarium veterinarian mike murray said in a 2009 article for popular science, birds are capable of passing gas, but they don’t because they lack the same combination of diet and gas-forming bacteria in their gut that gives mammals their odorous gas. in a blog post on her website, she posits that birds have much shorter digestive tracts than mammals, so there’s less time for gas to build up, allowing farts to slip by undetected. according to mental_floss, human farts are smelly due to a combination of our diets and the microbes in our guts that help digest the foods in our diets. weisbrod goes on to describe how birds eat similar diets to many mammals who definitely flatulate but explains that he could not find any other accounts of bird flatulence at that time. there’s no reason to believe that birds are somehow exempt from passing gas, but it doesn’t seem like anyone has ever truly observed—or more importantly, measured—a bird fart. murray added that if he spotted gas in an x-ray of a bird’s gastrointestinal tract, he’d be concerned something was wrong with the bird. according to a q&a with proctologist lester gottesman in vice, farts make a sound due to the composition of gas and the shape (read: tightness) of the sphincter. lastly, maybe they do swallow enough air that would leave most animals saying "excuse me" after a butt-bellow, but perhaps something about the construction of the, erm, exit point keeps it from making a sound. a video by asapscience adds that "the longer the food stays in the gut, the more time it has to ferment" and break down into its smellier components—namely sulfur. he added that he thinks birds do fart "in some cases and would depend on what species, their diet, and whether it is observable." so if birds don’t have the right food-microbe combo and intestinal length to produce smelly gas, then we wouldn’t smell it. this is pure speculation, but maybe something about having feathers around the bird’s cloaca (its all-purpose back-end chute) helps the fart slip by unnoticed. (just think of how your dog’s poop steams in the cold when you take him out for his daily business in the winter.) several days later a bird perched in the same position was observed to defecate with the accompanying wisp of whitish gas. but between ornithologists, veterinarians, and amateur bird watchers, how is it possible no one has ever seen the feathered creatures flatulate? the feces dropped from the bird while the gas wafted below and parallel to the slightly raised tail, until it dissipated rapidly into the cold air. a lot of the gas that makes up a fart, gottesman said, is swallowed air. he also acknowledges that the "wisp of whitish gas" could also have simply been water vapor—steam rising from the feces. according to an ornithologist there, relayed via email by the lab’s good-humored press officer miyoko chu, birds definitely swallow air. in another blog post, she describes the only written account she’s aware of describing a possible bird fart. the gas could be clearly seen against the dark-colored eave that hangs over the sheltered perches, upon which the birds were fluffed and resting. and a lot of swallowed air leads to a lot of gas, which can make a bigger, beefier noise. (and apparently no scientist has stepped up to the plate to follow up on weisbrod’s observation.) but how much air does a swallow swallow when a swallow swallows air? and without a smell, bird farts rustle no one’s feathers. but the daily dot reached out to the cornell lab of ornithology for answers nonetheless. as far as we could tell, this isn’t a question any scientist has specifically tried to measure. but laura eriksen, a birder, educator, and blogger at the cornell lab of ornithology, has a different theory. without a smell, bird farts rustle no one’s feathers. he also said that he’s never personally noticed a bird fart. it’s a little difficult to know for sure that birds rarely or never fart. a small puff of whitish gas was expelled along with the feces. but he thinks they expel it via burping rather than farting. one of the birds in front of me defecated. but even if birds produced immaculate, odorless gas, would we hear it? it comes from former cornell student alan richard weisbrod, in his 1965 master’s thesis on blue jays. have you ever wondered, "do birds fart?" they don’t fart—detectably. do birds fart? that is less clear. well maybe now we’ve sparked your curiosity. no?

a new study from the university of washington’s foster school of business found that despite working the same amount of time, a worker who starts the day earlier will come off as more conscientious, and consequently receive better performance reviews, than someone who starts later. even when employees who started later in the day worked the same number of hours as those who started earlier, supervisors were inclined to rate employees who began work earlier as more conscientious, and gave them higher performance ratings. another recent study covered by the new york times further suggests there may be an implicit view among some managers that employees who take advantage of flexible work policies in any way are less conscientious than employees who work more "traditional" hours. researchers found that employees who worked from 7 a.m. to 3 p.m. were consistently given higher ratings of conscientiousness and performance by the student supervisors than employees who worked from 11 a.m. to 7 p.m. in the study, which will be published in full in the journal of applied psychology later this year, researchers asked 149 supervisors to rate an employee’s performance; employee start times ranged from 5 a.m. to 9:45 a.m. studies have shown that women take advantage of workplace telecommuting policies more often than men for the same reason -- and that their careers may suffer as a result of not logging as much face time at the office. "it seems likely that some employees are experiencing a decrement in their performance ratings that is not based on anything having to do with their actual performance," the three researchers wrote in a post for the harvard business review. the one morning work mistake you can't recover from rolling into the office around 9:30 a.m. every day may be killing your career, even if you stay late to put in a full day's worth of work. "you are implicitly saying, ‘most of us will be working these traditional ways and the rewards will come to those working these traditional ways.’ and that is where you have this stigma or career penalties." in a word-association experiment designed to test the implicit stereotype that early risers are more diligent workers, the researchers also found that a majority of the 120 working adults surveyed linked words associated with the morning (like "sunrise") with words associated with conscientiousness (like "industriousness"). that's why companies like google and microsoft let employees work from home or adjust their schedules to account for personal responsibilities, like taking a child to school in the morning. in a second experiment, the researchers assigned a group of 141 college students the role of a supervisor, and asked each student to review a profile of a fictitious employee. but the study suggests a downside: your boss may be unconsciously judging you for giving yourself a later start time, regardless of how much work you're getting done. the researchers concluded that employees who can opt for flexible work schedules should shift their schedules earlier, not later, to account for managers' morning bias. past studies have shown that giving workers a little leeway in setting their hours makes them happier and more productive -- presumably a win for both the employee and the company. that's because more women than men are primary caregivers for their children and assume a disproportionate amount of household tasks, according to a 2013 bureau of labor statistics report. bosses who preferred to work later hours themselves were less inclined to display this "morning bias." "most organizations still treat workplace flexibility as an accommodation," erin kelly, a sociology professor at the university of minnesota, told the times. although the study did not consider gender, it seems women could be more adversely affected by morning biases than men. the performance of the fictional employee was the same in all cases, but start time varied across profiles. this "morning bias" appears to be deeply ingrained.

that had been lacking credibility. among the allegations was evidence that the voicemail of a murdered schoolgirl had been illegally accessed, which gave her family false hope that she was still alive. news corp bought storyful in december 2013 for $25 million, pledging that the startup would operate as a standalone company. brooks's hard charging ways led her to some of the highest positions technology. she once famously rigged a hotel room with recording devices when meeting a source who claimed to have had a sexual relationship with princess diana. known as a sharp and aggressive your favorite children's book illustrator just got his own exhibition in chicago despite the fact that renowned author and illustrator edward gorey was born in chicago and spent a sizable chunk of his formative years in the windy city, his work has never been recognized with its own exhibition. the second exhibition, "g is for gorey, c is for chicago," pulls from the collection of loyola alumnus thomas michalak, a member of the board of directors of the edward gorey house in massachusetts who has collected gorey material for over two decades. pam ambrose, director of luma, told huffpost the shows aim to address the lack of awareness of gorey's chicago roots in addition to tracing the man's development from a budding artist to an acclaimed cultural icon who inspired creators like daniel handler and tim burton. it includes a number of rare items offering a deeper look at the mysterious man behind the art, including some of his report cards, early drawings and book covers he designed, and the ornately decorated envelopes of letters he sent to his mother, helen. beginning earlier this month and continuing through june 15, the macabre creations of the late gorey are front and center for two concurrent exhibitions at the loyola university museum of art (luma) in chicago. while gorey will forever be linked to gothic subculture thanks in large part to his signature victorian characters dressed in head-to-toe black, the show paints a broader portrait of the artist than that. one of the shows, "elegant enigmas: the art of edward gorey," is a touring exhibition organized by the brandywine museum in chadds ford, penn. "i want people to really think about who this man was," ambrose said," because he appears to be many contradictions in one persona. his influence is also felt in "summerland: a ghost story," a small mixed-media installation by chicago artist kenneth gerleve that's also also included in the show. for example, prominently-placed illustrations of cats throughout the show acknowledge his fascination with felines, and many of his kid-centric illustrations feel downright giddy when compared to his familiar somber style. the luma shows have been a hit -- they had people lined up outside the front door on opening day, "pretty good" for a university museum, ambrose noted. "this is an artist who was much more important than the immediate perception of just the gothic tale or cautionary tale," ambrose said. that offers a comprehensive look at his illustrations as well as work by other artists he influenced. but was this a persona invented to keep people away? tickets to a saturday bash celebrating what would have been gorey's 89th birthday sold quickly. he seems like someone who shapeshifts a bit." it's very hard to say. that is, until now.
fashion brand lets models go un-photoshopped and makeup-free we're just as tired of overly-retouched ads as the next girls, so we've been championing rag & bone's diy project since it started back in 2011. with more publications swearing off photoshop (verily magazine might just be our favorite) and more brands eschewing makeup in ad campaigns, we're happy that a project like this can add to this positive movement in the fashion industry. in case you're not familiar with the concept, the diy project lets models take complete control of the shoot, including the styling and actual photography. rag & bone simply gives the chosen model a bag of clothes and a digital camera -- the rest is entirely up to her, including whether or not she wears makeup. as the campaign closes its third year, we're thrilled that the latest slew of ads starring julia stegner are as refreshing as ever. as for stegner, her beachy shoot features her adorable pup and one of the most effortless haircuts we've seen in a while. thus far, we've seen gorgeous rag & bone styling interpretations by industry powerhouses like lily aldridge, karolina kurkova, miranda kerr, candice swanepoel and carolyn murphy. with julia stegner's new shots, the results are fresh, personal and seemingly makeup-free.

'a quick way to restore your shelves to their former glory is to place the shelves in a resealable plastic bag, spray with oven cleaner, seal the bag, then leave to soak. from removing oil by adding more oil to banishing bad smells with lemon and water, these are the very easy - and cheap - tricks that will clean what is often the filthiest part of a kitchen. remove stuck on food with dishwasher tablets 'dishwasher tablets are excellent at removing stuck-on food from your pots and pans in a dishwasher, so why should your oven be any different? if your oven has steel burners then place them in a resealable bag overnight with a drop of bleach and warm water. next rub the tablet over the built-up grease on your oven door and watch the burnt-on dirt wash away with minimal effort.' the oven cleaning hacks that will have your appliance sparkling without any scrubbing scrubbing the oven is one of the most dreaded spring cleaning jobs. lawrence lessig, a harvard law professor, wrote a piece in the orlando sentinel calling jolly’s bill a "cynical example of fraudulent reform" because "all that would change is that congressmen wouldn’t have to do the dirty work." "but you actually got elected to be one more marble on our side of the aisle to keep the majority, and to do that you’ve got to go raise $2 million — and that makes members angry." "if you’ve already consumed 40, 50 hours of the week in travel and fundraising, there’s not a lot of time left over for governing, and we’re seeing the results of that," he said. he said he’s not paying his $400,000 in dues to the nrcc, and he said "i don’t buy the notion" that he needs more sponsors before house leadership grants a hearing on his bill. the national republican congressional committee, in a letter to cbs after the "60 minutes" segment, accused jolly of peddling "fiction" when he said party officials told him he had to raise $18,000 a day. i’ve argued for other ways to get lawmakers to spend more time working — returning to the five-day week, cutting travel allowances, ending the corrosive practice of members targeting each other for defeat through party committees. then, three weeks ago, "60 minutes" did a sympathetic piece on jolly’s idea, giving national attention to the scandal of lawmakers spending 30 or more hours a week dialing for dollars. jolly’s democratic sidekick, nolan, said that when he first served in congress in the 1970s, lawmakers worked full weeks, giving them time to develop respect for one another and to find common ground. in february, when rep. david jolly introduced his quixotic plan to ban members of congress from soliciting campaign contributions, the florida republican had only six co-sponsors. the little support jolly has gained for the idea comes largely from florida, home to three of his eight co-sponsors, including democrat alan grayson, also a senate candidate. campaign-finance reformer fred wertheimer told me the idea "is not going to solve the problem," because those working for the members could still solicit funds. has recruited 160 co-sponsors for his system of public financing of elections — another good idea — but so far he has only one republican, gadfly walter jones (n.c.). jolly is a potential ally of democrats on campaign-finance reform, saying that citizens united "could be revisited" and that "we can do better." "we’re looking at the last couple of sessions of the congress of the united states as being the most unproductive in the history of the country. and though the bill wouldn’t by itself solve the campaign-finance mess, it could help to improve the woeful political culture in other ways. the number of co-sponsors on jolly’s bill has jumped from six all the way up to — um, eight. but while jolly can be accused of election-year gimmickry, he voluntarily refused to solicit contributions for his senate run. "we’re here three days a week, and half your time is spent raising money," he said. jolly, appearing monday morning at the national press club with his lead democratic co-sponsor, rep. rick nolan (minn.), was not surprised. "we’ve got six more co-sponsors than i thought we might have," he said. lawrence lessig, a harvard law professor, wrote unfortunately, liberals have piled on. lawmakers know what needs to be done to clean up the corrupt system — but nothing happens. well, if everybody’s busy campaigning and raising money, there’s no time for governing." a democratic congressional candidate in florida, businessman randy perkins, went one step further, announcing he would stop "soliciting or accepting" financial contributions. democrats talk about overturning the supreme court’s citizens united decision allowing corporations and unions to spend unlimited sums on politics. a member’s political survival depends on raising money — that’s the reality." he rescued this bizarre creature from a sidewalk, but he had no idea what it would grow into jeff longo was wandering in the intense florida heat when he saw a tiny ball of fluff on the sidewalk. and so, despite having no clue even as to what the animal was, he decided to take it back to his home in st. petersburg. however, without an inkling of even which species biscuits belonged to, longo didn’t have the first idea about how best to raise her. what’s more, then and there, despite having no experience of rearing animals, he vowed to nurse the poor baby back to health. clearly, then, the first order of the day was to give the adorable and tiny creature, which was just over an inch in length, some major tlc. in addition to getting the gift of life, though, biscuits had also, again thanks to her encounter with longo, gained a new family. however, most of the responses were from people telling him, simply, that there was no way he’d manage to raise biscuits on his own. since biscuits had somehow become separated from her family, then, it was now down to longo to fill her mother’s shoes. longo, a florida native, thought that the little thing didn’t look good, and he knew that the unrelenting sunshine was taking its toll. indeed, alongside her surrogate mother, biscuits gained some four-legged family friends – in the shape of longo’s dogs. so, this being the 21st century and all, he began to research his new-found friend online. that said, given their difference in stature, longo admitted that he had to "watch them so they don’t accidentally squish her." undeterred, though, longo continued his research and eventually discovered the answer he was looking for. so, for two months, longo took biscuits everywhere with him – even to work. the gliding rodents are nocturnal, and young squirrels tend to stay with their mothers until they are at least two months old. it turned out that he was going to be looking after a southern flying squirrel. indeed, longo later recounted how the helpless baby was "half-dead" when they first met. consequently, longo christened the critter biscuits and began to hand-rear her himself. they furthermore survive on a diet of nuts, seeds, fruit and insects as well as eggs and birds. as each day passed, biscuits grew bigger and stronger, until she eventually became a healthy adult squirrel. first, longo went to reddit to ask the website’s online community for help. naturally, this species of squirrel usually resides in forests and woods, using trees as their habitat. he even bottle-fed her with a mix of puppy formula and heavy cream. this took place in 2013 on the sizzling streets of tampa.

they include: personality and perseverance propensity to get injured propensity to choke under pressure individual differences in maximum oxygen uptake differences in how we acquire muscle mass coordination height enjoyment of competition "we have so many factors within a person that can contribute to [athletic performance] — different genes, different cognitive abilities, different physical attributes," she says. put another way, if we compare batting averages between two baseball players, the amount of time the players spent in the batting cage would only account for 18 percent of the reason one player's average is better than the other. a meta-analysis in perspectives in psychological science looked at 33 studies on the relationship between deliberate practice and athletic achievement and found that practice just doesn't matter that much. it's okay if you can't make up the difference with practice, or if you're just a "slow learner" when it comes to sports. "one important thing — that's easy to misunderstand— is that this is looking at variance across people, not within an individual," brooke macnamara, the lead author of the perspectives paper, tells me. overall, she says the finding is a strike against the popular "10,000 hour rule," which implies anyone can become master at an activity if they were to just devote the time to it. instead, there's likely a whole constellation of factors — some of which are genetic or biological in nature — that explain why some people are better athletes than others. but it also means that for the same amount of practice, some will end up being better at sports than others. it's also okay to just enjoy being on a team, trying hard but knowing you'll unlikely be the best. even more simply: some people are just better at sports than others, and the difference cannot be made up by practice alone. i was a horrible lacrosse player in high school: bad at catching the ball, slow, and not very aggressive. here's where we should note a limitation of studying practice: researchers typically ask athletes to recall their schedules and practice hours, and memories can be faulty. the research in sports, and in other activities such as music, games, and education, just doesn't back that hypothesis up. baseball: throw a ball at me and i'll be more likely to bruise than catch it. but macnamara doesn't think better measurements of practice would make that 18 percent figure leap up to near 100. more precisely, the analysis found, practice can account for 18 percent of the difference in athletic success. the analysis found this 18 percent figure is roughly true no matter what type of sport is being played. practice accounts for the same difference in performance in bowling as it does field hockey, two completely different activities. on the other hand, it's not like these findings are an excuse not to try. "we're trying to argue against these ideas that it's so important it accounts for nearly everything." the analysis also found that the age when athletes started their sports didn't change this figure much either. growing up, my dad was on a quest to find "my sport" — the activity i'd finally master. "there’s probably not one huge contributor that’s accounting for everything else," she says. practice also explains fewer differences in ability the further an athlete ascends into higher levels of play. practice matters, but it's unlikely to bridge the gap between inborn superstars and your average, or perhaps clumsy, kid. life's just too short to spend it on activities you're horrible at. which is why it is so hard to pin down what predicts performance." this is when my history teacher — the varsity coach — pulled me aside and suggested i shouldn't bother. yet i'd spend hours at a handball wall with my stick: throwing, catching, repeating. i'd probably be cut, he said (adding that i was getting very good grades). there was a reason i lagged behind my peers on the lacrosse field. which suggests "deliberate practice loses its predictive power beyond a certain level of skill," the study reports. "some people improve very quickly with less practice, while others require much more practice." by 11th grade, it was time to try out for varsity lacrosse. these days i stick to activities that don't involve hand-eye coordination: hiking, biking, running, skiing. for the athletically un-inclined, like myself, it's a bit of a relief. "so if a person practices, they will get better. i'm not a well-coordinated person, and that's just fine. "all of those things are important and interact with each other. i was really bad at sports in high school. almost across the board, practice should improve one’s performance." freshman and sophomore years, i made it onto the junior varsity team — a miracle. i played on winter leagues, and woke up early for 6 am pickup games. tennis: i was cut from the middle school team. they probably had a natural advantage on me. so what, then, explains the remaining 82 percent? but it was mostly a parade of failures. for me, practice did not make perfect. soccer: i was much too slow. lacrosse was the closest we came. "eighteen percent is big," macnamara says. this new study helps me understand why. basketball: all of the above. lo and behold, i now have scientific validation. i love physical activity. "essentially, learning rates vary," macnamara says.
the disclosure paves the way for the show’s new host, trevor noah, and suggests that stewart will not hang around as candidates start to make announcements this year about running in the 2016 election for u.s. president.stewart had said previously that he would continue to do the program until some time between july and the end of 2015. noah is a relative unknown in the united states and has already come under scrutiny for a series of controversial tweets made in past years that were discovered on social media after comedy central announced him as stewart’s heir. stewart’s announcement sets the stage for trevor noah, a south african comic who has hosted a late-night program in that country, to take the reins of the series. he offered few details about what he might do for his final broadcast, but did reiterate a contest that would give a viewer the chance to attend the program’s last taping. the comic announced on monday’s broadcast of the program that he will leave the show after its august 6th broadcast. stewart made the announcement at the very end of the evening’s broadcast, just before rolling the program’s signature "moment of zen" final segment. the viacom-owned network and stewart have both come out in support of noah, urging audiences to give him a chance before passing judgement on his humor. jon stewart has set his official departure date from #thedailyshow jon stewart now has a firm departure date from comedy central’s "the daily show." say it ain't so!

one word that should never follow "i love you" i don’t remember the exact day, or the exact reason, or even the exact words, but i know it started with "i love you, but ..." it could have been "i love you, but you’re driving me crazy" or any of the following: "i love you, but you’re not listening to me"; "i love you, but stop leaving dirty dishes in the sink"; or "i love you, but i need some alone time." i was throwing "i love you" in to soften the blow, but let’s be honest, when you say it like that, the purpose of the statement is to communicate everything except "i love you." what he heard was "i love you if ..." and "i would love you, if only you would ..." he didn’t like it, he said so, and i’m glad he did. i stopped and repeated the sentence i had just said to him with the revision, and the light bulb inside my head nearly blinded me with epiphany. above all else, i want my family to know that i love them regardless of circumstances, even if they are driving me crazy. the "but" slices the top of the sentence off and the "i love you" gets discarded like a strawberry’s calyx. what my husband heard wasn’t the first part of the sentence, but the second, every time. it has made a significant difference in my communication with my husband, and now, my kids. my husband asked if i could replace the word "but" with the word "and." it took me a while to make the change in my delivery permanent, but it was worth the effort. i’ve begun many a sentence with those four words, and never paused for a moment to think about what they mean. "i love you," usually the most beautiful and powerful triad of words in the world, becomes inauthentic and trivial — cheap. "i love you and you are driving me crazy." suddenly, his driving me crazy was no longer an exception to my loving him. i could love him and be driven crazy by him simultaneously! what are we actually conveying when we begin a sentence like that? it was part and parcel of the package. a little conjunction transduction made all the difference. he was right. a throwaway line.
if you've ever dreamed of getting up close and personal with a rocket launch, your time is now on tuesday morning, nasa will broadcast its first-ever rocket launch livestream in 360-degree video, providing an unprecedented vantage point that will make viewers feel as if they are standing on the launch pad at cape canaveral. make sure your virtual reality headset is handy; people who have them will be able to "look around and experience the view as if they were actually standing on the launch pad," nasa said in a press release. the launch of the united launch alliance atlas v rocket—aimed at transporting supplies to the international space station—is scheduled for a 30-minute window beginning at 11:11 a.m. while the minimum safe viewing distance is typically miles away from the launch pad, this livestream promises viewers a much closer look at a powerful rocket launch, or what nasa is calling a "pads-eye view." the rocket will be carrying a cygnus spacecraft made by orbital atk, with more than 7,600 pounds of scientific research, crew supplies, and other materials destined for the orbiting laboratory. the 360-degree livestream will be accessible on the nasa television youtube channel starting 10 minutes prior to liftoff. et.

as vanity fair’s kurt eichenwald pointed out while most newspaper endorsements don’t influence voters the way they once did, it’s rare for historically conservative papers to endorse a democratic candidate for president. for the first time in its 126-year history, this newspaper endorsed a democrat the arizona republic has only endorsed republican candidates for president in its 126-year history but this year is different, the paper’s editorial board wrote on tuesday. while most newspaper endorsements don’t influence voters the way they once did, it’s rare for historically conservative papers to endorse a democratic candidate for president. the paper praised clinton’s leadership, and wrote that the democratic candidate’s stance on immigration issues is far closer to what arizona residents want than anything trump has suggested. the endorsement editorial, which said the paper has "a deep philosophical appreciation for conservative ideals and republican principles," praised clinton for her experience, and trashed the gop nominee. the arizona republic is not the only conservative paper to endorse clinton this year. as vanity fair’s clinton has received far more newspaper endorsements, many from conservative papers, than trump. the editorial also called out trump for consistently making degrading comments toward women and minorities, which it said show "a stunning lack of human decency." the paper wrote that trump’s lack of control poses a real threat to national security and called his recent "conversion to conservatism unconvincing." hillary "clinton has the temperament and experience to be president," the board wrote. " has the temperament and experience to be president," the board wrote. " in june, the dallas morning news endorsed clinton and bluntly stated that trump did not deserve its readers’ votes. new hampshire’s union leader this month published a blistering editorial condemning trump’s candidacy, and endorsing libertarian gary johnson. "instead of offering solutions, he hangs scapegoats like piñatas and invites people to take a swing," the editorial said. donald trump does not."
"we were always thinking there would be more contagious cancer out there, but we didn’t know where they would be discovered," said elizabeth p. murchison, a cancer biologist at the university of cambridge who was not involved in the new study. he and his colleagues began to wonder if other species of clams or related animals — known collectively as bivalves — had contagious cancers of their own, and, if so, why. tasmanian facial tumor disease, as it was eventually called, appears to have had its start in a single tasmanian devil that lived in the 1980s. they concluded that this strain of contagious cancer must have started in pullet shell clams and then jumped species, infecting golden carpet shell clams. but they did discover that dna in the tumor cells carried a genetic sequence not found in healthy cells in the clams. dr. goff and his colleagues are now trying to turn the contagious cancer in shellfish into a model for human cancers. transmitted by bites, the cancer spread to other tasmanian devils and acquired mutations along the way that helped make it even more infectious. but last year, stephen p. goff, a molecular biologist at columbia university, and his colleagues found contagious cancer in soft-shell clams. carol reinisch, a marine biologist at environment canada, found that the cancer clustered in populations, as if it was caused by an outbreak of some sort. even stranger, the cancer cells in the golden carpet shell clams did not develop from the species’s own cells. instead, the scientists matched the cancer’s dna to pullet shell clams, which live in the same intertidal beds off the coast of spain. with eight contagious cancers now on the books, dr. murchison has started to wonder if they are not as peculiar as previously thought. "that’s really quite incredible," dr. murchison said, noting that scientists had tried without success to infect foxes and other dog relatives with canine cancer. the evolution of a contagious cancer in some ways may mirror the evolution of a single tumor in the body. the new research "does raise the possibility that these types of diseases could arise in humans," dr. murchison said. however they arise, they drive a cell to multiply uncontrollably until the cancer is wiped out by the immune system or kills its victim. dogs, too, can get a type of contagious cancer called canine transmissible venereal tumor, which jumps from host to host during sex. in shellfish, dr. murchison said, "we can see the effect of evolution on their genomes in a more pronounced way." but dna in the tumor cells did not match that of the affected animals, studies showed. for years, tasmanian devils and dogs were the only species known to contract contagious cancer. but dr. goff and his colleagues could not locate any pullet shell clams with this disease. in every case, the researchers reported in the journal nature, the cancers in the animals were contagious. "somehow, this cancer has been spreading from clam to clam up the coast," dr. goff said. but in these cases, the cancer does not spread like a true parasite from host to host. after examining the dna, they confirmed that the cancer cells in different clams all came from a single common ancestor. the two researchers found no evidence of a virus in the soft-shell clams. the new study, she said, shows that contagious cancer can indeed cross the species barrier. in 1965, scientists put mosquitoes in a cage with hamsters, one of which had cancer. they chose to study cancers in mussels, cockles and golden carpet shell clams. as it turned out, the cancer in cockles comprises two separate strains. the mosquito carried the cancer cells to the healthy hamsters. "i don’t think we should be starting to panic," dr. murchison said. yet it’s not inconceivable that a human cancer might gain that power. scientists have determined that the cancer originated in dogs 11,000 years ago. it killed all the vulnerable pullet shell clams, leaving only resistant ones behind. so should people worry about an outbreak of infectious cancer? they hope to find clues to metastasis, the way cancer spreads through the body. she suspected a cancer-causing virus moving from host to host. from new york to prince edward island, these clams have suffered from aggressive tumors since the 1970s. in the 1990s tasmanian devils in australia began developing deadly face tumors. there have been rare reports of people transmitting cancer. either way, the cancer stays inside the body where it started. for help, dr. reinisch turned to dr. goff. a second strain of the cancer was identified last year. "we are now at four for four," dr. goff said. in the traditional view of cancer, mutations strike a cell. an estimated 0.04 percent of organ transplant recipients contract cancer from the donor organ, for example. a decade ago, scientists discovered two exceptions. these mutations have several causes, including toxins and viruses. the tumor usually disappears in a few months, however. "they might be emerging fairly often," she said. cancer is contagious among clams. what about us?
a lifeway research poll asked 1,001 people if they agreed with the statement, "i believe the battles in syria are all part of the prophecies of the book of revelation," and 32 percent of them said yes. 1/3 of americans believe this about the syria conflict most things aren't really the end of the world, but one-third of americans who were surveyed believe that the syria conflict is an indication that our days are numbered. though he believes the bible does predict future events in the middle east, the author of the end: a complete overview of bible prophecy and the end of days said that he "does not think the trouble in syria was predicted in the bible." twenty-six percent agreed with the assertion that "u.s. military intervention in syria might lead to the battle of armageddon that’s spoken about in the book of revelation." a biblical passage which prophesies the destruction of damascus and links it to the coming of armageddon is leading many people to think that the current violence is an apocalyptic omen. stetzer said that he could see why attaching biblical significance to the syria conflict would appeal to many christians, because, "for christians, the end of the world doesn’t mean despair. location and income also skewed the results, with southerners and members of households making less than $25,000 per year being much more likely to connect syria with the end of days. gender played a role in responses, as women were more likely than men to draw a corollary between biblical prophecy and the current situation in syria. in addition, one in five people polled agreed with the statement, "i believe the world will end in my lifetime." mark hitchcock of faith bible church in edmond, okla., speculates that people looking for answers in tough economic and political times "want to know that god is in charge. however, syria's shared border with israel, as well as the explicit biblical mention of damascus, may account for the significant number of affirmative responses. isaiah 17:1 is one of the passages most frequently referenced when relating syria to the end of the world. he said that previous u.s. military actions like the war in afghanistan or 1990s air strikes on bosnia "didn't get the same reaction." (king james version) ed stetzer, president of lifeway research, was surprised by the results of the survey. they want to know that someone has his hands on the wheel," according to lifeway. behold, damascus is taken away from being a city, and it shall be a ruinous heap. the end is really a new beginning." it states: the burden of damascus. the rev.
the horrible incident that cut my honeymoon short the honeymoon is the light at the end of the tunnel for many brides and grooms-to-be who have had it up to here with wedding planning. after hitting a speed bump and falling off of the vehicle, her husband shattered his shoulder and rudner rotated her hip, cutting the trip short. at a stop in mykonos during their cruise through the greek isles, rudner and her husband rented atvs. "at least i get my checkmark for 'in sickness and in health' and 'for better or for worse,'" she said. in a huffpost live segment that aired tuesday, alejandra rudner told host caitlyn becker about the disastrous events that plagued her european honeymoon. but unfortunately, the much-awaited trip doesn't always turn out as planned.
this drug could add five years to your dog’s life when examining the benefits of a drug that extends life expectancy, it’s not enough to look at how many years are being added on, but the quality of the years being added. after the results that have been seen in the mice study, the researchers believe that they could see a dog’s life extended by up to five years by making them more impervious to health issues such as cancer, kidney failure, and dementia. geneticist daniel promislow told the telegraph: "if rapamycin has a similar effect in dogs – and it’s important to keep in mind we don’t know this yet – then a typical large dog could live two to three years longer, and a smaller dog might live four years longer." promislow remains optimistic on both fronts, saying, "if we can understand how to improve the quality and length of life, it’s good for our pets and good for us. the drug is currently being tested on 32 middle-aged dogs (6-9 years old) for its affects on both increase canine longevity and dogs’ overall health. not only would it increase the length of dogs’ overall lives, but it would compound that by increasing their number of "good" years. researchers at the university of washington’s dog aging project are quick to point that out when they talk about their hopes for rapamycin. the trial will last up to six months, after which, the dogs will continue to be monitored to hopefully determine an increase in life expectancy. a longer trial is underway to determine how extended treatments with rapamycin affect the longevity in dogs. the drug, also known as sirolimus, was originally developed and prescribed to prevent rejection of transplanted organs in humans, and also to fight cancer. however, in low doses, rapamycin was shown to slow aging processes and increase the lifespan of mice. it’s win-win."
"our core commitments as a catholic university are incompatible with the inclusion of elective abortion coverage in the university's health plans," engh wrote in the letter. "an elective abortion is a serious moral evil, and if it’s in our power to end that on whatever level we can operate, we should do our best to end that moral evil," bretzke said to cbs. just this week, loyola marymount university, a catholic university in los angeles, also announced that it will eliminate elective abortion coverage for its staff starting next year. another catholic university drops abortion coverage a second catholic university in california this week has dropped elective abortion coverage for its staff. president obama's affordable care act requires that birth control be covered but allows employers to restrict abortion coverage. health plans must cover birth control under the affordable care act, but obamacare allows employers to offer plans that restrict abortion coverage. the move appears to be part of a trend among catholic campuses seeking to uphold their religious beliefs while employing and enrolling many non-catholics, the los angeles times notes. in a letter dated oct. 3, santa clara university president michael engh announced the 2014 change to the jesuit university's 1,600 employees. the move by both universities was met with outrage by some of its staff, who thought there should have been more dialogue before a decision was made. the change by the universities moves in the opposite direction of california's abortion law. father jim bretzke, a professor of moral theology at boston college, sympathized with santa clara's decision. "they believe that that is a moral evil and so they’re pursuing dropping that from their packages." if you’re more interested in playing the "hater" card than you are in confessing your own hate; if you want to arrogantly lecture, rather than humbly learn; if you don’t want to feel guilt in your soul when you are guilty of sin; if you want to be enabled rather than confronted, there are many universities across the land (in missouri and elsewhere) that will give you exactly what you want, but oklahoma wesleyan isn’t one of them. everett piper, president of oklahoma wesleyan university, weighed in with a letter to the campus community: this past week, i actually had a student come forward after a university chapel service and complain because he felt "victimized" by a sermon on the topic of 1 corinthians 13. oklahoma wesleyan is not a "safe place", but rather, a place to learn: to learn that life isn’t about you, but about others; that the bad feeling you have while listening to a sermon is called guilt; that the way to address it is to repent of everything that’s wrong with you rather than blame others for everything that’s wrong with them. this fall, protests at yale, princeton, duke and the university of missouri — where the chancellor and system president resigned in the midst of turmoil — drew national attention to the concerns many students have about how minorities are treated on campus. so here’s my advice: if you want the chaplain to tell you you’re a victim rather than tell you that you need virtue, this may not be the university you’re looking for. if you want to complain about a sermon that makes you feel less than loving for not showing love, this might be the wrong place. we don’t believe that you have been victimized every time you feel guilty and we don’t issue "trigger warnings" before altar calls. it appears that this young scholar felt offended because a homily on love made him feel bad for not showing love! i have a message for this young man and all others who care to listen. we believe the content of your character is more important than the color of your skin. an altar call is supposed to make you feel bad! emmy-lou explains that all you need to do is close your eyes or simply stare at a fixed point if you are at your desk for example and place your feet flat on the floor for stability. then start counting the breath in and out through the nose as per the breathing ritual in the pink box. 'a sigh is wonderful as it's effectively telling the body that we are going to hit the reset button on the pattern,' she said. next, turn all focus to pulling in your breath, sucking the oxygen deep into your belly through the nose as though pulling breath in through two straws up the nostrils. emmy lou says you should repeat this eight times - or at whichever number feels good and comfortable for you - visualising and allowing the shoulders, eyes, mouth and brow to soften. speaking to femail, she explained: 'when worry kicks off and stress kicks in, you need to make space. so what if there was a simple three-minute solution for clearing your mind and erasing your worries instantly? according to emmy-lou knowles, mediation coach and intuitive healer at www.youremmylou.com, there is - and anyone can master it. how to completely banish stress in just three minutes juggling high-pressured jobs with starting families and maintaining social lives is leaving our generation highly anxious. you don’t need incense, candles or to be sat legs crossed on the floor – let’s be realistic.' then, simply sigh.
lawmakers are going to punish university for not shutting down "sex week" a group of conservative tennessee lawmakers plan to punish the state's flagship public university over a student-organized event in early march called "sex week" -- by dramatically cutting back its ability to host guest speakers. state lawmakers are moving forward this week with a vote on legislation that would bar the university of tennessee (ut) and other public institutions of higher education from using institutional revenue to "engage and pay visiting or guest speakers for events." last week, two other state senators -- education committee chairwoman dolores gresham (r-somerville) and government operations committee chairman mike bell (r-riceville) -- issued a letter to university leaders warning that state funding for the university may be in jeopardy, even though no taxpayer funds went toward sex week. sex week organizers told huffpost that there have been no protests against it on campus, while an ut administrator said in february that the university had received no calls of complaint from local community members or alumni. they are being pushed in response to sex week, a week-long student-organized and student-funded event at ut's knoxville campus discussing sexuality, lgbt issues, sexual health and related topics. ut administration and faculty leaders, who firmly oppose both bills, agree with campfield on that one point -- that a university should be a place where many voices are heard. bell and gresham argued in their letter that the university could have shut down the event on the grounds that it was obscene. university leaders have repeatedly explained to lawmakers that they could not block sex week because the first amendment protects college students' right to speak, and legal experts have backed them up. but ut system president joe dipietro told the chattanooga times free press that the university did not have "any indication from anybody that there's an obscenity situation at all in this program." another bill would require state colleges to distribute student fees to pay for guest speakers "proportionally based on membership" of the student groups inviting the speaker. sadly, when you look at a list of the paid speakers for the university the vast majority are from one point of view and balancing points of view are minimized. "if people realize we're an institution that doesn't allow outside speakers, i think that could have a significant impact," ut faculty senate president david golden told the tv station wate. nonetheless, the tennessee state house has already passed a resolution condemning the students who organized sex week, which the house called "an atrocious event." a ut-knoxville graduate student provided the huffington post with a form email she received from campfield in response to her objections to his legislation. both of these bills were authored by state sen. stacey campfield (r-knoxville) and were scheduled for their first committee vote on wednesday. campfield previously gained national recognition -- and stirred national controversy -- in 2012 for his "don't say gay" bill, which would have prevented schoolteachers from discussing homosexuality. even commencement speakers who asked the school to cover travel and lodging costs or who sought a speaker fee would be eliminated. (the legislation would not prevent the hiring of guest faculty to conduct classes for which students receive credit.) "i can think of no better place for contradictory, conflicting, controversial ideas to be presented than on a university campus." the legislation ultimately did not pass that year or when it was resurrected in 2013. on monday, a petition opposing campfield's bills, signed by 3,500 students, was presented at the statehouse. the lawmaker said: while i support diversity of thought at the university, what is currently in place is not diversity. bill haslam (r) has not said whether he would sign the bills into law. attendance at sex week increased this year, according to the school's daily beacon. in addition, 650 student letters were sent to lawmakers friday. gov.
