one of the most ‘annoying things’ on the entire planet just turned 20 who's birthday is it, you ask? i feel ancient 😵 the sound was remixed into a song by axel f.  you have been warned. i don't often feel old however finding out crazy frog is now 20 years old... it goes like this: student daniel malmedahl recorded the sound in 1997, in an attempt to create the sound of an internal combustion engine. fast forward six years and another swedish student, erik wernquist, gave the sound an animated frog. a swedish tv channel discovered it after he put the sound on his website and he performed it on air. people can't believe how long it's been... the blue amphibian who irritated people all over the world for practically all of 2004 and 2005. the story of crazy frog is as weird as the thing itself. you have been warned. you remember crazy frog, right?
however, as understanding science explains, "although astrologers seek to explain the natural world, they don't usually attempt to critically evaluate whether those explanations are valid — and this is a key part of science." see also: 6 questions to ask before sharing science on the internet "and, indeed, having such a program organized by a hospital leads into the completely false assumption that astrology might have some kind of scientific background which, of course, it completely lacks. however, as understanding science explains, "some expectations generated by astrology are so general that any outcome could be interpreted as fitting the expectations; if treated this way, astrology is not testable." diego andrés golombek, a professor at the university of quilmes in argentina, told quartz, "astrology can be harmless, of course, unless it gives directions and instructions into how to proceed with, for example, an illness or medical treatment." there haven’t been many studies that investigate the science behind astrology, but of the few that have, the results have failed to support the validity of astrological views. the guidance is given based on the patient’s sign — whether he or she is an aries, taurus, or so forth — and the leading astrologist develops a star chart for each patient. so, unfortunately for everyone who swears their daily horoscope is always on point or blames their stubbornness on being a scorpio or a taurus, it appears that there’s not much scientific evidence to back those claims. a hospital in argentina is reportedly using astrology to help treat some mental health conditions, like depression and anxiety, by giving patients an understanding of their astrological personalities. there are a few foundational ways to evaluate whether a concept is scientific, and the university of california, berkeley’s understanding science website lays out a "science checklist." so far, it can’t be said that astrology relies on replicable scientific evidence — and replicability is a must for an idea to prove itself as valid. for instance, a study tested the accuracy of astrological charts in describing the personality traits of 193 study participants, and the results indicated that the scores were at a level consistent with chance. you should read this next: science explainer: why gmos aren’t harmful to your health you should read this next: science explainer: why gmos aren’t harmful to your health you should read this next: science explainer: why gmos aren’t harmful to your health further, it uses a set of rules about the relative positions and movements of the stars and planets to predict and explain worldly events and human personality. so, based on the evidence (or lack thereof), is there any real science to support astrology? yes, astrology’s basic premise is that the sun, moon, planets, and constellations have an effect on humans and earthly events. plus, astrology doesn’t lead to ongoing research, which is another key part of science. for something to have a true scientific basis, it has to encompass testable ideas. does it attempt to explain the natural world? unsurprisingly, the astrology workshop is being met with criticism over its scientific validity. explainer: is there any science behind astrology? photo credit: pixabay.com looking at the star signs from a scientific standpoint. until then, astrology will have to remain in the realm of pseudoscience. does astrology use testable ideas? does it rely on evidence? 2. i am horrified by this prospect!" 1. 3.

morgan stanley analysts estimate that amazon's apparel sales grew by $1.1 billion in the most recent quarter, while the department stores nordstrom, sears, macy's, kohl's, jcpenney, and dillard's collectively lost $225 million in apparel sales in the same period. "we expect online (primarily amazon) will continue to take share from department stores, but at an accelerating pace over the next five years given new evidence that amazon is gaining traction in fashion," the analysts wrote in a recent note. that's more than the combined online sales of macy's, nordstrom, kohl's, gap, and victoria's secret parent l brands in the same period, according to bloomberg. over the past couple of years, amazon has ramped up its investment in fashion by launching its own private-label clothing brands and sponsoring the first new york men's fashion week. in a 2012 interview with the new york times, amazon ceo jeff bezos gave a simple reason that amazon was investing in fashion: "gross profit dollars per unit will be much higher on a fashion item," than with cheaper products, he said. the company has also hired executives from luxury fashion companies, such as julie gilhart, the barneys new york fashion director whom amazon reportedly hired as a consultant, and vogue editor caroline palmer. department-store executives have blamed declining apparel sales on the weather and on consumers' changing shopping habits, which in recent years have gravitated more toward big-ticket items like televisions and vacations over clothing. amazon is now the biggest seller of clothes online in the us, with its apparel sales totaling $16.3 billion last year, bloomberg reports. also in the past few years, amazon has started to shift its fashion strategy toward offering more high-end designer names, such as zac posen and stuart weitzman. amazon is now second only to walmart in terms of overall apparel market share, according to morgan stanley analysts. an unlikely company is crushing america's biggest clothing stores an unlikely company has suddenly catapulted to the top of the fashion world: amazon. the apparel market has only grown 1% annually in the past 15 years, according to morgan stanley. but department stores' loss so far has been amazon's gain, according to morgan stanley analysts. amazon made one of its first major pushes into the category 10 years ago with the purchase of the clothing website shopbop. the company's rise as a leader in apparel sales has been swift and relatively quiet. luxury fashion websites are typically well-merchandised and highly curated — not things for which amazon is necessarily known. three years later, amazon bought the online shoe retailer zappos for $850 million. but amazon's strategy appears to be working. that shift has had some industry experts scratching their heads.
the majority of people don’t use bars of soap these days but, for those who do, be aware that leaving a bar of soap in one spot could be encouraging bacteria to grow on it—bacteria that you’re then going to spread over your entire body the next time you lather up. not washing your feet you might be thinking that your feet make contact with plenty of water while you’re in the shower, so there’s no real reason to actually bend down and give them a proper wash. you’d be wrong, though. using scented soaps yes, those soaps that make your bathroom smell like a tropical rainforest or a freshly-made vanilla cupcake do transport you to a place of olfactory luxury while sudsing up, but those very fragrances could be doing a number on your skin at the same time. showering in hard water some people may not even know how to tell if their water is considered hard, but figuring it out and taking steps to adjust it could save your hair and skin from a lot of damage. those with skin conditions such as acne or rosacea may also find that washing their face with hot water can cause excessive redness and irritation—it could even burst a blood vessel in your face if you wash too aggressively. if you don’t actually want to store your razor outside of the shower, at least make sure that you hang it up when you’re done using it so it can air dry. if you have reasons for resisting the switch to liquid body wash, try finding a wire soap dish or one that has holes in the bottom so any remaining water can drain away once you’re out of the shower. avoiding cold showers most people wouldn’t even dream of standing in cold water for more than a second, let alone taking an entire shower in water that’s anything less than steaming hot. this video demonstrates why: your hair. believe it or not, some of the things you do every day while taking a shower could be affecting you in ways you’ve never thought of. anyone who chooses to exfoliate their skin every day is aggressively going after fresh skin cells, which can make your skin red and irritated as a result. there’s no excuse for just letting the soap suds run down to your toes anymore—imagine what you’re color out of their strands, or at least causes their tint to fade a little quicker. use a gentle cleanser and avoid washing your face in the shower, particularly if you have acne-prone skin or rosacea. washing your face without a doubt, it’s easier and less messy to wash your face when you’re already in the shower. in addition to speeding up your metabolism, a study done in 2009 suggests that regularly taking a cold shower could even help you lose weight over time. anyone who notices their skin seems particularly irritated after a shower should look to their soap as the first culprit. keep your skin in the best shape. plus, you won’t have to worry about the scent of your soap mixing with the scent of your perfume to create "questionable" smells. not washing or replacing your loofah regularly be honest, how long has the same loofah been hanging in your shower? however, did you know that some of the most common shower habits might not actually be that healthy? shower habits you a handful of studies have found a link between left-handedness and creativity, conferred, some think, by the fact that left-handed folks constantly have to adjust to a right-handed world. when considering the risks and benefits of any given decision, inconsistent-handed people (as researchers call them) are more likely to focus on the risks, whereas people at the outer edges of the handedness spectrum pay more attention to potential benefits. over the last few years, a number of studies have concluded that it’s not which hand is dominant that matters—it’s the degree of dominance. they’ve studied whether lefties are better at problem-solving, and if they’re more likely to die young. from all these studies on left-handedness, we can conclude one thing, and one thing alone: science is complicated. some researchers conclude that lefties are no smarter than righties, while others say that left-handedness comes with a clear intellectual advantage. according to researchers, very few people are truly entirely left- or right-handed; it’s more of a spectrum. scientists have been chipping away at the peculiarities of left-handedness, which occurs in about 10 percent of the population, for a long time. they seem to be more empathetic and better able to view things from other people’s perspectives. we use our left hands for some things and our right hands for other tasks. if you’re a lefty who enjoys feeling superior, we’re not going to tell you to tone it down. these experiments have found that people toward the middle of the spectrum are more flexible thinkers. it seems we’ve been aiming our stereotypes a little too far to the left. they’ve looked into the purported links between left-handedness and things like mental illness, faulty immune systems, and criminal behavior. the left-handed brand has come a long way in the last few decades. have you got a big question you'd like us to answer? we associate left-handedness with intelligence, out-of-the-box thinking, and artistic talent. the majority of people no longer assume that southpaws are tools of satan, alight with hellfire. other studies found no link at all. for all we know, you could be right. today’s lefties are surrounded by a far more benevolent glow. does being left-handed really make you more creative? the answer to that is a definitive ... maybe. might not even be the right question. but are these flattering generalizations backed up by science? if so, let us know by emailing us at bigquestions@mentalfloss.com. are lefties more prone to schizophrenia and learning disabilities? is there really a left-handed personality? are lefties really more creative? that depends on who you ask. but "are lefties different?" they may even sleep differently. but who knows? this is ever-changing, constantly evolving science.

consumers can try to avoid 1,4-dioxane by avoiding the following ingredients: peg, polyethylene, polyethylene glycol, polyoxyethylene and -eth- as such, sen. chuck schumer of new york is calling for the ingredient, which he claims causes eye, nose and throat irritation, to be removed from all personal care products in the us. the cancer-causing ingredient lurking in your beauty products: lawmakers are calling for a ban on a carcinogenic ingredient commonly found in body washes and lotions. luckily, schumer insists that 1,4-dioxane is relatively easy for brands to eradicate noting in a statement that "vacuum stripping" is a cost-effective way to remove it from personal care formulations. but despite that, it’s still found in a shocking 46 per cent of products and brands aren’t even required to list it on the label. found in everything from body washes to hand soaps and lotions, the environmental protection agency claims it is a likely carcinogen. a byproduct of other chemicals used in beauty products 1,4-dioxne can often escape your attention on the list of ingredients. when it comes to grooming, we slather and lather beauty products onto our skin in an effort to look better and smell fresher. chances are, once your products go down the drain you don’t stop and think about what could be in them. now, a new ingredient is coming under fire; 1,4-dioxane. what’s more, it has an ewg (environmental working group) score of 8, 10 being the most toxic. but what exactly is the true cost of our vanity? or maybe you did when microbeads – the small pieces of plastic in facial scrubs and makeup – made headlines last year.
the patient lost 113 pounds in 23 weeks on a diet of whole grains and "prebiotics" -- nondigestible high-fiber foods (examples include garlic, onions, chicory root, dandelion greens and asparagus) that feed friendly bacteria, like the bifidobacterium in your yogurt, and starve the bad. fact is, the little buggers have species-specific appetites (a microbiologist can tell what types of food you eat and predict whether you're slender or not just from the variety of microbes in your stool sample). a study published in the american journal of clinical nutrition found that red wine's polyphenols -- those compounds whose heart-healthy benefits you've heard so much about -- also have prebiotic potential. after a month of this regime, volunteers in an fmri study at ucla's school of medicine showed brain activity that's associated with greater emotional stability (a stronger connection between pain-processing circuits and the prefrontal cortex), compared with the non-probiotic control group. zhao transferred the bacterium to his lab mice -- and here's the shocker -- they became fat and diabetic (control animals on the same high-fat diet did not), suggesting that enterobacter helped cause obesity. turns out, m. vaccae are among the gut bacteria that trigger a rise in serotonin -- which not only calms us but also boosts memory and concentration. when microbes digest compounds in meat called carnitine and lecithin, the liver uses the byproduct to make an artery-hardener that may be even more of a culprit in heart disease than cholesterol: trimethylamine n-oxide (tmao). "bad guy" bacteria may be partly to blame for your junk-food cravings -- by, for instance, sending out sugar-and-fat-jonesing signals via the gut-to-brain vagus nerve. here's a taste... by jena pincott "you're taking the wrong chill pill" try this to preempt stress-triggered pig-outs: two 1/4-cup servings daily of yogurt that is (preferably) unsweetened and (crucially) probiotic-enriched (look for b. animalis, s. thermophilus and l. bulgaricus). "you struggle to burn off your muffin top" while the blame for a big belly doesn't lie entirely with its wee inhabitants, the wrong microbes can contribute to it and make it harder to lose. just one glass (9 ounces) of red wine daily for a month meaningfully boosted drinkers' ratios of good-to-bad gut bacteria (compared with alcohol-free and polyphenol-free gin-drinking controls). in a study led by liping zhao at shanghai jiao tong university, a 385-pound patient had unusually high counts of a fat-loving bug called enterobacter in his gut. the surprising thing that may be making you crave junk food the 100 trillion microbes that live in your gut know -- and influence -- you from the inside out. "you found wisdom among the dahlias" a bacterium in soil called m. vaccae may be a cognitive enhancer, found a study published in behavioural processes. "you really love a smooth grenache" good news here if you think dandelion greens are more compelling when paired with a strong drink. the problem here is that certain red-meat-loving gut bacteria increase your heart attack risk, found a study at the cleveland clinic. we inhale and ingest this microbe when we're around dirt and plants; to what extent might it help us navigate life's mazes? note: only if you have bacteria in your gut that are accustomed to meat -- vegans don't -- could you churn out tmao. "sorry, you have a high-steak problem" now consider pairing that grenache with something other than short ribs. one explanation: the good bacteria in yogurt send out signals that increase serotonin, the neurotransmitter that famously reduces anxiety. "a number of gut microbes form so-called spores -- environmentally hyper-resistant cells that help to colonize them," explains james scott, professor of occupational & environmental health at the university of toronto. plus, some microbes may help you extract more calories from food and increase fat storage -- effectively making you put on weight. as it turns out, the bug triggers chronic low-grade inflammation, which leads to insulin resistance and weight gain. "your housemates influence you more than you think" ok, you don't like yogurt. after mice ate a peanut-butter-flavored dose of the bug, they navigated mazes twice as fast as those not treated. very, very hungry" surprisingly, gut bacteria may also control appetite, nudging you toward the oozy, creamy, crunchy foods they like. now consider pairing that grenache with something other than short ribs. a caveat: the benefit doesn't apply to sweet dessert wines, which presumably feed the wrong microbiota. they're found on surfaces and in dust; we inhale and ingest them. (for mice, the "superbrain" effect lasted for at least a week after the last exposure.) (but burger lovers, be heartened: scientists are working on ways to identify and eventually target the villain bacteria.) but if your housemates eat them -- good news! while most probiotic eaters don't have big mood changes, says lead author kirsten tillisch, md, many (anecdotally) say they feel calmer over time. ongoing research focuses on the subtle, cumulative, long-term effects of microbes as anxiety reducers. so what can they tell you about yourself? their healthy brain-boosting microbes have probably taken up residence in you. or kimchi, tempeh, sauerkraut or other "friendly-flora" foods. "we generally believe that if your brain is really in a comatose kind of situation, or you’re not really responsive, that your perception—how you feel about things—may also be significantly decreased," says david hui, an oncologist and palliative-care specialist who researches the signs of approaching death. "roughly from the last two weeks until the last breath, somewhere in that interval, people become too sick, or too drowsy, or too unconscious, to tell us what they’re experiencing," says margaret campbell, a professor of nursing at wayne state university who has worked in palliative care for decades. during six-and-a-half years of treatment, although my mother saw two general practitioners, six oncologists, a cardiologist, several radiation technicians, nurses at two chemotherapy facilities, and surgeons at three different clinics—not once, to my knowledge, had anyone talked to her about what would happen as she died. the "patients’ pre-death dreams were frequently so intense that the dream carried into wakefulness and the dying often experienced them as waking reality," the researchers write in the journal of palliative medicine. when she was awake, it was only the most basic part of her that was there: the part that told her legs to move to get her to the bathroom, the automated steps in brushing her teeth and then wiping the sink afterward. for many dying people, "the brain does the same thing that the body does in that it starts to sacrifice areas which are less critical to survival," says david hovda, director of the ucla brain injury research center. jimo borjigin, a neuroscientist at the university of michigan, first became intrigued by this subject when she noticed something strange in the brains of animals in another experiment: just before the animals died, neurochemicals in the brain suddenly surged. my mother had been the one to decide, with her doctor’s blessing, to stop pursuing the dwindling chemo options, and she had been the one to ask her doctor to call hospice. now, americans who have access to medical care often die gradually, of lingering diseases like most terminal cancers or complications from diabetes or dementia, rather than quickly from, say, a farm accident or the flu. * * * in her last couple of weeks, when my mother’s mind seemed to be floating off somewhere else most of the time, she would sometimes lift her arms into the air, plucking at invisible objects with her fingers. for those who do die gradually, there’s often a final, rapid slide that happens in roughly the last few days of life—a phase known as "active dying." "if you’re focusing attention, doing something, trying to figure out a word or trying to remember a face—when you’re doing high-level cognitive activity, these features go up," borjigin says. recent research points to evidence that the sharpening of the senses some people report also seems to match what we know about the brain’s response to dying. "as the brain begins to change and start to die, different parts become excited, and one of the parts that becomes excited is the visual system," hovda explains. the rats’ brains showed higher power in different frequency waves, and also what is known as coherence—the electrical activity from different parts of the brain working together. ultimately, because most people lose awareness or consciousness in their last few hours or days, it’s hard to know for certain how much patients are suffering. during this time, hallenbeck writes in palliative care perspectives, his guide to palliative care for physicians, people tend to lose their senses and desires in a certain order. he compares the breakdown to what happens in aging: people tend to lose their abilities for complex or executive planning, learning motor skills—and, in what turns out to be a very important function, inhibition. according to the centers for disease control’s most recent figures, americans are most likely to die of heart disease, cancer, or chronic pulmonary lung disease. "they see lights and then they describe the experience as ‘realer than real.’" she realized the sudden release of neurochemicals might help to explain this feeling. the way death is talked about tends to be based on what family, friends, and medical professionals see, rather than accounts of what dying actually feels like. "the predominant quality of pre-death dreams/visions was a sense of personal meaning, which frequently carried emotional significance for the patient," they report. despite a growing body of research about death, the actual, physical experience of dying—the last few days or moments—remains shrouded in mystery. being at the bedside of an unresponsive dying person can feel like trying to find out whether someone is home by looking through thick-curtained windows. * * * a week or two after we spoke to the nurse, my mother sank into a state where she was rarely conscious. but that’s not what it feels like to the person dying, as far as doctors can tell. what it feels like to die "do you want to know what will happen as your body starts shutting down?" most people dying of cancer need pain medication to keep them comfortable, campbell notes—and the medicine usually works. "we can see the effect of black holes, but it is extremely difficult, if not impossible, to look inside them. "a lot of cardiac-arrest survivors describe that during their unconscious period, they have this amazing experience in their brain," she says. a month or two earlier, she’d been able to take the dog for daily walks in the mountains and travel to australia with my father. in fact, researchers led by christopher kerr at a hospice center outside buffalo, new york, conducted a study of dying people’s dreams. "there are some patients that just get really, really old and just fade away, and there’s no distress." when people become too weak to cough or swallow, some start to make a noise in the backs of their throats. so, we thought, if you’re alert or aroused, similar parameters should also go up in the dying brain. in fact, medical researchers believe that the phenomenon—which is commonly called a death rattle—probably doesn’t hurt. "pre-death dreams were frequently so intense that the dream carried into wakefulness." while scientists had known that brain neurons continued to fire after a person died, this was different. james hallenbeck, a palliative-care specialist at stanford university, often compares dying to black holes. (patients were interviewed every day, so the same people often reported dreams about multiple subjects.) it was 2005, and my mother had reached the end of treatments for metastatic breast cancer. most of the patients interviewed, 88 percent, had at least one dream or vision. having a disease associated with pain doesn’t mean you’ll necessarily endure a difficult death, either. now, she was weak, exhausted from the disease and chemotherapy and pain medication. "if they’re getting a good, comprehensive pain regimen, they can die peacefully," she says. seventy-two percent of the patients dreamed about reuniting with people who had already died. "the waves get higher and higher, and eventually, they carry the person out to sea." the researchers say the dreams often helped decrease the fear of death. once, i captured her hands in mine and asked what she’d been doing. my mother and i sat across from the hospice nurse in my parents’ colorado home. whether dying is physically painful, or how painful it is, appears to vary. but modern medicine has radically changed how long the end of life can be stretched. her mind turned away from her children and husband for the first time. as one passes the ‘event horizon,’ apparently the laws of physics begin to change." for most of the patients, the dreams were comforting and positive. and those dreams usually felt different to them from normal dreams. "you may or may not even be aware of what’s happening." "there are some kinds of conditions where pain is inevitable," campbell says. "suddenly, all the different regions of the brain became synchronized," she says. "and so that’s where people begin to see light." the sound can be deeply disturbing, as if the patient is suffering. but what we felt most was a sense of relief. this half-dreaming, half-waking state is common in dying people. i wanted to know where her mind was. "these are well-used parameters in studying human consciousness in awake humans. fifty-nine percent said they dreamed about getting ready to travel somewhere. the last senses to go are usually hearing and touch." i wanted to know what she was thinking about. they anesthetized eight rats, and then stopped their hearts. borjigin and her research team tried an experiment. they exert an increasingly strong gravitational pull the closer one gets to them. medicine is just beginning to peek beyond the horizon. * * * until about 100 years ago, almost all dying happened quickly. twenty-eight percent dreamed about meaningful experiences in the past. for one thing, the dreams seemed clearer, more real. is the person sleeping, dreaming, experiencing something supernatural? still, we weren’t prepared for the nurse’s question. the neurons were secreting new chemicals, and in large amounts. in fact, that was the case." my mother and i exchanged glances, a little shocked. what does dying feel like? on thursday, the state highway patrol posted this very clear message to their facebook page: the state highway patrol says it has "no plans to increase patrols on highways near the state line to look for those transporting marijuana into the state from colorado," but that the "bottom line" is that "any amount of marijuana in either dried or in plant form in the state of wyoming is illegal to possess." albany county sheriff dave o'malley told the laramie boomerang that his office expects to see more drivers under the influence of marijuana as well as drivers carrying pot out of colorado into wyoming. "we saw an impact just after the medical-marijuana legalization in colorado in the number of stoned drivers on (wyoming) highway 287," o’malley said to the newspaper. under colorado's marijuana law, it's illegal to transport marijuana outside of state lines and drive while under the influence. "we had more people in possession as well as people using while they’re driving. this state is not excited about legal weed yes, a lot of people are excited about colorado's new legal recreational marijuana laws. but don't count the wyoming highway patrol among them. so we’ve had an upswing in that regard."

my point is that the very voters and media personalities who would almost certainly condemn donell have embraced donald, which indicates the degree to which a racial double standard exists at the core of the republican party and conservative media world. if donell trump’s attitude toward the fairer sex could be distilled into a single sentence, it’s what he told esquire in 1991: "it really doesn’t matter what [the media] write about you as long as you’ve got a young and beautiful piece of ass." presented with such a presidential candidate — one who seemingly went out of his way to personify every negative stereotype our society holds about black male sexuality, avarice and propensity to violence — how would the republican party base and conservative entertainment industry respond? some conservatives may respond to this thought exercise by claiming that, actually, republican voters would enthusiastically welcome a black candidate, a donell trump — so long as he, too, championed nationalist, politically incorrect, anti-immigrant populism. he routinely nudges attendees at his rallies to beat up protestors, has boasted that he could shoot someone on manhattan’s 5th avenue to prove his voters’ loyalty to him, and has dropped hints that his supporters should kill his opponent. f t in a sense, we already know how this segment of the right would respond to such a hypothetical black politician, given the way they've treated president obama. meanwhile, many of the same people who claim with a straight face that the plagiarizing former nude model melania trump would make an ideal first lady slam michelle obama’s innocuous healthy-eating initiative as nothing less than a maoist reeducation scheme. over decades in the media spotlight, he has insulted a slew of women by calling them, among many other slurs, "fat," "ugly" and "pigs"; he told one female journalist she had "the face of a dog." moreover, so much of donald trump’s popularity is based on unsubtle appeals to white nationalism that — despite the thought exercise above — it’s impossible to imagine a true black analogue. trump’s hesitance to condemn david duke, his "law and order" mantra evocative of richard nixon’s southern strategy, and his conspiracy theories about the president’s birth certificate are all intended to whip up white racial resentment. an intellectual, ivy league-educated, cool-tempered family man, obama has nevertheless been portrayed by much of the right-wing media as nothing short of the anti-christ, a crypto-muslim manchurian candidate secretly plotting to destroy america. which brings us to the crux of the matter: whether the subject is poverty, police brutality or affirmative action, conservatives are loath to acknowledge the presence of racism in american society. a racial double standard exists at the core of the republican party and conservative media world. last summer, a black real estate developer and reality television show host — let’s call him donell trump — announced his candidacy for president of the united states. donell trump also displays rank ignorance about every single political issue he’s asked about, speaks at a fifth-grade reading level, and has trouble forming grammatically correct sentences. once the proprietor of a global beauty pageant, whose contestants he routinely demeaned, donell trump is obsessed with boasting about his sexual prowess. yet it’s far from hidden; it courses through the presidential campaign, as the notion of a donell trump candidacy clearly shows. the values donell trump exemplifies — pride, greed, envy, a literal catalog of the seven deadly sins — are ones we ought to recoil from when choosing a president. but the closest the gop ever had to a black trump, 2012 contender herman cain, fizzled out as soon as sexual harassment allegations against him became public. or would they lament how this habitual homewrecker and "baby daddy" to three separate women symbolized the epidemic of african american absentee fatherhood? would rush limbaugh insist that donell trump’s half-literate tirades were the heartfelt pleas of a down-to-earth, blue-collar billionaire? replace the outer-borough white ethnic vulgarity with african american ghetto vernacular and they’d call the man a "thug." donell trump constantly exaggerates his personal net worth, and his larger-than-life existence — shiny watches, fast cars, big yachts, massive cribs — resembles that of a rap star. granted, if conservatives rejected donell trump as unfit for office, they wouldn’t be in the wrong. a substantial part of his fortune was made through shady business ventures that took advantage of working-class people, but donell trump has no apologies. he joked about the size of his anatomy during a live televised debate and riffed about dating his adult daughter. if donald trump were black, would the gop base accept him? would bill o’reilly and jerry falwell jr. praise donell trump as a model american businessman and moral leader? or instead treat his listeners to a rant about the inanities of ebonics? "if you didn’t come in from the campaign, it was a tough circle to break into," anita dunn, who served as white house communications director until november 2009, told the washington post. this forced the men in the room to recognize the contribution — and denied them the chance to claim the idea as their own. as the post points out, things have gotten much better for female staffers in obama’s second term. obama noticed, she and others said, and began calling more often on women and junior aides. there’s an even gender split among his top aides, and half of all white house departments are headed by women. how beats tricks you into thinking it makes a premium product the sneaky designers at beats by dre employ a clever trick to make you think that the company’s plastic headphones are durable products worth the premium price. the crazy part is that the headphones are so cheap that beats actually needs to add weight to make them feel heftier. in these headphones, 30% of the weight comes from four tiny metal parts that are there for the sole purpose of adding weight. one way to do this cheaply is to make some components out of metal in order to add weight. obviously, product designers use all sorts of aesthetic design cues to make things look fancier than they really are, but in this case, it’s downright deceptive. from the medium post: one of the great things about the solo headphones is how substantial they feel. on the right, four pieces of metal designed specifically to add weight to the product. amazingly, for all the company’s claims about precision sound design, the headphones use freaking off-the-shelf drivers! here is an image illustrating this point: on the left, all of the components that actually do something. a detailed teardown (via popmech) of a pair of beats’ immensely popular solo headphones conducted by hardware-focused venture capital firm bolt has some answers buried beneath. a little bit of weight makes the product feel solid, durable, and valuable. the cans are so dainty, beats felt the need to beef em up a little. the company cuts corners everywhere it can; gluing pieces together instead of using screws, and reducing the amount of tooling wherever possible. none of this is all that surprising because beats are, after all, terrible and fragile. sponsored i was not aware of this particular trick. it’s practically a perfect business: take crap and sell it for a fortune. i was not aware of this particular trick. in part it’s marketing, and you know, dr. dre. and yet they sell millions of pairs of headphones. how do they do it? beats by dre headphones are garbage. besides their crappy sound, they’re basically designed to break. the headphones are incredibly cheaply made. image courtesy of bolt. but there’s more. mostly though, it’s amusing.

suggest that the fear of death is one of several interrelated psychological concepts that could help explain why trump has been so successful, including authoritarianism, an aversion to uncertainty and racial prejudice. reminding the american people that they are going to die. solomon is part of a group of researchers that has spent decades investigating the connections between death and a broad variety of human what the participants were thinking about. he and his colleagues have argued that the same is true of clothing and grooming, and that humans conceal their nature as animals from themselves to avoid thinking about their mortality. their inspiration has been the work of ernest becker, an anthropologist who argued that the fear of death was a kind of fundamental principle in explaining human psychology. becker won a pulitzer prize for his 1973 book " the denial of death ," but he was shunned in the academic community for what his peers saw as a lack of rigor. their research is still preliminary and controversial, and they haven’t worked out a complete theory, but they have discovered a number of startling facts about how people think about death. the other two groups were asked bible made thoughts of death also more accessible to fundamentalist christians. a different group of researchers found that after a group of canadians read an article in which canadian cultural tropes were mocked, they were thinking about death, too. image of a telemarketing call center via mike vargas, 44-year-old from washington dc served 14 years for a drug conspiracy released from custody in 2009 it wasn't hard getting a job when i came home, it just wasn't a good job. you work super hard to pull one of the slimy things out, and then you have to scoop the little thing up and take off before the cow attacks you for holding its calf. image of cattle ranchers via wikimedia creative commons mendoor smith, 43-year-old from iowa served 12 years for marijuana possession released from custody in 2013 the worst job i had was working on a cattle ranch as a utility farmer, making $8.25 an hour. other prisoners are so shell-shocked from being back in a society that changed dramatically while they were locked up, that figuring out how to do basic things like use public transportation or a cell phone can feel like a herculean task. the fact that over 75 percent of ex-cons are rearrested within five years of releas e should be no surprise when the only jobs offered to people with criminal records are the gigs no one else applies for. i've had four jobs since i've been out, and i never told anyone i was on parole until after i was hired, or they wouldn't have hired me. after serving 23 years in the feds, the first job i got on the outside was as a sauté cook at an italian restaurant, despite my earning two college degrees while in prison. david hibdon, 55-year-old from missouri served 10 years for drug conspiracy released from custody in 2014 my first job out of prison was the worst job available in colombia, missouri. i dreaded that job, but as i've talked with other ex-cons over the years about their first gigs on the outside, i now consider myself lucky. ex-cons remember their worst jobs after being released from prison getting a job when you first get out of prison can be a nightmare . i had to be there from about 6 am to 5 pm every day, and the commute was 45 minutes from the halfway house i was placed in. you had to be there talking to people on the phone all day, cold calling, trying to collect donations for different organizations around the state and country. after about an hour and a half of lifting and stuffing this slimy, nasty thing, the vet finally got it all back inside and sewed up. but most ex-cons needed the job to get out of the halfway house, so they just kept working there until something better came along. but even when ex-cons do manage to get hired, the work is underpaid, demoralizing, and their employers don't do much to encourage the re-entry process. that job sucked, but i was still glad to have it because i wouldn't be in the position i'm in today otherwise. i had to be there at seven in the morning and got off at 4 pm, with only a short lunch break in between. i remember calving one shift during the winter, and when i did my hourly inspection of the herd, i noticed a cow with an extremely bad vaginal prolapse. the work sucked, and i was forced to do the grunt work no one else would do, like clean out the fryers every night. i started working the same week i was released at this telemarketing place that hired ex-cons at $7.25 an hour. i had to lift the cow's vaginal insides and hold them while the vet tried to stuff them back inside the cow. and all the other ex-cons that worked there would sleep on a nearby hill or smoke k2 all day while i was working. most employers refuse to hire someone fresh out the feds or convicts who are still incarcerated but allowed to get a job through "work-release." it wasn't really tough work, but the handling of manure and animals was rough, as was taking care of the calves and cows. they asked a lot of questions, stuff about what was prison like and what i did to get all that time. i was making about 50 bucks a day, but i was required to give 25 percent to the halfway house. with my first paycheck, i bought a bike and then it only took me forty minutes to get to work. i called my boss and he called the vet who came out at four in the morning. it served its purpose because if you don't have a gig you have to stay at the halfway. often times, it's a requirement by the criminal justice system, or else freshly-released inmates will risk being sent back to the feds. vice chatted with three ex-cons to get more perspective on what re-entering the workforce was like once they got out of prison. the halfway house didn't provide transportation to the job, and i had to walk there every morning. i wasn't in any position to argue and risk being canned, and my employers took advantage of this. one dude even jumped up, picked up a computer, and slammed it down because he couldn't get anybody to donate. according to the national institute of justice , over 60 percent of ex-cons are jobless up to a year after release. i had to walk around 27 acres and pick up the trash that blew off the trucks, rain or shine. it was cool at first, but after a while i was starting to feel like a robot. he was a big help and was instrumental in me getting the job i have now. when i did my final inspection of the morning at 10 am, the cow had died. i was picking up trash at the city dump in 100-plus degree weather for $8 an hour. there are organizers that help former prisoners assimilate into the workforce, but the support is generally few and far between. i worked with mostly young people, and there were also a bunch of ex-cons working there. nobody wanted the job because of the stink and the dust blowing on you from the trash trucks. you had a total of 16 minutes of break time for a full eight hour shift. it was one of the most degrading experiences i ever went through, but i got past it. i could go back to the dump if i wanted, but that job sucked. it sure didn't help me become a better person cause i was still the same after. having to stick my entire arm in a cow to help pull out a calf was not fun either. no one else would take these jobs besides ex-cons at the halfway house. i've done a lot of different things, but that was the worst. that said, getting a job is a necessary step for prisoners to integrate back into society. it's easier and the pay is better, but i am always looking for something better. it took me two months in the halfway house to save up and buy a $500 car. he helped me get my class a driver's license so i could drive trucks for him. there was a lot of favoritism, and also a big turnover within staff, of course. if you went to get a coke, you had to clock out. anybody could have got hired at this place, but the conditions were terrible. the farm was a tight-knit family, so i was treated well, but the work was completely horrible. i worked there because it was the only job available. i've had like seven or eight jobs since then. i'm a machinist now, and i assemble parts all day at a machine. if you went to the bathroom, you had to clock out. it was a seven mile walk that took over two hours. dealing with cows everyday is messy, and i'd have to clean out their living pens. i quit that job when i had something better lined up. i eventually started my own business, subcontracting myself out to do maintenance on rental properties. if you didn't kiss ass, you were an outsider. it prepared me for the struggle of rebuilding my life after prison, though. some days i walked through raw sewage, or mud up to my ankles. it didn't kill me and it made me stronger. i had two coworkers that knew about my [criminal] situation. having a 1,200 pound animal chase you is a little intimidating. if i bought a soda or cigarettes i was almost broke. my boss was a good boss. dudes would curse out the boss. all that work was for nothing. i was alienated out there. he walked out shortly after.
verizon and at&amp;t don't like this internet ruling, but your pocketbook will verizon and at&t don't like this internet ruling, but your pocketbook will a seemingly obscure legal decision was reached this week, but it affects our use and enjoyment of the internet, and ensures that we won't be charged more for it. it was a way for these companies with with limited competition to generate more revenue, but it would also mean that the bigger companies that could pay more for faster service would receive preferential treatment for their content, compared to smaller startup companies that could not afford to pay. they've wanted to offer different classes of internet services, one that provides faster speeds and better access to those websites that pay, and a slower access speed for those that don't want to pay. net neutrality means that the internet service providers or broadband carriers treat all data that travels over their networks in exactly the same way, much like our telephone service and power are regulated. three years ago when these rules were being formulated by the fcc, a groundswell of users spoke up in support of net neutrality, more than any other regulation in recent history. but for many years, there has been an effort to change all this, led by the broadband carriers comcast, verizon, and at&t. it’s the way the internet has worked since its inception and we know how the internet has transformed our lives in nearly everything we do. they want companies to compete by being able to attract customers based on their products and services, not on speed of access. when comedian john oliver explained on hbo’s "last week tonight" what was being proposed that might compromise net neutrality, it generated 45,000 responses to the agency in just a few minutes. it’s also spawned innovation and many new companies to create products and services we never imagined. next page: how the citizens beat the lobbyists, and what this decision means for you. the internet association , the organization representing nearly 40 tech companies, including those above, also filed a formal petition in opposition. four million citizens emailed and called the fcc objecting to any changes away from net neutrality. the decision upheld the federal communications commission's (fcc) regulation that supports net neutrality. opposition also came from the major technology companies such as amazon, google, facebook, and netflix.

we've finally figured out when the moon formed the cataclysmic collision between earth and a mars-size object that forged the moon may have occurred about 4.47 billion years ago, suggests a study of meteorites with ancient fragments from that cosmic impact. if future research can uncover examples of this impact in asteroid samples, "possibly by getting them from an asteroid sample return mission like osiris-rex, we would have one of the key pieces of the puzzle explaining why our world is the way it is, and what has changed since its infancy," bottke said. this finding suggests that, one day, it may be possible to find samples of what the primordial earth was like before the giant impact that formed the moon, or to uncover bits of the impacting rock itself. the simulations found that numerous fragments from the moon-forming impact — hundreds of millions of which were at least a mile (1.6 kilometers) long — blasted the asteroid belt, striking asteroids there at speeds of more than 22,370 mph (36,000 km/h), more than twice as fast as typical crashes in the belt. "we can now use asteroids, for the first time, to tell us about many of the major events that took place in the inner solar system during the planet-formation era," bottke said. "to understand the formation and evolution of our world as well as those in the inner solar system, we need to understand the timing of major events during the planet-formation era," bottke said. this research "raises the intriguing possibility that trace amounts of the primordial earth or moon-forming impactor called theia may still be found on asteroids today, or possibly within some of our meteorites," bottke said. [how earth's moon was made (a photo timeline)] "by understanding the moon, we can tell the story of the early bombardment of earth," study lead author william bottke, a planetary scientist at the southwest research institute in boulder, colorado, told space.com. finding these materials would be one of the holy grails of geology — we have no rocks older than 4 billion years old on earth, and no one knows the exact nature of the original building blocks of our planet." they found that the impact not only created a disk of debris near earth that formed the moon, but it also ejected huge amounts of rubble — as much as several percent of earth's mass — away from earth and the moon. collisions against these asteroids in more recent times returned these remnants to earth in stony meteorites, which the scientists now have analyzed and used to date the age of the impact. "investigators can learn about the explosive device and the explosion itself by studying what happened to people, infrastructure, and whether trace amounts of the explosive device can be found among the blast damage. the leading explanation for the moon's origin, known as the giant impact hypothesis, suggests that the moon resulted from the collision of two protoplanets, or embryonic worlds. the ages of the most ancient lunar samples the apollo astronauts brought back are still debated, since these samples have typically been battered and heated by subsequent cosmic impacts. "in a sense, the asteroid belt has been an eyewitness to multiple 'drive-by shootings' from the earliest time in solar system history," bottke said. "by reading the traces left behind, we can use asteroid samples to tell us who did it, when they did it and how they did it." the researchers deduced that the moon-forming impact occurred about 4.47 billion years ago, in agreement with many previous estimates. one of those was the young earth, and the other was a potentially mars-size object called theia. "in an explosion, there is often collateral damage, where nearby buildings and innocent bystanders are affected," bottke said. these collisions from the moon-forming impact would have generated superheated material, the researchers said. to find out more about this giant impact, scientists developed a computer model of the event. earth was born about 4.5 billion years ago, and scientists think the moon formed shortly afterward. "this gives us a new window on a time period which has been virtually unknown up to now." however, the precise timeline of this giant impact event is under dispute. "it may be simply a matter of looking and asking the right questions. the scientists detailed their findings in the april 17 issue of the journal science. here, the 'innocent bystanders' were the main-belt asteroids." the moon then coalesced from the rubble.
anyone over the age of 18 caught with 10 grams or less of the drug will no longer have to make a court appearance and will not have offenses entered into their permanent record; instead, violators will have to pay a fine of 100 swiss francs (approximately $110), then be on their way. a 2013 unicef report found swiss children are the world's second-most likely to smoke marijuana, with just over 24 percent of 11, 13 and 15-year-olds having smoked pot in the last year. for perspective, canada leads the world in kids' marijuana use, with 28 percent of its children aged 11, 13, and 15 admitting to smoking pot in the past 12 months. per the independent, the measure is also expected to save money by cutting back on the 30,000 marijuana-related cases courts have had to handle each year. penalties are now stricter for anyone caught selling to a person under the age of 18. another country decriminalizes marijuana as of oct. 1, possession of marijuana is decriminalized in switzerland. lawmakers in the country relaxed weed regulations in an effort to unify what had been a patchwork of often confusing policies that varied from one local area to another. but "decriminalized" is not the same as "legal," as a swiss broadcasting corporation report makes clear. the new law also provides greater resources to help children with marijuana habits. growing marijuana plants, imbibing the drug in any form and dealing it are still forbidden. it will also free up police resources to pursue larger drug trafficking incidents.
the only option is to buy whole big organic carrots and carve your own baby carrots.or just give up on baby carrots entirely! i well remember eating them back then, but what i never knew is that baby carrots aren’t small carrots. carrots destined to be baby carrots are often not properly irrigated so they take on a white blush which is not attractive. chlorine gets rid of this and makes the baby carrots look pretty again. baby carrots, so cute, little mini carrots that haven’t grown up yet. they could make you very ill. baby carrots are not good for you. other machines peel them, cut them and reshape them into little mini carrots. i can’t believe i never knew this, but why would i. the carrots are also bleached to make them look more bright and attractive. perfect for a healthy snack and a great size for little toddler fingers to hold on to. these days baby carrot production is pretty much automated, machines pull up 75 tons of carrots in an hour. no, baby carrots are big carrots that have been cut down and reshaped! well the manufacturing process is quite unclean so the chlorine gets rid bacteria. it can make you sneeze, give you excess saliva and make you restless. baby carrots – their history back in the 80s baby carrots became popular. a carrot you would think, would be a carrot, especially when its carrot shaped. long term consumption of baby carrots can lead to a weakened immune system and even liver malfunction! nope, even organic baby carrots are soaked in chlorine. it’s also very bad for the environment. they are soaked in a bath of chlorine. you should stop eating baby carrots for this disturbing reason! so why do they put them in chlorine? it can make your eyes run and your nose and throat irritated. they are very bad for you! the next step in the process is the most worrying one. chlorine is pretty bad for you. the opposite is the truth of the matter. their cute looks are a deception. so what’s the option. don’t fall for it. buy organic? stop!
john gruber, a well-regarded apple observer, thinks it's a clever marketing move for apple's second-tier phone: it’s just that instead of putting the year-old iphone 5 in slot #2, they’ve created the 5c to debut in that slot. same a6, same camera, same just about everything — except for the most obvious difference, its array of colorful plastic shells ... what changes with the 5c is that the middle tier is suddenly more appealing, and has a brand of its own that apple can promote apart from the flagship 5s. since 2010, apple's media blitz for its new iphone has gone like this: on a friday following the big unveil event, people can begin preordering the new phone, the verge points out. if you want it the first day it's on sale, you have to wait in line -- creating yet another organic marketing tool for apple. the iphone 5c number apple doesn't want you to know on monday, apple managed to make a bit of news by not announcing any. for the first time, the iphone maker didn't reveal how many preorders were made on its new line of smartphones. here's a new one released on monday: for now, apple will keep plugging away at the 5c. with investors interpreting apple's silence as weak initial 5c sales, apple's stock slid to $450 on monday from friday's close of $465. the silence on orders for the iphone 5c -- a week after it was announced -- has investors down on the tech giant. the company's top-line phone, with the new features like the fingerprint reader and desktop-like performance, should be the one with higher sales. as many others have pointed out, the iphone 5c is essentially a rebranded iphone 5 with nearly all the same specs. for one, apple's top-line phone, the iphone 5s, can't be preordered. by the time the iphone 5 was released two years later, that preorder figure was 2 million. but this year, apple was mum about preorder numbers several days after iphone 5c preorders went live. with android-run smartphones made by samsung and google cutting into apple's market share, many see the global appetite for apple smartphones waning. but preorder numbers for iphone 5c, even if they are low, may not be the best indication. by creating the perception of scarcity, apple's tactic worked to get some consumers off the fence about buying a new iphone. a few days later, apple trumpets the high number of new iphones the public wants. here's a new one released on monday: for now, apple will keep plugging away at the 5c. but circumstances may be a bit different this year. the 5c is, effectively, an iphone 5. in 2010, more than 600,000 iphone 4s were preordered in 24 hours. this didn't go unnoticed by wall street.
knowing her daughter’s love for dancing and playing, she decided to take some of her old pennies and glue them to the bottom of her daughter’s play shoes, and the results were amazing. however, just because they may be as good as obsolete in a monetary sense, there are still a lot of things that pennies can be used for with the help of a little creativity. the reason for this is not only that pennies are the lowest denomination, but that people don’t want to use pennies anymore. it actually costs more for the united states to produce a new penny than a penny is worth, meaning they are literal black holes of value. creative mothers like this one will always find a way to bring a little extra joy to their children with whatever means they have at their disposal. these repositories are nice to collect our coins in one place, but more often than not, pennies tend to dominate the bulk of the volume. you might think the sound would be overwhelming, but it was actually quite pleasant to both her and her daughter. the shoes were transformed into make-shift tap shoes, giving her daughter an extra level of excitement during her play time. i thought it was weird she glued pennies to her daughter’s shoes, but when i found out why? it wasn’t too different from the sound of actual tap shoes. a lot of people have large change jars somewhere in their home. that’s exactly what one mom did with her spare pennies. more parents should take a cue from this nurturing woman. genius!

"we are a small island nation at the bottom of the world with lots of resources and opportunities and we need to maximise that, and some of the way we can do that is bringing in investors," he said. us surge according to immigration new zealand, in november 2016 when the us presidential election was held, 17,584 people registered their interest to study, work or invest in the country, compared with 1,272 in november 2015. the revelation that mr thiel had quietly become a new zealand citizen has raised some questions about the processes for foreign investors, with some politicians asking how, exactly, he was able to secure it and whether he was given special treatment. mr thiel, who previously said new zealand was a "utopia" and has invested heavily there, is just one of several us migrants who have realised what the country has to offer. "what we are experiencing at the moment is a slight increase in visas issued to american nationals, both temporary work visas and permanent resident visas," steve mcgill, general manager at immigration new zealand, told the bbc. "we've definitely had an increase in american inquiries, and at least one sale that has been a direct run-off from the presidential result in the united states," says nick horton, an agent specialising in luxury real estate. "they are from all over the united states and are educated, looking to either work in new zealand or invest if they have a considerable amount of capital behind them." but mr mcgill said opposition to wealthy investors, who can secure a residency visa by spending a minimum amount in the country, was not a major issue. "the same happened after the global financial crisis, and the same thing happened after obama was elected, when some people thought the united states wouldn't tolerate having a black leader." between october and december last year, 348 residency visas were granted to people from the united states, compared with 338 in the same period in 2015. the temperate, mountainous country is also comparably well-placed to deal with rising sea levels, and its most recent major attack was in 1985, when french spies blew up a greenpeace vessel in auckland harbour.
