six of roald dahl's made-up words have been added to the oxford english dictionary to celebrate his centenary roald dahl is remembered for his solitary, kind-hearted child heroes—charlie, who visited a chocolate factory, and sophie, who befriended a floppy-eared giant, among them—and their triumphs over bullying adults. witching hour referred to in the bfg as "a special moment in the middle of the night when every child and every grown-up was in a deep deep sleep, and all the dark things came out from hiding and had the world to themselves." although the word was first found in the american thesaurus of slang in 1942, dahl’s giant’s use of it planted it firmly in the minds of every child who read the bfg: "every human bean is diddly and different. to honor the centenary of his birth this month, the oxford english dictionary has updated its latest edition today (sept. 12) with six new words connected to dahl’s writing, and revisions to six other phrases popularized by dahl’s evocative stories. human bean this is a mispronunciation of "human being," uttered by the giant in the bfg (1982): "we is having an interesting babblement about the taste of the human bean. the first instance of the phrase is over a century older, having been used in an issue of the british satirical magazine punch in 1842. but the beloved british children’s book author was also known for the distinctive language he used to create the vivid, often dark, worlds in which the characters lived. in may, the oxford university press also published a roald dahl dictionary complete with 8,000 words coined or popularized by the author. oompa loompa the diminutive factory workers who played music and danced in charlie and the chocolate factory were made more famous by the 1971 film adaption of the book, starring gene wilder. new entries dahlesque the characteristics of dahl’s work—in the oed’s words, "eccentric plots, villainous or loathsome adult characters, and gruesome or black humour"—now have their own adjective. golden ticket these refer to the tickets hidden in chocolate bars that granted access to willy wonka’s chocolate factory in charlie and the chocolate factory (1964). the first golden ticket, however, was awarded to 18th century painter william hogarth, giving him admission to the vauxhall gardens in london, in recognition of his paintings of the venue. here are the new dahlisms added to the oed, and the revised phrases, with notes on their origins. dahl also played with sound ("sizzle-pan" to refer to a frying pan in the bfg, for example). dahl invented words based on old words, rhymes, malapropisms, and spoonerisms (swapping the first letters of words around, such as "catasterous disastrophe" from the bfg). "he was using very linguistic principles," says vineeta gupta, head of children’s dictionaries at oxford university press. we can thank shakespeare for this evocative phrase: according to the oed, "witching time" first appeared in hamlet (1604). gupta called the phrase "typical dahlesque," reflecting how the author played with sound to convey meaning. the term was first used in 1983 by the literary magazine books ireland. there was linguistic method to dahl’s mad use of language. the human bean is not a vegetable." some is scrumdiddlyumptious and some is uckyslush." scrumdiddlyumptious "extremely scrumptious excellent, splendid (esp. of food) delicious."
police records show that maria corral and suspect juan alberto contreras-rodriguez were arrested in a 2012 marijuana trafficking bust in which authorities seized 500 pounds of pot, the atlanta journal-constitution reports. startling link between kidnapped teen's mom and suspect authorities in georgia have revealed a new link between a kidnapped teen's mother and one suspect in her daughter's abduction. on wednesday, corral's daughter, 14-year-old ayvani hope perez, was found alive one day after being taken at gunpoint from her suburban atlanta home during a robbery. corral may have just been in the "wrong place at the wrong time," michael katz, the lawyer who represented her, told the journal-constitution. officials said that perez was in good health following a medical evaluation wednesday afternoon, according to nbc news. the charges against contreras-ramirez were dropped after aspects of the search were deemed unconstitutional. police have since arrested contreras-rodriguez, 40, and another man, wildrego jackson, 29. corral was never indicted on charges related to the drug incident. two additional suspects in the investigation remain at large, police say. more arrests are expected.
so when george papageorgiou, the owner of esti olive oil, asked me if i wanted to go to kalamata to see how they harvest the olives and turn them into olive oil, i jumped at the chance. i can't help but think that everyone, even the french, might fall in love with olive oil if they had a chance to taste the greek rendition. before there were rules for the amount of liquid you could carrying on a plane, my mother and i would bring half-gallon containers of olive oil back from our trips to greece. the most unexpected country that rocks at making olive oil even though the peloponnese is only an hour's drive away from athens, it's as if you're entering another world, or at least another country. before leaving the facility that day, george sent me home with a box filled with bottles of olive oil: virgin, extra virgin, organic extra virgin. with malaxation the slow churning action allows the small droplets of oil that were released in the milling process to aggregate, forming large droplets of oil which facilitates mechanical extraction. i say this with objectivity as a chef, and would like to think that this overrides any bias that my greek heritage holds. concrete boxes are replaced with olive groves, and the words "traffic jam" tend to mean that a group of goats have convened, gathering and blocking the road. as my hands turned a reddish-brown, i reminisced about the days i used to spend as a child, collecting olives with my yiayia. in greece it is said that the best of greek olive oils come from the peloponnese. as we headed into the olive grove, numerous fine mesh nets were being laid down to gather and catch all the olives. the storage of the olive oil in steel tanks helps to preserve it and keep it from oxidizing. we took the gathered olives back to the production plant where george had them ground into paste using large millstones. i know others might disagree with me, but i will take a good quality olive oil over butter any day! like goldilocks searching amongst the belongings of the three bears, george is in constant search for the olives that are "just right." i had always assumed that the grading of "extra virgin" denoted a different process or different stage in the olive's ripeness. i asked george if the oil we had witnessed being made was virgin or extra virgin. i was going to the peloponnese and getting a chance to enjoy some "liquid gold." if the olives are too black, the quality of the olive oil will be lost. the final room we visited that day was lined with shiny steel tanks, much like a winery. the grove of mature olive trees look as if they belong in greek mythology. with the booming introduction of greek yogurt into the u.s., i'm hoping that greek olive oil will soon follow suit. i looked around the manufacturing facility, much like a child the first time they visit disneyland. it's the final resting place for the olive oil before it is bottled. the differentiation of "extra virgin" is the virgin olive oil that satisfies specific high chemical and organoleptic criteria. in greek, the word theoxenia comes from mythology and relates to hospitality; how hosts treat guests or even strangers. in layman's terms it is the virgin olive oil that has low free acidity and no quality defects. the olives must be harvested at a specific time during the ripening process. if the olives are too green the olive oil produced will taste bitter. for years i have wished that greeks would be more like the italians. the italians do a fantastic job of exporting and promoting their products to other countries. needless to say, i greatly enjoy the small villages of the peloponnese. the lower hanging branches were gently being shaken, taking care not to wound the trees. in fact, all olive oil produced by physical (mechanical) means is virgin. the esti olive grove in kalamata is located in a beautiful sunlit valley. that night, and many nights since, i have enjoyed his olive oils. in each bite i can taste the olive grove and its bright sun-kissed fruit. "this," he explained "is the traditional method used for making olive oil." after grinding, the paste then gets slowly stirred in a separate container for 20 to 40 minutes. i use it to fry fish and as an ingredient in cakes. to me this was kind of like winning the lottery. the best olive oils come from greece. george papageorgiou is trying to make that happen. being greek, i grew up eating olive oil. i began to collect olives in my little basket. i was a bit overwhelmed during the whole process. i love using it to make popcorn. this is a process known as malaxation. i drizzle it on fresh tomatoes and slices of bread. i wanted to see what was behind every door. it's an important part of greek culture. this was something george clearly keeps in mind. it's a constant balancing act. workers set up ladders to reach the tall branches. george shook his head. this was not correct. i snapped pictures.

sunday morning: out to brunch la dolce vita (13), at chaksibhari marg (00 977 1 4700612, no web), doesn’t have the best coffee in kathmandu, but what it lacks in a caffeine fix it makes up for with delicious italian pastries, pasta and gnocchi, sprinkled with grated yak’s cheese. take a hike nowhere is the localised nature of the earthquake damage more apparent that in the area known as durbar square, a riot of ancient palaces, temples and royal monuments which comprise the unesco-listed historic heart of kathmandu. something of a thamel institution – everyone from jeremy irons to ricky martin have stayed here – the kathmandu guest house (19) is a bit rough round the edges these days, but still a good mid-range choice – it’s located in a former palace. take a view puff your way up the 400-step stone staircase to the buddhist stupa of swayambhunath (1), known as ‘monkey temple’ on account of the hundreds of ‘holy’ monkeys who will be your chattering, food-begging companions. an aperitif owner prakash will probably be around to welcome you in person to zibro (11) on chaksibari marg (00 977 984 1059449, no web), his laid-back rooftop bar where young nepalis shoot the breeze with holidaying indians and european travellers. why 2017 is the year to visit kathmandu with the two year anniversary of the nepal earthquake approaching, the capital is back on its feet. rebuilding and restoration is proceeding apace while tourists are returning to bathe in the himalayan city’s sensory overload: temples and squares; prayer flags and sputtering scooters; merchants yelling behind marigold-garlanded stalls amid wafts of incense, spices and holy cow dung. lunch on the run climb six flights of stairs to the rooftop kasthamandap café (9) at 23 maru (00 977 1 6219177, no web) for an open-air coffee and snack under a sun umbrella. window shopping the thamel district, north of durbar square, survived the earthquake more or less intact and remains the backpacker hub (a successor to freak street). follow the flow down to jagannath mandir (4), a hindu temple which attracts gawping fascination on account of its athletic and imaginative erotic carvings which seems to suggest that the earth has always moved in these parts. dine with the locals at bhojan griha (12), on dilli bazaar in the eastern district of kathmandu, traditional ‘newari’ dishes are served to guests in a 19th-century mansion, restored with painstaking attention to detail. the icing on the cake treat yourself to a massage by a seeing hands blind masseur whose fingers are attuned to muscle and tissue in ways that the sighted will never match. cultural afternoon the historic buddhist city of patan – effectively a suburb of kathmandu – is a 20-minute taxi ride across the tea-coloured bagmati river. a walk in the park it says a lot that swapna bagaicha (14) on kaiser mahal, tridevi marg, is also known as the garden of dreams. nearly two years after the earthquake which devastated swathes of nepal and severely damaged the capital, kathmandu is bouncing back to its alluring self with astonishing verve. if it’s between 10am and noon, keep an eye out – the kumari devi, or living ‘child-goddess’ might put in an appearance at her window above the courtyard of her magnificently carved sacred home, the kumari dar (5). however, now that you are down at the south end of the historic region, the heartrending extend of the earthquake damage becomes unavoidable. it’s a carnival of noisy alleys and tiny squares, packed with hundreds of trekking agencies and shops hawking everything from tourist tat to genuine tibetan antiques. start at the northern, thamel end check post (2) where tourists pay an entrance fee of 1000rs (about £7.70) fee for free run of the whole area. you will see from here how localised the earthquake damage was; isolated pockets have collapsed like cards while large areas remained more or less unscathed. cordoned off for safety is the red brick old royal palace, (6) whose walls are now cracked, while the adjacent basantapur tower (7) somehow remain precariously erect. every rupee spent in hotels and restaurants, shops, taxis or temples, is helping kathmandu back on to its feet. the façade of the kwa bahal (15), also known as the golden temple, is one almost untouched highlight; the four giant, prayer flag-festooned ashoka stupas (16) are another. nevertheless, the plants are still lovingly tended and the rs 200 (£1.50) entrance fee is being put to good restorative use. to its north, frenetic thamel is a maze of hotels, restaurants, trekking agencies and shops. get your bearings the old city, known as durbar square, lies at the centre of kathmandu. take a ride for the ride of your life, board a small propeller plane for a dawn ‘mountain flight’ along the crest of the himalayas. to the south, the bagmati river borders peaceful patan district with its own durbar square and expatriate communities. a botanical park and serene retreat from the frenetic city, it’s just a few minutes’ walk from central thamel. staying there hotel shangri-la (18) is, as the name suggests, as swanky as kathmandu gets. patan is a repository of temples, palaces and stupas strewn around its own durbar square. hotel horizon (20) is a gem tucked away in an alley near the north end of durbar square. sadly, the park took a hard hit in the earthquake, damaging some of the neo-classical pavilions, statues, ponds and fountains. flights are in the early mornings when conditions are generally clearest, but good views are weather-dependent and weather-related cancellations are frequent. the music is on multi-cultural message too, with songs from little known local bands playing nepali folk-rock fusion in the background. beyond the former royal palace to the east are the smarter shopping centres and embassies. however, taxis are cheap and plentiful and rickshaws can be a useful way of travelling short distances. if the day is clear, the whole of kathmandu valley unfurls at your feet. exit via ‘freak street’ (official name jochne) (8), the legendary 1960s hippy hangout (though its glory days are now over). it’s a great place to commendable organisation which provides employment and independence for nepal’s blind men and women. a range of therapies are offered in a clinical setting, in its premises off jyatha road, thamel (17). getting there qatar airways flies to kathmandu via doha from heathrow, manchester, birmingham and edinburgh, from £685 return. the restaurant says that all produce is organic and no plastic is used. sadly, several of these took hits in the earthquake. and then there’s the fact it’s guarded by scores of ‘holy tortoises’. now's the time to go, says martin symington why go now? you’ll pass up craft (10) on chhetrapait. dishes include buffalo meat or vegetable-filled momo dumplings, and duck with peanuts and spiced lentils. breakfast on sequinned cushions in the courtyard is a treat. join throngs of pilgrims at shiva-dedicated mahendreshwar mandir (3) with its chiming bells and flickering candles. there are commanding views over durbar square. local tempos (minibuses) and buses are as it relates to monetization, we’ve made a handful of changes: we tested adding affiliate tags to e-commerce links, which we ended up turning off we announced promoted user posts and we announced tests we’ll be running on sponsored headlines. these changes and experiments will continue to happen, but while it is critical that we build reddit into a sustainable business, we don’t want to compromise what’s brought us here. you can see what experiments we are running on this live thread, and notable changes to the site are listed in r/changelog. as we evolve our ads platform, we are working to do it in a way that that complements the core experience and engages redditors. mobile web (m.reddit.com) is undergoing a major overhaul that we’re testing internally, and hope to start showing to users in the next couple weeks. we have been running many experiments on desktop web to increase user engagement, particularly for users who are new to reddit. the mandate of these teams is to eliminate spam and abuse and to ensure reddit is a welcoming place for all. i would like to share some of the things we have been up to since we last chatted. changes and additions to ads can be met with skepticism, and this is why we test changes carefully and listen to feedback. the current moderator mail system is a hack on top of our messaging system, which is itself a hack on top of our commenting system. there are a number of problems we’d like to solve: increased velocity, improved personalization, reduced dependence on /new, and not requiring us to choose the defaults. going forward, we will list these in r/changelog so all these kinds of announcements are in one place. we’re still in the early days, but i’m happy we’re dedicating resources to it. the new tool should save a lot of time for everyone, and new tech stack will allow for better future iterations and builds. click to hear about some of the things that have been keeping us busy. this has been a long time coming, and we’re excited to show it off. we’ll be working with moderators to refine it while we work towards a full rollout. we’ve also reduced our support ticket backlog substantially, dropping our average response time from 64 hours to 7 in the process. in the last quarter, we’ve reduced harassment reports by 15%, spam reports by 66%, and moderator spam removals by 15%. the current algorithm is outdated and is no longer meeting our needs. both our iphone and android apps have had multiple releases, and we’re proud at how well they are progressing. we’ve started development on a new frontpage algorithm. we’ve seen great results from our anti-evil, trust & safety, and community teams. yesterday, we previewed new moderator mail to moderators. on the product side, we’ve been busy. happy to chat about this stuff, or anything else. #2 will blow your mind.

also go without legal weed, but not because of a lack of interest; rather due to a lack of staples. the united states government took a historic step back from its long-running drug war last week, when attorney general eric holder informed the governors of washington and colorado that the department of justice would allow the states to create a regime that would regulate and implement the ballot initiatives that legalized the use of marijuana for adults. unfortunately for klob and for the citizens supporting the measure, the petition effort failed because klob inadvertently violated colorado law when he didn't staple each petition volunteer's affidavit with the signatures they collected when he turned the documents in to the la junta city clerk's office. krdo first reported about local marijuana advocate tim klob's petition where he helped gather nearly 600 signatures to put a measure on the november ballot to allow recreational marijuana sales and industrial hemp grows in the southeastern colorado town of la junta. a64 states that adults can possess up to an ounce of pot, can grow as many as six marijuana plants at home (with only three flowering at any given time), but that home-grown marijuana can only be for personal use and cannot be sold, however, adults can gift one another up to an ounce of pot. this week, grand junction became the latest major colorado city to ban retail sales of recreational marijuana by its city council members, even though several citizens requested that the issue be put to a public vote. colorado springs, the state's second largest city, voted to ban recreational pot shops last july and became the largest community in the state to opt-out of the state's new marijuana laws. john hickenlooper signed several historic measures to implement marijuana legalization in the state, establishing colorado as the world's first legal, regulated and taxed marijuana market for adults back in may. a64 allows adults to possess up to an ounce of marijuana for recreational use even in those cities or counties that have banned retail sales. in the state's capital city of denver, which opted in on retail sales of marijuana, a two-year moratorium on new pot business licenses was recommended by the city council. colorado voters passed amendment 64 last november making the limited sale, possession and growing of marijuana for recreational purposes legal for adults 21 and over. recreational pot sales in colorado cities that opt-in can begin on jan. 1, 2014. colorado's 271 municipalities and 64 counties must decide by oct. 1 as to whether they will allow for legal recreational marijuana sales. though all necessary materials were included in the documents, the lack of staples voided the petition through a technicality. klob and la junta are now back to square one. catastrophic invasion of iraq. one survey of 18- to 34-year-olds recorded dire numbers for trump, but still found only 31% supporting clinton, with 29% preferring libertarian gary johnson and 15% the neuralgic of all, florida. she may not be the candidate of your dreams, but she’s all that stands between you and an american nightmare. in that year, a small but significant bloc on the left voted image: christie's auction house downplaying the iphone 7 so the next iphone can thrive maybe i'm reading too much into the tea leaves, but it strikes me that apple could be deliberately cutting the headphone jack this year — a year that is already going to be less exciting by virtue of no major redesign — in order to protect the next iphone from the inevitable backlash over the headphone jack's removal. and that's why, the more i think about it, the more i feel like the iphone 7 has to be a little bit boring so that we can get really hyped about the next big iphone, and it needs to drop the headphone jack now, so the 10th anniversary iphone doesn't carry that particular scarlet letter. i'm not completely sure how i feel about apple potentially shifting the design upgrade from every two years to every three — new colors aside, that makes it really hard to show off that you've got the latest and greatest phone — but now that we're nearly a decade into the modern smartphone era, it might not be realistic to expect new designs every other year. regardless of what other whiz-bang goodness apple introduces this year — and i'm sure there will be at least one feature that will make even the most jaded amongst us salivate — the reality is that this will absolutely be the iphone remembered as "the one where apple dropped the headphone jack." this isn't to say i won't still buy the next iphone — i'm totally going to buy the new iphone in september — but if we're being honest, this probably won't be the most exciting iphone release we've seen. the backlash will be angrier than when apple changed from the 30-pin connector to the lightning port (making all of those old dock accessories obsolete) and the rallying cry from pundits is already louder than it was when apple decided to not include a floppy drive on the original imac. and, as is usual pattern, more and more credible leaks have come out about what will presumably be called the iphone 7 bloomberg probably has the most accurate reporting thus far (thanks to its hiring of apple reporter mark gurman) in a report that basically confirms what has leaked out about the iphone over the next few months. and thinking about it, i have to wonder: is apple making such an enormous and potentially unpopular change this year so that next year's iphone — you know, the one that might have an all-glass display and an ultra-sharp amoled screen — won't suffer? the big news is that the form factor will remain largely the same, there will be a dual-lens camera system for the larger iphone, and the home button will provide haptic feedback rather than depress like a physical button. in case you need a reminder, this is what we can always expect from a new iphone: it will be apple's fastest iphone ever. still, i'm sure i'm not the only person who looks at the leaks of the next iphone and says, "huh. it's also the phone that will coincidentally be released the same year as the 10th anniversary of the original iphone. ok."     if we're being honest, this probably won't be the most exciting iphone release we've seen. and these would be amazing upgrades — old design or not — but the real headline is that this is the first iphone without a headphone jack.     the backlash will be angrier than when apple changed from the 30-pin connector to the lightning port. not to downplay the new stuff (though i have thoughts on that, just wait), it's worth noting that this follows my playbook for bulletproof iphone predictions to a tee. the secret reason apple might be killing the iphone headphone jack apple is expected to unveil its next iphone in a few weeks. but we'll survive and within a year, most of us will be used to using either lightning headphones, dongles or snazzy wireless options. but i mostly just want to get this release over with so i can start looking forward to the iphone 8. a frequent point of discussion on our podcast, mashtalk , has been about the headphone jack and where all of us are in facing reality. despite the inevitable death of the headphone jack, i'm still going to buy the iphone 7. i can say with absolute certainty that every major review of the device is going to focus substantially on this fact. there will be at least one extra feature you can't get on any other iphone. i feel very certain that, backlash aside, the ultimate fallout of a headphone jack-free iphone will be minimal. adapters will be annoying and we'll all bitch and moan about how bluetooth just isn't good enough. and now, i guess we can add, "it won't have a headphone jack." waterproof casing, wireless charging, better battery life and more powerful optics could all be things we see. yes, yes, i've been telling everyone to accept that the headphone jack is dead since january . fun fact: this was one of the first product designs from jony ive. that's the phone that might ditch the home button altogether. which of course, means that the buzz around the 2017 iphone will be all positive. new design, new screen and some other snazzy feature. dunzo let's all take a moment of silence for the headphone jack. even tech editor pete pachal has come around to see the light. personally, i think that's ok. it will have apple's most advanced optics. and there will be backlash. oh yeah, and the headphone jack ? and apple loves to celebrate anniversaries. it will come in rose gold. we'll have moved on. the jack is dead. but that missing headphone jack? that's it. it's dead. so last year's problem.     a 20th anniversary edition macintosh from 1997. so, i suspect, does apple. people will grumble. pack it up.

the bathroom they want at least once a day, pam retzlaff answered a call from parents concerned about her decision to allow a transgender student at edgar road elementary school to use a bathroom different from his biological gender. that was more than two years ago – a blip in the schoolwide effort to help the soon-to-be third-grader transition as seamlessly as possible from female to male – yet still no cohesive policy exists nationwide on the issue of bathroom access for transgender students. atherton high school in louisville, kentucky, has had a policy in place for two years that allows transgender students to use the bathroom that matches their gender identity, and principal thomas aberli says there have been no problems. last month, the u.s. department of education and the u.s. justice department told schools across the country that title ix of a 1972 federal education law protects transgender students from discrimination based on sex, including the use of bathrooms, locker rooms and showering facilities. although he said students were always able to use the most appropriate bathroom for their needs, biggs said a student visited him in november and explained that some transgender students didn’t feel comfortable using the bathrooms that were available. even before controversy erupted earlier this year over new state laws limiting transgender rights, or this month’s deadly mass shooting at an lgbt nightclub in orlando, many schools across the country had taken proactive steps to make the school environment safer and more welcoming to transgender students. eliza byard, executive director of the gay, lesbian and straight education network, a new york-based organization that supports lgbt-inclusive policies for teachers and students, said school leaders and students live with the issue and understand it better than elected officials do. in camas, wash., across the columbia river from portland, ore., liberty middle school principal marilyn boerke said she was prepared for an onslaught of complaints from parents in the conservative district when the school adopted its policy in 2014, "but it just didn’t happen." in a virginia case, a federal court agreed with the federal government and sided with a transgender student who challenged his school’s policy that forces him to a bathroom that does not match his gender identity. the majority of students surveyed said they didn’t report the harassment or assault to school officials because of doubt the staff would do anything about it or fear that it could make things worse. "there’d be times when i would personally wait in the stall to make sure everyone in the bathroom was cleared out so i could come out of the stall," he said in an interview. in reality, however, lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender students face the greater risk of harassment and assault, especially transgender students, and supporters say the bathroom discussion should be focused on protecting their safety. according to the gay, lesbian and straight education network’s 2013 school climate survey, transgender and gender-nonconforming students faced more hostility than lesbian, gay or bisexual students did. this month, the kansas board of education voted unanimously to oppose the obama administration’s policy, though the board will allow school districts to continue policies that accommodate transgender students. despite some concerns that permitting transgender students to use the appropriate bathroom might threaten the safety and privacy of other students, aberli said that hasn’t happened at atherton. student alonzo hernandez, 16, helped kick-start the process of creating a multi-stalled gender-neutral bathroom at the santee education complex, a high school in los angeles, where he is a junior. opponents of policies that accommodate the bathroom needs of transgender students have argued that it’s an issue of safety for non-transgender students. it was new territory for retzlaff, then principal of the school in webster groves, missouri, a st. louis suburb, but it was never a question of whether she would or wouldn’t open the bathroom. hernandez is in transition from female to male, and his effort was driven, in part, by his own discomfort in using the school’s existing bathrooms. how one theory you never heard of explains everything donald trump does when donald trump declared his candidacy for president a year ago, nate silver’s fivethirtyeight political blog said he had "a better chance of cameoing in another ‘home alone’ movie with macaulay culkin—or playing in the nba finals—than winning the republican nomination." when trump said orlando nightclub patrons should have been armed, the backlash showed him that position was outside the window, so he stepped his stance back to one more acceptable to voters. trump’s public policy, explained with this in mind, now consider trump’s recent about-face after he said the victims of the recent orlando shooting should have been permitted to carry guns into the pulse nightclub. other ideas, such as a guaranteed basic income, even though they may be debated in other countries and supported by economists on both the left and the right, are never seriously considered by politicians because they lie outside the window. while many of his supporters are no doubt staunch believers in the second amendment, even the nra—which endorsed him—said, "no one thinks that people should go into a nightclub drinking and carrying firearms." using the overton window theory to your advantage it is important to remember that politicians rarely move the window; more often than not, they only support policies that are deemed acceptable by their constituents. this theory, named for the late joseph p. overton of the mackinac center for public policy, is a way to explain how opinions about public policies shift over time and the constraints within which policymakers operate. this wasn’t just a flip-flop or mere pandering — it’s more likely that trump’s movement on the issue is evidence he realized his initial stance was a step outside the overton window. even though there are loads of ideas about how to address poverty in the united states, politicians support and debate only a select few, such as the minimum wage, earned income tax credit, medicaid, etc. the reality is that trump—like policymakers and politicians past, present and future—is operating within the confines of the overton window of political possibility. in other words, if you want to see policy change—if you want to expand the overton window—appeal to the hearts and minds of your fellow citizens and the politicians will soon follow. about a week after making the statement, trump appeared to backtrack and said he meant nightclub employees and guards should have been armed, not patrons. with a net favorability rating of -32 percent according to fivethirtyeight and "exactly zero" chance of winning, according to the atlantic, how has trump seemingly emerged victorious from a pool of 17 republican hopefuls? although there is no limit to the number of policy ideas available, elected officials are limited to only actively supporting ideas within this window. one thing is sure, though: while donald trump has thus far appeared to accomplish the impossible, even he has limits. they only go where the current leads them, and it is us — you, me and our neighbors — who determine the direction of the current. the overton window is the spectrum of ideas that are politically palatable to voters. the overton window: when you think about it, it’s so true... the lesson in all this is that politicians, as friedrich hayek once wrote, are like corks bobbing in the sea. to try to answer that question would be to travel down a rabbit hole of speculation that has swallowed so many. these are within the overton window. for example, consider federal welfare policy.
section 922 as appearing in such appendix on september 13, 1994, as such weapons were manufactured on october 1, 1993; (ii) any weapon that is operated by manual bolt, pump, lever or slide action; (iii) any weapon that has been rendered permanently inoperable or otherwise rendered permanently unable to be designated a semiautomatic assault weapon; (iv) any weapon that was manufactured prior to the year 1899; (v) any weapon that is an antique or relic, theatrical prop or other weapon that is not capable of firing a projectile and which is not intended for use as a functional weapon and cannot be readily modified through a combination of available parts into an operable assault weapon; (vi) any semiautomatic rifle that cannot accept a detachable magazine that holds more than five rounds of ammunition; or (vii) any semiautomatic shotgun that cannot hold more than five rounds of ammunition in a fixed or detachable magazine. section 921(a)(30) as appearing in such section on september 13, 1994, and shall include, but not be limited to, any of the weapons, or copies or duplicates of the weapons, of any caliber, known as: (i) avtomat kalashnikov (ak) (all models); (ii) action arms israeli military industries uzi and galil; (iii) beretta ar70 (sc-70); (iv) colt ar-15; (v) fabrique national fn/fal, fn/lar and fnc; (vi) swd m-10, m-11, m-11/9 and m-12; (vi) steyr aug; (vii) intratec tec-9, tec-dc9 and tec-22; and (viii) revolving cylinder shotguns, such as, or similar to, the street sweeper and striker 12; provided, however, that the term assault weapon shall not include: (i) any of the weapons, or replicas or duplicates of such weapons, specified in appendix a to 18 u.s.c. if a gun’s operating system is essentially the same as that of a banned weapon, or if the gun has components that are interchangeable with those of a banned weapon, it’s a "copy" or "duplicate," and it is illegal. with this directive, we will ensure we get the full protection intended when lawmakers enacted our assault weapons ban, not the watered-down version of those protections offered by gun manufacturers. on wednesday, we are sending a directive to all gun manufacturers and dealers that makes clear that the sale of these copycat assault weapons is illegal in massachusetts. "assault weapon", shall have the same meaning as a semiautomatic assault weapon as defined in the federal public safety and recreational firearms use protection act, 18 u.s.c. we recognize that most residents who purchased these guns in the past believed they were doing so legally, so this directive will not apply to possession of guns purchased before wednesday. it prohibits the sale of specific weapons like the colt ar-15 and ak-47 and explicitly bans "copies or duplicates" of those weapons. i could tell you just how many mass murders were thwarted when the perpetrator ran up against a law like this, but i wouldn’t want to let the wind out of the ag’s sail. every black rifle, and all of the variants, compliant versions, and anything that any of these yokels think might be used for an "assault" is now strictly illegal. assault weapons prohibited under our laws cannot be altered in any way to make their sale or possession legal in massachusetts. in the face of utter inaction by congress, states have a duty to enact and enforce laws that protect people from gun violence. not only do we have the legal authority to do so, we have a moral obligation to do so. you can’t have a "mass shooting" without some political ladder-climber coming down hard on the rights of law-abiding americans. in the dozen years since the federal assault weapons ban lapsed, only seven states have instituted their own assault weapons ban. they sell guns without a flash suppressor or folding or telescoping stock, for example, small tweaks that do nothing to limit the lethalness of the weapon. many of those bans have been challenged (unsuccessfully) by the gun industry, and we anticipate our directive may be too. because the criminals who are shooting up campuses and theaters and police protests–they’re all easily stopped by enacting a simple bit of legislation. but gun manufacturers have taken it upon themselves to define what a "copy" or "duplicate" weapon is. breaking: this state just banned the sale of all semi-auto rifles, effective immediately well, we all knew it was coming. i thought she’d just said it was legal to own them if you’d bought them before wednesday. the directive specifically outlines two tests to determine what constitutes a "copy" or "duplicate" of a prohibited weapon. what about all of those guns currently in the law-abiding hands of law-abiding gun owners? if washington won’t use its power to get these guns off our streets, we will. now she’s got a moral obligation to get them "off our streets." if i were in massachusetts, i’d be feeling a bit paranoid right now. the massachusetts assault weapons ban mirrors the federal ban congress allowed to expire in 2004. they market "state compliant" copycat versions of their assault weapons to massachusetts buyers. but our job is to enforce state laws and to keep people safe. wait–to get the guns off the street? what does the state consider an "assault weapon"? and this time it is massachusetts attorney general maura healey. time for some crafty legal eagles to start dismantling this gibberish. she published this in the boston globe today. this directive does both. that will end now. right. yes, you’ve read correctly.

the world’s safest country, in terms of homicide, is tiny liechtenstein, which didn’t have any murders in 2012, but there are a number of countries, especially in europe and east asia, with rates lower than 1 per 100,000. the americas overtook africa as the region with the world’s most murders in this year’s report, accounting for 40 percent of the world’s homicides, though that's a somewhat misleading figure as there are wide geographical variations among and within countries in the region. according to the report, a group of countries—all of them in either the americas or africa—accounting for just 11 percent of the global population are the location of 46 percent of the world’s homicides. men accounted for 95 percent of the perpetrators and 79 percent of the victims of homicide in 2012, a rate that is "consistent across countries and regions, irrespective of the homicide typology or weapon used." overall, the number of murders in the world is relatively stable—even declining slightly—but the most striking finding in the report is how geographically concentrated homicide is become. overall, one in seven homicide victims in 2012 were men between the ages of 15 and 29 living in the americas. and the world's safest country in terms of homicides is... honduras has the world’s highest homicide rate at 90.4 murders per 100,000 people, and it’s not even close. the americas were also the only region where shooting accounted for the majority of homicides. the u.n. office of drugs and crime released its 2013 global study on homicide this week. the rates were driven largely by gang and drug violence. belize, el salvador, guatemala, and jamaica all have rates around 40. homicides are concentrated by gender as well. venezuela is next with 53.7. joshua keating joshua keating is a staff writer at slate focusing on international affairs.
here's how long you can hold onto your cosmetics (via @gma) "good morning america" teamed up with lifestyle expert april franzino, the beauty director at good housekeeping magazine, to find out how long you can keep day-to-day products such as makeup and shampoo. "it's hard to keep track of every single thing that you have so before you go to use any product just take a second and think, 'okay, have i had this for a really long time?'" franzino's tips to save money on beauty products include swapping out liquid eyeliner in favor of a longer-lasting pencil and buying products that have pumps instead of traditional lids because they prevent bacteria from getting in. franzino also recommended not to buy items with an expiration date in bulk because you may end up having to throw it away before you use it. "that's where bacteria can grow," she told abc news, "so you really need to be careful about switching that out every three months at least." products with active ingredients, however, such as toothpaste, are regulated by the fda, meaning they will have an exact expiration date that experts advise you should probably stick to. the u.s. food and drug administration (fda) does not regulate cosmetics, but does warn consumers that "a cosmetic product may go bad if it is stored improperly — for example, in a place that is too warm or too moist." liquid makeup that is used around the eyes, such as eyeliner and mascara, should be replaced every three months, franzino added. view photo as far as hair products go, franzino advised that shampoo and conditioner are generally good for a year. "at that point you may start to notice that they're not performing as well," franzino told abc news. liquid makeup, such as concealer and foundation, should be replaced every six months, franzino said. "you should not be using it beyond that expiration date, especially sunscreens," franzino said. powdered makeup can last about two years before the colors begin to look a bit off, according to franzino. "so you might want to switch them out." aerosol spray products can last much longer.
the things you should never, ever do at a wedding these are the things to avoid on your big day tacky is, of course, in the eye of the beholder. "at one wedding i attended, there was a cash box by the door that said "please contribute to help cover the cost of the wedding," someone else added. other agreed sharing their own awkward experiences, "my cousin and her husband did a thing where they had her husband's two kids go around with baskets and see which kid could get the most money." "when my childhood best friend got married, we were sent an announcement with instructions to send money to a travel agency for the bride & groom's honeymoon," one user explained. a huge number of users declared marriage proposals one of the tackiest things you can do at someone else’s wedding. what’s distasteful to some may be perfectly normal to others, and vice versa, but there are some things we can all agree on. and, while the majority agreed that a donation instead of gifts to couples that already had homes was fine, there were some circumstances that really had them vexed. have you seen that video doing the rounds on facebook where a guy proposes to a bridesmaid at her best friends wedding? the general consensus is that these acts are unquestionably tacky and definitely not the way to go on your big day. "then it was included on the invitation that space was very limited and they wouldn't be inviting me to the wedding. from cringe-worthy dance routines, cheesy tunes and being stuck at the singles table, chances are you’ve experienced at least one of these at a wedding. "miserable marriage jokes are never really funny, but especially so at a wedding," said one person. "what made the cash box even worse was the sister standing by it screeching "you forgot to put money in the box!" taking to reddit in their masses, a horde of disgruntled guests shared the most tasteless moments they experienced at weddings. others agreed adding, "don't propose when it's someone else's day. "who tells someone that they aren't invited, but asks for a gift? think cake toppers that show the bride dragging the groom and ring-bearer signs that read "too late now" or "help me". perhaps the most common gripe among guests though was being asked for money. "really anything that implies that one party isn't there under their own free will. another pet peeve guests have at weddings are vulgar gags about marriage. s***'s not funny," another added. but, what else should you avoid? if someone dared to walk by without dropping in cash." get your own," one person stressed. this is my day. so selfish and inconsiderate," and quite simply, "f*** those people." "i would be livid. adorable, right? wrong. like no. gtf outta here!"
some researchers claimed it was unlikely ismaïl could have fathered that many offspring, noting that women are only fertile for a small window each month, that sperm usually do not fertilize eggs, and that infertility often afflicts women, especially in the developing world. ismaïl was infamously ruthless — his reign is said to have begun with the display of 400 heads at the city of fez, most of them from enemy chiefs, and over the next 55 years it is estimated he killed more than 30,000 people, not including those in battle. "this really emphasizes to us how important it is to choose the right model for studies of reproduction — you really want to know what kind of women you actually are doing your calculations with, thinking about where women are in their life cycles and the sexual habits of women." other factors included how good ismail's sperm were at fertilizing women's eggs as he aged and how women often may look more sexually attractive when they are most fertile during their menstrual cycles. to solve this question, scientists developed computer simulations to see how many times ismaïl had to have sex each day to have 1,171 children in 32 years. moreover, the sultan did not need a harem of four wives and 500 concubines to sire that many offspring — the researchers suggest he needed a harem of only 65 to 110 women. although the models of conception the researchers employed ultimately all found that ismaïl could have actually had all these children, "the results from them were all quite different from each other," oberzaucher said. how one man could have fathered 1000 kids sultan moulay ismaïl of morocco, "the bloodthirsty," reputedly sired hundreds of children and perhaps more than a 1,000. based on reports by dominique busnot, a french diplomat who frequently traveled to morocco, the sultan may actually have had 1,171 children from four wives and 500 concubines by 1704. the simulations suggest ismaïl needed to have sex an average of 0.83 to 1.43 times per day in order to father 1,171 children in 32 years. ismaïl's rule was the longest in moroccan history, and toward its end he controlled the country with an army of more than 150,000 men. now computer simulations suggest this could have been possible if the ruler had sex about once a day for 32 years. "we were as conservative as possible with our calculations, and moulay could still achieve this outcome," study lead author elisabeth oberzaucher, an anthropologist at the university of vienna, told live science. for instance, one set of simulations assumed the menstrual cycles of women do not synchronize, while another suggested they could. ismaïl, who reigned from 1672 to 1727, was the first great sultan of the moroccan alaouite dynasty, the current royal house of the kingdom. according to the guinness book of world records, ismaïl fathered 888 children, the greatest number of progeny for anyone throughout history that can be verified. men who merely looked at one of his wives or concubines were punished by death. however, other scientists argued women are more fertile than those doubting ismaïl had said. at that time, ismaïl was 57 and had ruled for 32 years. the women were either strangled by the sultan himself, or their breasts were cut off, or their teeth torn out. the simulations were based on a variety of models of conception. they found the sultan could have set this record. he was sharifian — that is, he claimed descent from muhammad, the founder of islam. oberzaucher and her colleague karl grammer detailed their findings feb. 14 in the journal plos one. any suspicion of adultery against ismaïl was severely punished.
customer reports cook with down syndrome but was shocked when they discovered who he was a customer dining at ankar’s hoagles in chattanooga, tennessee (us) noticed that the cook was suffering from down syndrome and so s/he decided to report the said worker to the health department. when i learned that someone had the audacity to file a report with the local health inspector over an adult with down syndrome being in the kitchen of a restaurant that he is not just employed at, but that he owns, i was floored. but when the health department came to the restaurant, they were shocked to discover that the ‘worker’ with down syndrome was actually the restaurant’s manager and co-owner! while 0.720% might seem small, it's perfect for nuclear fission, and when the ore samples from okla are compared to other samples from all over the world, it is likely that this was the percentage over 2 billion years ago when the reactor started. typically, uranium ore is made up of three types (isotopes) of uranium, each one with a different number of neutrons: uranium 238, which is the most abundant, uranium 234, which is the rarest, and uranium 235, which nuclear scientists are most interested in because it can sustain nuclear chain reactions. one would expect to find that the uranium ore is composed of 0.720% uranium 235, since that is the percentage found in other rock samples from the earth's crust, the moon and even meteorites. eventually, enough of the water would have boiled away until there wasn't enough left in the reactor to slow down the neutrons. sadly, all good days are numbered, even for a happy natural reactor: the levels of uranium 235 got used up and the level was too low to sustain any more meaningful reactions. the natural reactor must have annoyed nuclear scientists: the first nuclear reactor to produce electricity started up in 1951, and this only produced a trivial amount of energy. and as even scientists had struggled to create a nuclear reactor, it seemed unlikely that nature just happened to create one purely by accident. but in this case, the reactor is a region of natural uranium within the earth's crust, found in okla, gabon. uranium is naturally radioactive, and the conditions in this rocky area happened to be just right to cook up some nuclear reactions. then, the natural flow of groundwater would trickle in until there was enough water to start the whole process again. this conclusion may very well have furrowed some brows since there are three very specific conditions that a reactor needs to churn out energy continuously. the pile of rock in the ground in okla, on the other hand, created nuclear power around 2 billion years ago! the uranium 236 is then overwhelmed with instability and splits, creating a variety of smaller, stable atoms and some neutrons. it was discovered in 1972, when some french scientists took uranium ore from the mine in gabon to test its uranium content. the reactor eventually slowed to a stop, leaving only a few traces behind that it ever existed – including the enigma of the "missing uranium." nuclear fission is when an atom breaks apart into smaller atoms, usually releasing energy in the process. what might seem to be a minor discrepancy of 0.003% is very significant with regards to uranium. the water would slow down the neutrons, but the energy would heat up the water. the nuclear reactor had a supply of a regulating substance as well: a flow of natural groundwater. the neutrons started shooting off into the ground without reacting with anything, and the reaction would stop. as the atoms started to split, they released neutrons as well as energy. this neutron fuses with a uranium 235, and together they combine to form uranium 236, which is unstable. these neutrons can then happily shoot towards other atoms and continue the chain reaction. this neutron can then whoosh towards another uranium 235 atom and start the fission process. an ancient nuclear reactor that was churning away 2 billion years ago sounds like a myth. however, these french scientists found something fishy: the uranium sample only contained 0.717% of uranium 235. instead, this missing 0.003% had undergone nuclear fission and split into other atoms. the first was owning a good percentage of uranium 235 to fuel the reaction. that meant that, back at the mine, around 200 kilograms (around 440 pounds) of uranium 235 appeared to be missing. after a time, the water would get so hot that it would start to boil off. featured image: danilo russo/flickr source: naturally occurring nuclear fission source: naturally occurring nuclear fission source: naturally occurring nuclear fission uranium 235 decays naturally into thorium and releases a neutron in the process. the conditions that the natural reactor happened to fulfill are as follows. is there really a 2 billion-year-old nuclear reactor in africa? unlikely, but not impossible, because that is exactly what happened. the second condition is a source of neutrons. maybe it's because the term reactor usually implies a manmade structure. this watery cycle probably continued for hundreds of thousands of years. it hadn't been lost or stolen.
inspired by the personal conversations that other people had with roman's bot, she's now working on replika, a new product that, like eterni.me, will collect a person's stories and memories and learn to mimic their conversational mannerisms by texting with them. the goal of the platform, she explains, isn't to let everyone create their own "roman" that will live on after they die, but to give everyone a kind of "friend" that is there every day to talk to, to make you "more connected with your friends and yourself." they let us combine our curated memories and experiences with all our messy data — the texts and tweets and "likes" and photos — and organize it into something that we hope will let our loved ones and future generations actually understand something about who we were. the natural progression of eterni.me or replika's ideas would be to combine the ai with realistic digital 3d avatars (something eterni.me eventually plans to do to, but has back-burnered while it works on the first part of its mission). long-time vr researcher jacki morie coined the phrase "the ultimate selfie" to describe how she predicts that current technologies could eventually combine to create digital avatars that would not only would look like us, but move like us, and learn from us, too. kudya and other mourners could "speak" with roman by talking to the bot or asking it questions — its responses would be based on the thousands of texts messages and photos she had fed the neural network controlling its artificial intelligence. while the idea of talking to a dead relative through a digitized ghost may seem creepy — edging into bizarre "uncanny valley" territory — experts say that, on principle, it's actually a completely natural progression of the way that people have always grieved. but while we're far from achieving that pinnacle of immorality, technology in the here-and-now has already started giving us a sliver of eternal life while shaping how we grieve our loved ones if and when they die. facebook allows people to "memorialize" the pages of the deceased and those pages often become a public and wide-reaching digital wake where friends and family share photos, memories, or their messages to the dead. but intention or not, a person's replika bot would be able to keep responding like you and telling your stories after you died in the same way that eterni.me's avatars could. she imagines that in the not-so-distant future, when using an avatar in vr is fairly common practice, people will be able to train a digital surrogate that could live on after they're gone. the silicon valley-startup eterni.me aims to let people preserve their "most important thoughts, stories, and memories" in an artificially intelligent system that could ultimately communicate conversationally with others once its creator is gone. beyond the psychological implications, palliative care doctor mark taubert says that he doesn't think that it will be technically feasible for the tech to answer the kinds of burning questions people will have for their digitized loved ones. "i often find that the questions a grieving friend or relative may have for the deceased are often quite difficult to answer, for example, 'did you ever forgive me for what i did in ....?'" ultimately that process will build the ai's understanding of its subject, and be able to function like a smarter, more personalized version of the chatbots you can already interact with today. currently the idea lives within whitepapers and sci-fi movies, and the only thing (most) researchers agree on is that it won't be possible for a really long time. facebook is researching how to create life-like virtual reality avatars as are a host of different startups, including one called xxarray that explicitly envisions helping people create a digital legacy. "we want to encourage people to start curating their digital legacy and we will do that by triggering conversations based on previously collected data of what they did, felt, or experienced." how technology will bring loved ones back to life the theory that humans will eventually be able to upload our brains to computers has fascinated futurists and neuroscientists for years. "we chose this approach because we would like to help people solve the 'blank page syndrome' we have often seen when somebody tries to write in their diary," explains eterni.me founder marius ursache. though eterni.me's new app will be collecting all this information, the neural network backbone won't be able to turn that mass of unruly data into engaging conversations yet. "you'll be scanned and have this 3d construct that can then walk around in virtual worlds and it will retain the things that you did within an ai," she says. your friends could talk to your replika, too, asking it personal questions or using it to schedule plans with the real you. both servaty-seib and grief therapist dr. bob neymeyer agree that new ways to communicate with the dead could be healthy for many patients. "now even the first replikas we have on the app can tell you a lot about the person that trained it." or it could be addictive to people already prone to focusing too much on the dead, deemphasizing other relationships and not moving forward, says neymeyer. the app will connect to a person's facebook account (with other social integration planned) and launch micro-conversations based on their daily activities. if people have always found ways now to talk to the dead, could it be problematic if they start talking back? over 100,000 people have reserved their replika "name" and 17,000 applied for early testing of the app, but only 1,200 were given access to the beta version. how could an artificially intelligent system taught simply to mimic your style and echo your memories tackle that difficult question in any real way? aftertalk prompts the bereaved to write letters to their loved ones that can either be private or shared with a therapist or family member. but now it says it plans to launch revamped version of its app to a test group in early 2017. he's had patients who have listened to the dead's voicemail over and over or spent days on end at their grave. such an avatar could both soothe the bereaved and allow future generations to know much more about their great-great-grandparents. they are very, very much about the person who is dying or thinking about their own eventual death. while the roman bot couldn't narrate stories in the same way that eterni.me envisions, it wrote in his voice. deadsocial allows users to set up a curated facebook-page of sorts where their love ones can commune once they've passed. earlier this year, entrepreneur eugenia kudya created an ai-powered chatbot in honor of her friend roman mazurenko, who died tragically in 2015. heather servaty-seib, a grief researcher and purdue professor says that it's in line with the "continuing bonds" theory of bereavement. it could be damaging to children, who generally don't fully grasp the concept of death, servaty-seib says. "the artificial intelligence that we need requires a lot of effort and time — it may take years," ursache says. the bot would first ask you about the past and eventually prod you about your daily life. "a lot of the people who expressed interest in eterni.me don't have this time. kudya was vague about when she thinks the technology will actually be good enough for the general public. this forces us to use more or less the the approach of the cryonics initiatives — preservation first, technology second." until we can really can upload our brains to the cloud, that's our best shot at immortality. the concepts of death and bereavement as we know them now would cease to exist. talking to the bot helped kudya grieve and made her feel more connected to her friend. "it's all about making people a little bit more open about themselves ... a little more vulnerable," kudya says. "this kind of avatar could become a repository for our experiences and our memories." death changes the form of your relationship with someone, not the fact that you have one. they can even choose to schedule personal messages that will send from beyond the grave. "now imagine if someone had an extensive, almost inexhaustible archive of conversation available with the deceased," he says. their site is mostly unchanged, save for the counter of people signed up for early access that rises each day. many already talk to the dead through a smartphone screen instead of at a graveyard. since the company had a splashy launch two years ago it has progressed with crypt-like quietness. (or through a phone booth, like in otsuchi, japan where tsunami survivors "call" their lost loved ones.) by transferring our minds into machines we could live forever, unmoored from the feebleness of our physical bodies. digital legacy tools like eterni.me or deathlogic don't just serve the people left behind. meanwhile, a semblance of the company's vision has already come to "life." these services offer a way for us to build monuments to ourselves. still, there are some potential pratfalls related to how we mourn. he says.
breast cancer rates are on the rise among these women breast cancer rates on the rise among black women though the reason is unknown, researchers say breast cancer rates increased 0.2 percent among black women but remained stable among whites between 2006 and 2010, the latest time period assessed. though the reason is unknown, researchers say breast cancer rates increased 0.2 percent among black women but remained stable among whites between 2006 and 2010, the latest time period assessed. breast cancer death rates have dropped by 34 percent since 1990 in all racial/ethnic groups except american indians/alaska natives, while african-american women continue to have the poorest breast cancer survival of any racial/ethnic group. in june, a jama study showed that black women are less likely to survive a breast cancer diagnosis within five years because they undergo fewer screenings, have poorer health at the time of diagnosis and have more advanced disease by the time the cancer is found. authors of of the acs report also noted that reproductive history and obesity are more strongly linked to er-positive breast cancer, the form of the disease more common among white women, while lower socioeconomic status has been linked to raised risk for er-negative breast cancer, which is more common among african americans. historically, white women have had the highest breast cancer incidence rates among women aged 40 years and older, and they still do with about 127 cases per 100,000 compared with 118 cases per 100,000 black women. however, incidence rates are now converging among white and african-american women, particularly among those aged 50 years to 59 years. "although the incidence haven't declined, we have made strides in the effort to improve the survival rate. death rates have declined by 34 percent since 1990. however, not all ethnic groups are enjoying this improved survival," dr. stephanie bernik, chief of surgical oncology at lenox hill hospital in new york city, told healthday .

while it was determined the mold variety in the cannabis was not harmful to adults, it's clear that the united states needs to form better quality control and standards testing for cannabis, be it medical, recreational or for research. according to reports from pbs and the washington post, all marijuana used in research must be supplied by the federal government, and the pot that the government has been handing out looks like trash. sue sisley, a researcher with maps studying the medical effects of marijuana on u.s. veterans suffering from ptsd told pbs the weed supplied to them for the study doesn't even smell like weed. though there way may be hope on the horizon: the dea announced in the summer that it would start to allow other bulk growers the ability to provide cannabis for medical research, though none have yet been approved. rick doblin, maps’ director, blasted nida's capabilities by telling pbs, "they’re in no way capable of assuming the rights and responsibilities for handling a drug that we’re hoping to be approved by the fda as prescription medicine. " the farm is run by the national institute on drug abuse (nida), and is the only facility licensed by the dea to grow pot for research, since marijuana remains a schedule 1 drug to the dea. when confronted about the mold and potency, nida and the university of mississippi told pbs that neither test the samples for mold before they're shipped. https://t.co/uknsywqpwq pic.twitter.com/ibqv8p5nwu — washington post (@washingtonpost) march 13, 2017 though it's relatively simple to grow, the quality of cannabis you can purchase (legally or illegally) in the united states can vary greatly. as the post points out, when researchers are testing the effects of marijuana, they need to test the real thing that people are actually growing, buying and consuming. in the age of stickiest-of-ickiest-and-rising thc percentages, it appears the united states government still supplies researchers with low grade brick weed you probably smoked in high school. nida blamed the mold problem on the lab, saying they didn't handle it properly when they left it in a refrigerator for two days instead of freezing it. there they found high levels of total yeast and mold in some samples, as well as potency that didn't match what they had ordered. maps fired back, saying the weed with elevated total yeast and mold counts "were found in samples that never left the freezer before testing," according to pbs. regardless of how you feel about marijuana, the effects of the plant deserve to be properly researched, and right now, it appears they aren't. sisely had the samples provided by the government tested by an independent lab in colorado as a part of typical protocol. and while weed comes in plenty of colors, shapes, densities and sizes, the pot analyzed by pbs and the post looks extremely yellow and filled with stems. lighting, air quality, humidity and pests can all play a massive role in the end product, so growing weed may be pretty easy, but growing great weed can be pretty taxing. but the cannabis being supplied to researchers currently is far from something you'd typically buy in a dispensary in denver. all of the cannabis provided for medical research comes from a 12-acre farm located at the university of mississippi. in colorado you can walk into a dispensary and buy weed that is easily 20 percent, sometimes upwards of 30 percent. so the government clearly doesn't have it together when it comes to growing pot. not only is the weed bad, but sisley claims it was moldy as well. actually, it's worse than the weed you smoked in high school. one sample was supposed to contain 13 percent thc — it reportedly had just 8 percent. this is what happens when the government tries to grow weed. (it's classified in a category with heroin and ecstasy, which also makes a lot of sense.) shockingly, 13 percent thc is the highest percentage nida offers. it doesn’t smell like cannabis.' government marijuana looks nothing like the real stuff. it doesn’t smell like cannabis," she said. the sacramento bee told the story last year: lester holt sr. was concerned in 1979 when he learned that his son was planning to drop out of california state university, sacramento, to work at a san francisco radio station. before the lights go on, here are five things to know about holt: holt is a registered republican donald trump has spent the weeks leading up to the general election debates predicting unfair treatment by the moderators. he was not involved in any major clashes during the debate but showed a willingness to ask tough questions, such as when he asked clinton about the "reset button" with russia during her tenure as secretary of state. holt is the first black presidential debate moderator since 1992 holt, whose grandparents immigrated to the united stats from jamaica, is the first black moderator of a general election presidential debate since carole simpson in 1992. gwen ifill moderated vice-presidential debates in 2004 and 2008, and bernard shaw moderated the vp debate in 2000, but it has been 24 years since a black journalist moderated a debate between the major-party nominees for president. these are the people who will be lobbing questions at republican donald trump and democrat hillary clinton when they go head-to-head at the 2016 presidential debates.
