lindsey tepe of the new america foundation, for instance, has written about the ways in which public education has become a battleground between those who view american history as "a sweeping tale filled with ... grand heroes, epic battles, and the continuing struggle for the rights to life, liberty, and the pursuit of happiness," and those who recognize that "american history is also full of inconvenient truths ... and the injustices perpetrated throughout the course of building this nation." and, as in the u.k. and canada, the veterans of foreign wars (vfw) distributes poppies on veterans day and memorial day so that people can publicly commemorate the fallen. separately, two bills have been introduced in congress in the last two years alone—one to establish two minutes of silence on veterans day, the other to do the same on memorial day. in this environment, it would be worthwhile to rigorously observe a moment in which americans collectively acknowledge the good that their country has done in the world—and the real, human costs that have accompanied that involvement. one potential explanation lies in the fact that the u.s. hasn’t recently experienced the kind of generational destruction that, say, the first and second world wars brought to britain and russia, respectively. the numbers don’t lie, though: according to the vfw, only 9 million poppies will be distributed in the u.s. (population: 316 million) this year. by comparison, u.s. losses in the second world war constituted about 0.3 percent of the population, and 0.1 percent in the first world war. when america’s national mythology and political discourse preach a tale of endless victory and exceptionalism, there is less of an incentive to focus on those men and women who didn’t come home from battle. jay winter of yale university told me that those men "left behind ... a void, an absence, a black hole in the center of thousands of families defined in part by who wasn’t there." a debate is also underway about what america’s global role should be, with many americans leaning toward isolationism (despite a surge of support for a more muscular u.s. foreign policy following isis’s beheading of american journalists). in communities across the country, members of the military, members of government, and military families gather on both holidays to raise and lower flags, decorate graves, and participate in processions and parades. on memorial day, some people observe the national one-minute moment of remembrance at 3 p.m., which was passed into law by congress in 2000. from 1989 until his passing in 2012, senator daniel inouye of hawaii, a world war ii veteran, repeatedly introduced resolutions to return memorial day to its traditional date—and, by proxy, its original intent. during the second world war, the united states fielded a conscription-based military of approximately 16 million people, out of a population of 135 million. joe davis, director of public affairs at the vfw, believes the all-volunteer force, established in 1973, drove a wedge between the military community and an ever-growing civilian population. by comparison, 45 million poppies will be distributed in the u.k. (population: 64 million) for armistice day, according to the royal british legion. winter argues that "what makes u.s. commemoration different is the emphasis on redemption in american narratives of war." davis also cited as a factor the shifting of memorial day from its original, fixed date of may 30 to the last monday of may. it should come as no surprise, then, that the trauma of that conflict led to the establishment of decoration day, the precursor of memorial day. today, the professional military is well below its troop level during world war ii, and the u.s. population has more than doubled in the interim. the only american war that incurred such steep losses was the civil war, in which 2 percent of the population perished. in the united states, at least, they may also stem from a strain of american thinking that highlights historical triumphs and skips over what those triumphs have cost. neither bill has been passed, although the one for veterans day has since been revised as an amendment to the national defense authorization act. judging by recent polls, the american public is war-weary and largely of the view that the wars in iraq and afghanistan were failures. "what makes u.s. commemoration different is the emphasis on redemption in its narratives of war." in the u.k., on the other hand, "the absence of the lost generation mattered more." the soviet union suffered an even more dramatic loss in the second world war—amounting to roughly 15 percent of its population. britain lost approximately 2 percent of its population in the great war, resulting in a "lost generation." "when you link a military holiday to a three-day weekend, you lose the meaning of the day," davis told me. differences in how military holidays are observed can’t be reduced to a numbers game, though. whatever the explanation, the lack of an appropriate occasion to commemorate america’s war casualties has been noted. observation of the moment is left up to participating organizations, such as amtrak and major league baseball. all this isn’t to suggest that americans never mark veterans day and memorial day. is there a better way to observe veteran's day? why doesn’t the united states have a common culture of commemoration? the finer details make a difference as well. the timing of these bills is opportune.
don’t rely on previous salaries if women can lose millions over their careers because they get job offers based on pay that is already low, one way to stop the pattern is to ignore their past salaries. (as the actress jennifer lawrence wrote in lenny after the sony hacking revealed that she was paid less than her male co-stars, she didn’t fight for more because "i didn’t want to seem ‘difficult’ or ‘spoiled.’ ") one solution, ms. babcock said, is to coach women to negotiate. "if a cashier gets pregnant, has no parental leave, has to leave and reapply for her job, that’s not the same as making a career choice," said philip cohen, a sociologist at the university of maryland. it says that men and women must be paid the same for similar jobs, not just for exactly the same job at the same site, as the looser federal equal pay act requires. because starting salaries determine raises and future salaries, women who do not bargain lose as much as $750,000 for middle-income jobs and $2 million for high-income jobs over their careers, ms. babcock found. when receiving job offers, 51.5 percent of men and 12.5 percent of women asked for more money, according to a study of carnegie mellon university graduate students by linda babcock, an economist at the university. in august, the federal office of personnel management said government hiring managers could no longer rely on an employee’s previous salary when setting his or her new one. sometimes their pay lags because they take breaks from work when their children are young, work fewer hours or take more time off than men for child care crises. in states that offer paid parental leave, for instance, mothers are more likely to return to work, work more hours and earn higher wages, economists have found. women might have been spurred to negotiate after seeing that their salaries were lower, he theorized, or cities might have made salaries more equitable to avoid lawsuits. build more flexible workplaces ms. goldin of harvard has found that the pay gap is largest in occupations with the least flexibility in terms of where and when people work, like finance and medicine. the gap shrinks when people can work on their own schedules, as in many tech jobs and when people can easily substitute for one another, as happens among pharmacists. but her research and that of others has found that women are penalized for negotiating, while men are rewarded for the same behavior. make work easier for mothers research has found that salaries at men and women’s first jobs out of school are fairly similar. proposed federal legislation known as the paycheck fairness act would require companies to report pay data to the government, give grants for negotiation training and make class-action lawsuits easier. "we put the onus on the company to pay fairly instead of on candidates to negotiate fair pay," ms. pao wrote in the hollywood reporter. marc benioff, the c.e.o of salesforce.com, said last year that after such an analysis, the company spent $3 million to make women’s salaries equal to men’s. another is to change corporate practices so the people who set compensation are aware of the disparity and are advocates for women during negotiations. social scientists and policy makers have some ideas, as do companies that have been trying to combat the problem in their work forces. in other research, she found that when women did ask, they asked for 30 percent less than men requested. to negotiate, or not men are paid more partly because they’re much more likely to ask for it. "don’t ask about salary history for new hires, and it really reduces the impact of previous discrimination," ms. babcock said. alexandre mas, an economist at princeton, studied the effects of a 2010 california law that required cities to publish municipal salaries. jake rosenfeld, a sociologist at washington university, has found that salary transparency raises wages, in part by lending legitimacy to employees’ arguments in wage bargaining. policies that help keep women in the work force, like affordable child care, paid sick days and parental leave, could help. women are also more likely to have worked in the lower-paying public or nonprofit sectors. "one thing policy can do is make it easier for women to stick with their careers." change the law federal law doesn’t require most of these things, so some lawmakers are trying other tactics. google has said it does this and instead makes offers based on what a job is worth. in a pharmacy, for instance, electronic medical records have made it easier for different pharmacists to serve the same patient. publish everyone’s pay when employers publish people’s salaries, the pay gap shrinks. that has been true in the public sector, where disclosing pay information is often required. the gender pay gap widens a few years later when women start having children. kimberly-clark and pricewaterhousecoopers have said their examinations led managers to address the fact that fewer women were reaching top positions. the acting director, beth cobert, explained that the practice particularly disadvantaged women who had taken time off to raise children. "even being cognizant of gender pay disparity being an issue can change norms," he said. companies might address the culture of face time and overwork, and change how they operate. other american companies say they have analyzed pay this way, though most do it privately. sometimes their employers assume they’ll do so, even if they don’t. a few european countries have required that big companies publish pay information by sex. the strongest equal pay bill in the country went into effect in california this month. that is what ellen pao did when she was chief executive of reddit. ideas about how to bridge the gender gap on pay. "i think that is the most effective thing organizations can do." then, women aren’t penalized as much for working fewer hours. the california law also prohibits employers from retaliating against workers for discussing pay. president obama in 2014 required that federal contractors report it to the labor department. the company established pay ranges based on roles and experience and gave applicants nonnegotiable offers. so what might work to close the gap? but that legislation is stalled in congress. it prompted pay cuts, but only among men. another answer is to ban pay negotiation completely.
we compared traffic data from that same french news publisher with a top-10 french sports publisher of similar size and found that while before 10am they achieved similar results, the curves then diverge. there were still crucial differences — when one publisher experienced a peak in share performance at 11am, it is in fact one of the worst times for the other publisher to be sharing. firstly, when we compared three major publishers of national and international news based in south america, france and the u.k., we found significant variance in the shape of the traffic profiles for each publisher. it’s clear there is no one-size-fits-all approach for publishers, even if they are in the same category — optimal times vary depending on the location of the audience. we looked at 220,000 facebook posts made by our publisher clients between march 20 and july 10, 2016, and sorted them according to the time of day at which they were shared. overall, the sports publisher’s traffic is more consistent, with fewer dramatic peaks and troughs, while the news publisher has clearly demarked periods when more readers are clicking through to their stories. as can be seen in the above chart, the south american publisher achieved best performance when sharing between 11am and 4pm, and poor performance at other times. we also compared two similar publications in the same country and looked at the traffic profiles of two top-10 french news publishers. even for two publications of equivalent size working in the same country, there are stark differences in audience behavior depending on the subject matter of the content. again, there are important differences, and these nuances help us understand the characteristics of audiences and their varying appetite for particular content types at different times of the day. the british and french publishers, meanwhile, achieved more consistent results throughout the day, although both experienced peaks in referral traffic at different times. using data from leading publishers, we will dispel the myths and demonstrate that there are no universal "best times" to share content on facebook. could it be that readers in france all consume content more consistently throughout the day than the south americans? coschedule, fast company, hubspot, shortstack, forbes, hootsuite, quicksprout and others all claim to have the answers to such seemingly simple questions as "when is the best time to post on facebook?" by early afternoon, the news publisher is enjoying a strong peak in traffic, whilst the sports publisher is in a pronounced trough. indeed this is why many publishers now commit very significant resource to optimizing their performance — with large social media teams and even data scientists. there’s all manner of advice and guidance on the web for online publishers looking to optimize their social media efforts. one explanation for this could be that daily routines and behaviors vary between countries and cultures, which therefore impacts media consumption patterns. all shares were obtained using local time, in order to compensate for time zone differences, then normalized by average client performance and volume. to get the most accurate picture, a publisher would need to perform this analysis again on a real-time basis due to strong daily fluctuations. using the median for all stories and a year’s worth of data helped ensure the analysis wasn’t skewed by outliers. the natural next question is whether there are country-wide best times for posting stories on facebook. however, many of the strategies used by publishers for optimizing engagement and boosting referral traffic from social are flawed. we then compared performance of posts based on whether the articles were about sports or technology. we analyzed the median traffic that articles received from facebook three hours after they were shared. but even these descriptions of the individual publishers do not do the subtlety of the data justice. when's the best time to share on facebook? interestingly, there also seems to be significant variance based on article topic. and "how often should you post stories on facebook?" can as an undergraduate [at howard university], at harvard business school, and as i moved to different cities -- denver, boston, detroit, new york -- i'd always find a ballet studio. from the mundane to the truly unique -- from yoga class to family dinner to your bath tub -- we are spotlighting the environments where you are truly unplugged. that one email check pulled into class what i should be doing after class. email draws you in and there’s always some action item -- something that triggers a response. for the rest of the class, it made it much more difficult to concentrate. the truth is, that during class, i never looked at my phone. so there's something about being with the like-minded women (and some men!) and something that helps you celebrate what it is to be human. it just brings me so much joy to dance. everyone who is there has opted in simply because they love ballet and they enjoy dancing. i realized that i had invaded my sacred space with technology. i lost being in the moment, being present and the joy faded. our "sacred spaces" series explores where your phone is unwelcome. this interview was edited and condensed for space and clarity. bonita stewart is vice president of partner business solutions at google. it became this sacred space. who are there with me. remembering the exercise, going across the floor. want to share your own? companies fail to address these needs within their sales department, and they end up losing their top representatives because of it. becoming sales intelligent modern technology didn't create a training or resource crisis, but it did change the types of tools and training that social selling requires. organizations that rely heavily on cold-calling for lead generation need to know whom to target and how to reach them with actionable messages. they may have watched a demo video or presentation and come away feeling more confused than they were to begin with. productivity tools have enabled salespeople to work smarter and spend more time interfacing with clients than managing mundane tasks. when people don't feel they're supported because they're constantly wanting for resources, help businesses identify prospects, collect contact information, load the data into their crms, and schedule drip campaigns. the better you know your audience, the more effective your campaigns will "‘why would one of america’s top 1500m runners decide to have a baby leading into arguably the biggest year in a track athlete’s career, an olympic year?’ well, the answer is actually quite simple. though she never gave up her training — taking just a week off from exercise when she gave birth under her doctor's supervision — brown has also been savoring her moments with her newborn while on the road to rio. while in orbit for his second time at the age of 77, glenn exclaimed that it is impossible not to believe in god after seeing the earth from thousands of miles above. while many will focus on the scientific miracle that allowed glenn to become the first american to orbit the earth, glenn himself noted that god was also an inseparable part of that miracle. "to look up out at this kind of creation and not believe in god is to me impossible," glenn said in 1998. in the late 1990s glenn, among other nasa astronauts lucky enough to go to space to touch the face of god, insisted that his religious faith was made stronger by his experience in space. the tweet from nasa announcing his passing hints at that something: we are saddened by the loss of sen. john glenn, the first american to orbit earth. senator from his home state, and made history once again by becoming the oldest human to go to space in 1998 at the age of 77. so, as we remember the life and works of john glenn, let us recall too his faith in a god that brought him such comfort, a god that created this awe inspiring universe full of wonder. the native ohioan made history as the first american to orbit the earth in 1962, went on to become a long-serving u.s. "to look up out at this kind of creation and not believe in god is to me impossible." the passing of john glenn, one of america’s most famous nasa astronauts, marks the end of an era for american exceptionalism. "the opportunity to join in its quests and explorations was a challenge not only to fulfill a sacred duty but to join a joyous adventure." glenn was admitted to ohio state university wexner medical center last week for treatment and passed away on thursday, december 8. big government, faith, john glenn, nasa big government, faith, john glenn, nasa big government, faith, john glenn, nasa the famed astronaut, a devout presbyterian, also noted that he was praying every day during his second historic flight in space. pic.twitter.com/89idi9r1nb — nasa (@nasa) december 8, 2016 god speed, indeed, but god was also there all along, according to glenn. defense of its ideals was an obligation," glenn wrote in 2000. but glenn said something else that may be overlooked as the nation reviews his life and times. all of the medals are the same size and weight, with a diameter of 85 millimeters and a weight of 500 grams, making them the heaviest medals in the history of the summer olympics and tied for the largest medal in the summer games. the "podium value" of the gold medal at the rio 2016 olympics is approximately $564 , based on the price of gold at $43.76 per gram and the price of sterling silver at 61 cents per gram, as of thursday. more than 40 percent of the copper used in the production of the bronze medals came from the industrial waste of the mint of brazil through a process that was developed internally. paralympic medals with new sound innovation the 2,642 paralympic award medals were made by the mint of brazil and are of the same weight, dimensions and materials as the olympic medals. for the first time in history, according to rio olympic officials, the medals are designed in a curved dome-shape, higher in the center, so the thickness ranges from 6 mm to 11 mm. a total of 2,488 medals were produced for the rio 2016 olympics (812 gold, 812 silver and 864 bronze) by the mint of brazil. each of the 812 olympic gold medals is plated with six grams of gold (the minimum required by the international olympic committee) with 99.9 percent purity. if the entire medal was made of gold it would be valued at nearly $22,000, which is why 1912 was the last time all-gold medals were awarded. the remaining 494 grams is made of silver with 92.5 percent purity (the standard for sterling silver), according to the mint of brazil. this is how much a gold medal from #rio2016 is really worth: the rio 2016 summer olympic games is being billed as the "biggest sporting event on the planet." however, it is a long way off from the approximate $708 record price of the 2012 london gold medal, due to the record high price of gold and silver at the time. it’s difficult to argue against that claim as more than 11,000 athletes will be competing in 28 sports and 42 disciplines for the event’s ultimate prize: the gold medal. more than 30 percent of the silver used in the production of the medals are recycled from mirrors, waste solders and x-ray plates. the design is highlighted by a trail of seeds that wraps from the front to the reverse side of the medal. the front of each medal has the rio 2016 logo framed by laurel leaves (which were given as awards for the ancient olympics). sustainable design the medals were produced with methods that the rio 2016 olympic officials described as "symbols of sustainability and accessibility ." each medal comes with a sustainably sourced wooden box, certified by the forest stewardship council, that contains a miniature sculpture of the rio 2016 logo. the rio 2016 paralympic games logo is on both sides of the medal, with braille inscriptions on the front side. this is in line with the 2014 sochi winter olympic games (about $566, even though that medal was 31 grams heavier). even the ribbons attached to the medals were well thought out with half of the materials woven from recycled polyester polyethylene terephthalate (pet) yarn (recycled post consumer polyester made from bottles). for the first time the medals come with sound, so visually impaired athletes can identify the medal’s color . adding a personal touch, the name of the event in which the medal was awarded is engraved by laser along its outer edge. more than 100 employees in various professional fields—including, art, sustainability, engineering and production—were involved in the making of the 5,130 medals. the reverse reveals the traditional etching of , the greek goddess of victory, in the foreground and the greek panathnaic stadium in the background. the 864 bronze medals contain 475 grams of copper (95%) and 25 grams of zinc (5%). each of the 812 silver medals contains 500 grams of sterling silver. olympic officials say the seeds represent "the courage, persistence and development of athletes." the gold medal makes the loudest noise and the bronze the weakest. the purity silver standard also is a minimum ioc requirement. above nike is the engraving of "xxxi olympiad" and the olympic rings. at least three winter olympic medals were larger and heavier. anthony demarco is founder of the jewelry news network. please join me on the jewelry news network facebook page, twitter @jewelrynewsnet and instagram @jewelrynewsnetwork. the podium value is about $305. the gold is mined entirely free of mercury. the bronze medals have little intrinsic value. metal ball bearings were placed inside the medals which rattle when shaken.

these realistic optimists may get the best of both worlds, using their realism to perform better at work and elsewhere, but aren't getting bogged down by unhappiness, said sophia chou, an organizational psychology researcher at national taiwan university, who presented her findings at a meeting of the american psychological association in honolulu, hawaii earlier this month. [7 things that will make you happy] optimists and pessimists past research has shown that optimists value thoughts that make them feel good about themselves, whereas pessimists prize a more truthful vision of themselves. but a clear-eyed view can be bad for pessimists' well-being, as they tend to be more prone to depression, chou said. in order to cultivate a rosy-but-realistic outlook, people should maintain a clear-eyed view of reality, but emphasize what they can control in most situations, she said. after several years working in business, chou noticed there were some people who were both optimistic and realistic, and that they tended to be very successful. interestingly, the realistic optimists also got better grades, on average, than their less grounded peers -- probably because they didn't delude themselves into thinking they would do well without studying or working hard, chou said. the surveys tested how many "positive illusions" the students held, as well as whether they were more motivated by self-enhancement or reality. "every time they face an issue or a challenge or a problem, they won't say 'i have no choice and this is the only thing i can do.' so-called realistic optimists combine the positive outlook of optimists with the clear-eyed perspective of pessimists, new research has found. people with this personality type may be happier and more successful are you a "glass half-full" or a "glass half-empty" kind of person? traditionally, a more realistic outlook is paired with poorer well-being and greater depression, yet the realistic optimists managed to be happy. that's likely because they recognize the possibility of failure, whereas their counterparts use positive illusions to ease their anxiety, chou said. "realistic optimists tend to choose accuracy over self-enhancement; the unrealistic optimists tend to choose self-enhancement," chou said. being a realistic optimist does have one downside, however: they are more prone to anxiety than their completely unrealistic peers. the findings suggest that realistic and unrealistic optimists may actually be very different personality types, chou said. self-control key she found that realistic optimists believed they had more self-control and control over their interpersonal relationships. that allows them to stay cheery and upbeat about the future, even if they recognize the challenges of the present. so chou administered a battery of personality surveys to about 200 college and graduate students in taiwan. they will be creative, they will have a plan a, plan b and plan c," chou said. realistic views the optimists sorted into two camps: the realists and the idealists. as it turns out, some people can be both. to understand why, she dug deeper into the personality assessments. she wondered whether realism and optimism were really diametrically opposed. optimists tend to live longer and be healthier overall.

though you may have come across that "as seen on tv" infomercial for spray perfect, the company that's actually credited with revolutionizing the product is london-based company nails inc. their paint can sprays are now available stateside in three highly pigmented shades, including hoxton market (a hot pink), mayfair lane (a pastel pink) and shoreditch lane (a gleaming silver). don't worry about getting the spray-on nail polish all over your fingers -- you can remove the excess paint by simply washing your hands or using a makeup remover wipe. here's exactly how it works, demonstrated in gifs by nails inc. you start by applying a base coat -- because you've got to protect your natural nails and provide a smooth surface for the pigment to adhere to. this trend is perfect for people who can't paint their own nails some may call the spray-on nail polish trend "lazy" or "messy," but we think it's pretty awesome. unlike traditional nail lacquers that require a steady hand and a long drying time, aerosol-based nail polishes allow you to spray on a manicure in under 20 seconds. you can either use your own traditional brush-on base coat, or one that may be sold with your spray-on polish. milk makeup and china glaze have recently added spray-on nail polishes to their beauty lines, proving that this trend isn't going anywhere any time soon. and be sure to hold the bottle at least 3 to 5 inches above your hand to evenly disperse the pigment. pro tip: place a paper towel or old newspaper to prevent getting product all over the place. next, shake up the can and spray on your nail polish. seal your manicure with a traditional top coat and you're done! amazing, right?
for example, ‘it looks terrible!’ or ‘no you’re the worst!’ followed by ‘only joking, of course you’re wonderful!’ macmillan cancer support’s new murder mystery fundraising game ‘whodunnit?’ takes place on saturday 25th march. tell the truth first: in an emergency such as: ‘do you like my new hair cut?’ or ‘am i the best lover you’ve ever had?’ it can help if you expel the truth first. the poker face: although some people prefer to employ the poker face, many assume less is more and almost shut down in terms of movement and eye contact when they’re being economical with the truth. body language expert reveals nine ways to spot a liar there's nothing worse than having the wool pulled over your eyes, and when it happens you often wonder how someone managed to deceive you. for more information visit www.whodunnit.org.uk  macmillan cancer support’s new murder mystery fundraising game ‘whodunnit?’ takes place on saturday 25th march. when the gestures and the words are at odds it’s called incongruent gesticulation and it’s often the hands or feet that are telling the truth. experts will often use filmed footage that is then slowed down to pick up on the true body language response emerging in the middle of the performed lie. now body language expert judi james has revealed the key signs to look out for if you're concerned someone is being economical with the truth. heckling hands: the hardest body parts to act with are the hands or feet and liars often struggle to keep them on-message while they lie. self-comfort touches: the stress and discomfort of lying often produces gestures that are aimed at comforting the liar, such as rocking, hair-stroking or twiddling or playing with wedding rings. 'despite the fact there are no "one-size-fits-all" symptoms to spot, the following tips should help alert you to the fact that someone’s not being totally honest with you.' the mouth dries, the body sweats more, the pulse rate quickens and the rhythm of the breathing changes to shorter, shallower breaths that can often be both seen and heard. also, the guilt of a lie often makes people use an eye contact cut-off gesture, such as looking down or away. actors call this a ‘bit of business’ which is when less competent actors continue washing up or potting plants while being quizzed rather than struggling with their body language. first your brain produces the truth which it then has to suppress before inventing the lie and the performance of that lie. when we look up to our left to think we’re often accessing recalled memory, but when our eyes roll up to our right we can be thinking more creatively. the eye dart: humans have more eye expressions than any other animal and our eyes can give away if we’re trying to hide something. while she warns that there is 'no set formula' for spotting a liar, recognising some of the signs can help you root out a fibber. 'while i don’t usually condone lying, this is the perfect opportunity to try your hand at being economical with the truth,' she said. this often leads to a longer pause than normal before answering, plus a verbal stalling technique like ‘why do you ask that?’ rather than a direct and open response. overcompensating: a liar will often over-perform, both speaking and gesticulating too much in a bid to be more convincing. the best time to spot these in real life is to look for the facial expression that occurs after the liar has finished speaking. 'forget all those claims of "tells" and other body language giveaways that reveal when someone is being economical with the truth. convince yourself first: the brain likes to see the whole manufactured story which it can then perform using body language. keep busy: if you’re not very good at lying, try to keep busy when you perform the lie. relax: to combat the fight/flight response, breathe out slowly and deliberately to relax your muscles, especially the ones in your shoulders, arms and hands. micro-gestures: these are very small gestures or facial expressions that can flash across the face so quickly they are difficult to see. it might look rude but it can be better than over-sharing in terms of your body language giveaways! the lost breath: bending the truth causes an instant stress response in most people, meaning the fight or flight mechanisms are activated. visualisation is the nearest you’ll get to making the lie reality and that helps make your body language signals congruent. the face hide: when someone tells a lie they often suffer a strong desire to hide their face from their audience. judi james is supporting macmillan cancer support’s new murder mystery fundraising game whodunnit? we all tend to use self-comfort gestures but this will increase dramatically when someone is fibbing. this can lead to a partial cut-off gesture like the well-know nose touch or mouth-cover. gather your friends for an evening of bluffing, accusations and outrageous over-acting to help raise vital funds for people affected by cancer. the mouth might skew or the eyes roll in an instant give-away. these over the top body language rituals can involve too much eye contact (often without blinking!) the big pause: lying is quite a complex process for the body and brain to deal with. slow your own down a little, as this will help create reassurance in your audience. and says learning how to lie might help if you decide to take part. don’t just think of the transcript, visualise the whole story including all the smallest details. 'a bad liar might blush and sweat and show physical signs of agitation like fidgeting,' she explained. slow your blink rate: fibbing often causes a give-away accelerated blink rate. 'but a practised liar can easily deliver a lie while looking cool, calm and confident. for more information visit www.whodunnit.org.uk keep your vocal tone a little lower - lying can make us more shrill. and over-emphatic gesticulation. sip a cup of tea etc.

this is the best time to drink coffee here's when you should really be drinking your coffee many coffee drinkers probably reach for their morning cup of joe immediately after waking up, but this video from asapscience reveals that that's not really the best idea if you want to maximize your levels of energy and alertness. the video's narrator explains that 9 a.m. is probably the ideal time for most people to drink their coffee, because it's right after your body's peak cortisol production. the main factors at play are your body's circadian rhythm and the times when your body produces the hormone cortisol, which affects your level of alertness throughout the day.
the research firm symantec has been looking into the bangladesh bank heist, and on thursday it posted on its blog that a similar code used to steal bangladesh’s millions was also used to hack a bank in the philippines, as well as a failed attempt on a bank in vietnam last year. that group has also been tied to attacks as far back as 2009, which mainly focused on the u.s. and south korea, but it is also believed to be responsible for hacks on countries all over the world, such as the $12 million stolen from an ecuadoran bank last year. security investigators linked thefts from banks in asia, including the $81 million stolen from the central bank of bangladesh in february, to a hacking group in north korea. since investigators learned how hackers stole bangladesh’s money, banks that had kept similar heists quiet have come forward: just last week, it was revealed in a lawsuit that the banco del austro in ecuador was targeted, as well. pyongyang does not publish economic data, but estimates have put north korea’s gross domestic product between $12 billion and $40 billion, tiny when compared with south korea’s economic output of more than $1.4 trillion. the fbi has linked this group to the sony hacks, and those hacks to north korea. the code, symantec said, has also been linked to the 2014 hack of sony pictures’s emails. investigators say the malware the thieves used shared similarities to the code used by a hacking group known as lazarus. an expert quoted by the times said: "if you presume it’s north korea, $1 billion is almost 10 percent of their g.d.p. the system is run by the world’s largest banks, is based in brussels, and prides itself on security. the way hackers broke into the banks was by infiltrating the industry’s global messaging system, swift. the new york times adds: north korea’s economy has been ravaged by sanctions, food shortages and other deprivations. is north korea behind bank heists? this is not small change for them."
but look a little closer on those same filings and you can see that nearly all of those donations have been cycled back to telemarketers, leaving less than 2 percent for actual veterans and veterans' charitable causes. 'worst' charity for veterans run by va employee story highlights the national vietnam veterans foundation raised nearly $9 million in 2014 but it donated less than 2% of that money washington (cnn) at first glance, the national vietnam veterans foundation is a roaring success. that's why charity navigator, one of the nation's largest and most influential charity watchdog organizations, has given the charity a "zero" out of four stars for those same four years. the charity's most recently filed tax return, for 2014, lists a catalogue of expenses paid for by donations: including $133,000 for travel, $21,000 for unnamed "awards", $70,000 for a category described as "other expenses" and even a little more than $8,000 for parking. according to its tax filings, the charity has received more than $29 million in donations from generous americans from 2010 to 2014 for what it calls on its website "aiding, supporting and benefiting america's veterans and their families." "they don't have an independent board of directors, they actually don't even have a comprehensive board of directors -- only three members on the board at this point in time and some of them are family. "it's a zero-star organization and you can't go lower than that," says michael thatcher, charity navigator's ceo. so one can say, is this representative of an independent board? it's not."

dmx arrested again nov 5 - rapper dmx, whose real name is earl simmons, was arrested outside a south carolina airport on monday for driving with a suspended license and without a vehicle tag and insurance, according to the spartanburg county detention center. he was arrested in south carolina in august and charged with possession of marijuana two days before he was due in court on a drunk driving charge. airport police familiar with simmons and his lengthy arrest history stopped him as he was driving to the greenville-spartanburg international airport early on monday evening, a police dispatcher said. the 42-year-old entertainer spent several hours in jail before posting a $1,335 bond on the charges, according to spartanburg county detention center. the new york-born rapper, who lives in south carolina, was arrested when he did not have a valid license, the dispatcher said. "he was arrested on minor traffic charges and spent only three hours in jail," said domenick nati, a spokesman for the rapper. he was arrested in july on suspicion of driving under the influence and failing to have a valid driver's license. the rapper, whose albums include "it's dark and hell is hot" and "flesh of my flesh, blood of my blood," also starred in the movies "romeo must die" and "cradle 2 the grave." simmons' arrest record also includes charges of animal cruelty, reckless driving, drug possession and probation violations. simmons has had numerous run-ins with police in south carolina and elsewhere. he has had several felony convictions and has served prison time in arizona. nati said simmons still planned to perform on wednesday. "this short arrest will not affect any of his upcoming concerts." he was booked at 6:27 p.m. local time.

a recent study by the centers for disease control and prevention (cdc) and vanderbilt university medical center found that getting a flu shot reduced the risk of flu-related hospitalization by 71.4 percent for all adults and 76.8 percent for those over age 50 during the 2011-2012 flu season. they include: a standard dose for adults and children, a high-dose shot for people over age 65, a nasal spray for those who don't like needles, and a dose that is egg-free for patients who are allergic. as an added bonus, a new study published in the journal of the american medical association found that up to 36 percent of those vaccinated reduced their risk of heart attack, stroke, or other cardiovascular health problems just by getting a flu shot. what's new this year, says dr. michael jhung, medical officer at the cdc, is that many flu shots will immunize against four strains of the flu virus for the first time, an improved protection over years past. to figure out why some choose to work overtime even when they know it's not good for health, the researchers turned to a mathematical analysis called becker's theory of the allocation of time, which helps to measure the cost of time. bad news for workaholics if you're addicted to checking your email and regularly work through evenings, weekends and vacations, you might be a workaholic -- and your health may be suffering because of it. "we found workaholics -- defined by those working more than 50 hours per week -- were more likely to have reduced physical well-being, measured by skipped meals," doctoral researcher, sarah asebedo, said in a statement. a number of studies have shown the detrimental toll that work stress in particular can take on your health, including depression and an increased risk of heart attack and diabetes. but turning on that out-of-office autoreply and taking some time to rest and recharge can actually have a positive effect on not just your well-being, but also your productivity. even if you understand the negative consequences to workaholism, you may still be likely to continue working because the cost of not doing so becomes greater." "[becker's theory] looks at the cost of time as if it were a market good," asebedo said in the statement. more than eight in 10 americans are stressed about their jobs -- citing an unreasonable workload as their number-one stressor -- and 61 percent of employed vacationers will work through their vacation this year (up from 52 percent last year). "also, we found that workaholism was associated with reduced mental well-being as measured by a self-reported depression score." the kansas state university study, which will be published in the journal financial planning review, found that well-being is generally not a priority for workaholics. and with the possibility to work from anywhere, at anytime, it's easier than ever to become a workaholic in the first place. if you are not engaged in work-related activities, then there is a cost to the alternative way in which time is spent. "this theory suggests that the more money you make, the more likely you are to work more. "renewal is a way in which to increase your capacity to be more effective." the theory highlights the paradox that working overtime leads to more income, but less time to spend this income. of course, it's no secret that overworking can have a negative effect on your health and happiness. and workaholism in particular has been associated with poor sleep quality, weight gain, high blood pressure, depression and anxiety, not to mention unhappy marriages and higher divorce rates. it also suggests that as income increases, workers are more likely to develop unhealthy habits around working excessively. recent research has found a link between workaholism and reduced physical and mental well-being. the findings are based on data from the 1979 cohort of the national longitudinal survey of youth that included 12,686 young men and women. all the study participants were interviewed each year until 1994, and are still interviewed biennially. "renewal is not for slackers," tony schwartz, ceo of the energy project, told the huffington post. even a short nap can boost cognitive functioning, improving creative thinking, learning and memory.

mashable reports that nasa tracks more than 500,000 pieces of defunct satellites and old rocket bits orbiting earth, some no larger than marbles, so that the space station can be maneuvered away from close encounters — but many small pieces, like the one that hit the space station, are too difficult to keep track of. [nasa reminds us that astronaut poop burns up ‘like shooting stars’] but that’s exactly what happened last month in the space station’s cupola, a european-built 2010 addition that you’re sure to recognize — it’s where those great pictures and videos showing stunning shots of our planet are taken. because of the incredibly high speeds of these orbiting pieces of debris, something 1 centimeter across could disable critical instruments on the space station, and anything larger could penetrate the sturdy shields that protect crew modules. these days space agencies try to be more mindful of the waste left behind by missions, but no one has found an ideal solution for cleaning up the junk that’s already there. the danger posed by errant space debris were dramatized in the 2013 film "gravity," in which astronauts on a shuttle mission are terrorized by speeding chunks of space junk. according to the european space agency, the damage was likely caused by something as unassuming as a flake of paint or a metal fragment just a few thousandths of a millimeter across. and you almost certainly don’t want to imagine a piece of that junk taking a chunk of your spacecraft’s window with it. "i am often asked if the international space station is hit by space debris," british astronaut tim peake, who took the freaky photo of the damaged window, said in a statement. that’s just one piece of a much bigger problem the hole in the space station is superficial but a little unsettling for earthbound folk. especially not when the chipped window in question is the one that provides some of the best views of earth. and the views are safe, too — the chip is less than a centimeter across. "yes — this is the chip in one of our cupola windows, glad it is quadruple glazed!" (esa/nasa) when you sit around imagining life aboard the international space station (we all do that, right?) one thing you probably don’t want to think about is space junk slamming into your vessel. (youtube/nasa) the astronauts, of course, are perfectly safe — they generally don’t tweet photos during life-threatening station crises. in 2013, experts estimated that there were at least 29,000 objects of this size orbiting earth. a bit of debris chipped the international space station. debris 10 centimeters across could shatter the spacecraft into pieces. nasa released an animation depicting space trash in motion around earth. a flake of paint. space junk is definitely a real concern. you can say that again. let that sink in. um, yeah.

‘our job from now until the convention is to convince those superdelegates that bernie is by far the strongest candidate against donald trump’ sanders has a long road ahead of him if he hopes to convince the party’s super delegates to back him over clinton, as many of them have been strong supporters of her campaign since she first announced her candidacy. a spokesman for the sanders campaign, briggs, has said that the senator is planning on heading back to vermont on wednesday, but will be back on the campaign trail by thursday when he will head to washington, dc. the reports indicate that at least half of his staff will be laid off in the wake of clinton’s victories in new jersey and california, though some of them might be offered jobs in sanders’ senate office. a lot of the staff members who are being laid off are advance staff who often help with the logistics of setting up a campaign, but a lot of the field staff, who often handle phone calls and door to door campaigning, are being laid off as well. clinton, who has been declared the party’s nominee by many in the media, such as the ap, does have the support of more than 500 super delegates, which is what puts her over the top. bernie sanders makes major announcement to his entire staff and followers (quotes) sources close to the sanders campaign have reported that the vermont senator will begin laying off a large part of his staff starting wednesday. despite the layoffs, sanders is not ending his campaign and is hoping to be able to sway the super delegates to his side. the reports of the layoff came after clinton’s victory on tuesday where she won the majority of delegates in california and new jersey. it is important to note that despite clinton’s strong lead, she does not have enough pledged delegates to earn the nomination. a spokesman for the campaign, micheal briggs, reiterated this plan during a statement at a sanders rally that was held on monday in san francisco. whether or not sanders can persuade the party’s leadership to back him remains to be seen, but it is a long shot. the super delegates will not vote until the democratic national convention, which will be held the last week of july. it is an argument that sanders has made throughout this primary season and it’s one that the poll numbers back up. sanders is planning on holding several rallies in washington dc, which holds the last primary on june 14th. sanders will argue that he is the strongest candidate to face donald trump in november. the clintons have enjoyed strong support among the democratic party since bill clinton’s election in 1992. the majority of polls have sanders defeating trump by a larger margin than clinton does. there are 158 pledged delegates still available and 2,383 are studies have found that where we perceive bacteria thriving in bathrooms can be completely backwards, and what we use to keep us clean could actually be spreading the problem around! we have no idea who has been in there before us, and sometimes, we just can’t help but feel wary of public toilets, considering all of the crazy things that have been found in them. if the toilet doesn’t have a lid, remember that bacteria thrives in warm, wet places, so keep any surface dry, including your hands, your body, and any of the bathroom appliances. the powerful buffeting of dryers propels germs around the room and onto your hands, which can grow and increase, especially if you don’t dry them completely! when these feelings of insecurity strike, we usually reach for the nearest available seat cover and — if one isn’t available — we then make one of our own out of toilet paper. despite this, many people opt to line the seat with toilet paper — but really, this seemingly clean practice may actually be increasing your exposure to germs. as long as you remain aware of where bacteria is actually present, you can make smart decisions toward remaining healthy, happy, and free of more germs than are necessary! in fact, a study from the the journal of applied microbiology found that hand dryers were among the largest distributors of bacteria, other than flushing toilets. with every flush, germs are sprayed up and out of the toilet — and often exposed right onto the toilet paper. according to today.com, germs are not easily spreadable on toilet seats, since many different bacteria and viruses don’t survive long outside of a human body. read below to learn how bacteria is spread in all bathrooms, and what steps we should be taking to keep scary bathroom germs at bay! washing your hands is extremely important after you use the restroom, but drying them thoroughly and disposing of your paper towels is just as important. our skin does a great job of blocking bacteria, so trust in its ability to do its job when sitting on a dry toilet seat. but toilet seats are actually designed to keep as much bacteria off of you as possible. but toilet paper isn’t the only place where germs dwell more happily than toilet seats. though they are definitely more environmentally friendly, these dryers actually spread more germs than ordinary paper towels. there is a general misconception that covering toilet seats keeps you safe from germs. so what’s the best way to ensure you’re not spreading or picking up germs? but in truth, creating this protective paper barrier could be doing you way more harm than good. their special shape and material were specifically designed to prevent bacteria from dwelling on their surface for very long. sometimes, public bathrooms are a necessary evil, especially during long car rides or when nature calls inconveniently. toilet paper, unlike toilet seats, are not designed to ward off bacteria. you should never line the toilet seat with paper. though most are pretty pristine, every once in a while, we run into some truly unsavory public bathroom situations. closing the toilet seat lid before flushing! this lifehack may seem like a perfectly harmless, even safe, practice. in fact, they’re sponges for it. the reason? shocking!

assume higher nonwhite support for the democrat—let’s say a three-point bump among blacks and a seven-point bump among hispanics, giving clinton 97 percent and 80 percent support, respectively—and trump needs 66 percent of whites to win both the popular and electoral-college vote, if turnout doesn’t change. if trump could reverse the yearslong decline and bring white turnout back to its 2008 levels—74 percent—then he could win with another couple percentage points among whites, even with the high black and latino turnout of 2008. there’s still a strong case to make that donald trump is a long shot for the white house—that he’s too unpopular with too many americans outside the republican party and that if the obama coalition holds, he loses. given two unpopular candidates, it’s possible that "popularity" just won’t matter as much, that voters will take both candidates’ worst qualities as a given and move on. ok, ok. "possible" doesn’t mean "likely," and it’s hard to imagine a disorganized campaign exceeding team romney’s ability to pinpoint and bring republican-leaning white voters to the polls. it’s why the "never trump" movement fell apart after ted cruz left the race; a serious effort to derail the republican nominee would guarantee a democratic white house, because it’s almost impossible to overcome the asymmetry. of five separate econometric models of the election, four predict a republican win ranging from 50.9 percent of the vote to 55 percent of the two-party vote. it’s hard to isolate a single cause for kennedy’s victory, but he was almost certainly helped along by the modest recession that struck in the spring and lasted until the following winter. in the still unlikely event that the present acrimony between bernie sanders and the democratic party becomes an outright split, democrats risk throwing the election to trump, through in-fighting and division. a terrorist attack could do it—driving voters into the arms of the authoritarian in the race—but the literature is mixed on how terrorism affects voters. with all this said, even the most probable scenario here—that trump and clinton become generic candidates—is a distant long shot. partisanship has a tight hold on american voting behavior, and it’s hard to imagine how trump could break it, barring a national catastrophe. in fact, the very presence of trump—his proximity to the most powerful office in the world—could destabilize markets and make a downturn more likely. the economy is middling, president obama well-liked but not hugely popular, and clinton would be a third term for democrats. and their personal qualities mix with the fundamentals of this election—partisanship, demographics, and economic performance—to create favorable terrain for democrats. it’s a heavy lift, especially for a candidate who says he will eschew data-gathering and other quantitative methods for finding and mobilizing supporters. at the opening of the 1960 election, in early spring of that year, john f. kennedy and richard nixon were neck and neck. clinton’s biggest weakness in the nbc news survey of registered voters is with sanders’ backers who haven’t crossed the threshold to team clinton. they’re just too well-known for voters to treat them as interchangeable with any republican or any democrat. this would give him teetering democratic states such as new hampshire, pennsylvania, and wisconsin, as well as the three largest swing states: florida, ohio, and virginia. let’s say you don’t trust the models (they couldn’t predict trump, after all). if not for that downturn, there’s a fair chance nixon would have become president. it’s an extraordinary reach: an increase of nearly six points over the white share in 2012, matching ronald reagan’s performance in 1984. there’s one last thing that could deliver the white house to trump: a divided democratic party. the answer is easy: he wins and turns out white voters in historic numbers. trump is deeply unpopular with black and latino voters, as well as with women and young people. if sanders runs as a third-party candidate, the game is over, and democrats lose. he’s made real ground on hillary clinton, closing the gap between them by consolidating the republican party behind his candidacy. it would mean trump persuaded millions of democrats to switch teams, despite their wide approval for president obama. that trump is a poor bet for november doesn’t mean he couldn’t win. it could make them more attuned to perceived outsiders—and immigrants in particular—giving trump an advantage. given two generic candidates under those criteria, the presidency would go to the republican. still, with a smile from fortuna (or whichever god of chance you prefer), trump can win. and what are the prospects this year for a generic republican nominee? how would trump win, assuming key parts of the electorate are aligned against him? in which case, both clinton and trump become generic nominees. and consider this: on average, the united states sees a recession every five years. joe raedle/getty images at this moment, polls show a strong upswing for donald trump’s campaign. you just need to reverse-engineer the conditions of a trump loss. if anything guarantees defeat for an incumbent party, it’s a recession. but humility is a virtue, and life is volatile, even if elections often aren’t. or given the candidates, it could be a wash. clinton, meanwhile, is fighting a contentious primary, which keeps her from doing the same. one is all we need for president trump. he turns out white voters in historic numbers. but by october, kennedy had opened a small but persistent lead. a sudden slowdown could have the same effect on our election. it could push them toward hawkish candidates with traditional credentials, helping clinton. you see this in the most recent polling. and finding an answer here isn’t too difficult. (you can play with the numbers over at realclearpolitics.) if history is any indication, however, it won’t be. which raises an obvious question: how would it happen? this continued into the summer and the early fall. at the top of the list is demographics. easier to imagine is higher white turnout. but clinton is also unpopular, albeit by a smaller magnitude. in other words, it’s not happening. if this persists, it’s dangerous. party unity is a prerequisite for national competition. at least, that’s what i think. what are those conditions? say hello to president trump. but it’s possible. so let’s table this one. how trump could win. jamelle bouie jamelle bouie is slate’s chief political correspondent. then what? he could. he won. we’re due.
though ratu’s baby is a great moment of hope for the sumatran rhinos, the population is still threatened by its two biggest foes: poaching and loss of habitat. ratu, a rhino that lives at the sumatran rhino sanctuary in indonesia, is now mother to a little miracle. a very special baby was just born in indonesia, and people still can’t believe he’s real. with only 100 left in the world, these beautiful creatures are seriously on the brink of going extinct. the beautiful sumatran rhinos are one of the most endangered animals on the planet. once she had her son, though, she calmed down and became a very attentive mother. and when you see what it is, you won’t want to take your eyes off it for a second! her son, andatu, was born in 2012, the second sumatran rhino born in indonesia in 128 years! according to irf executive director dr. susie ellis, sumatran rhinos are one of the fasted declining species on the planet. in fact, ratu’s baby boy has now increased the sumatran rhino population by an entire 1%. it may seem hard to believe, but this is how crucial she is to her species’ survival. mama ratu once had a reputation as the feistiest, most difficult-to-handle rhino at the sanctuary. once you see this cute little face, you want to shower him with attention and love, too! ratu delivered her son on a rainy day, and boy, is she a welcome sight! they were just declared extinct in the wild in malaysia, and now exist only in indonesia. but the international rhino foundation recently announced a new breakthrough for this troubled species. let’s hope these beautiful creatures have a bright future ahead of them!
they’re also fed up with what they see as a new militancy among the undocumented immigrants of today—particularly young dream’ers who were brought here as children and seem to understand everything voters, we’ve caught a glimpse of a similar phenomenon—one that few could have imagined when donald trump entered the race for the republican presidential nomination. while generally more appreciative than other americans of immigration, respectful of the contributions of legal and illegal immigrants, and supportive of a comprehensive reform plan that provides the undocumented with a path to earned legal status, many latinos are also ambivalent about illegal immigration—especially if they, or their ancestors, came legally. finally, while many in washington will often try to compare latinos with african-americans as another aggrieved minority that has endured everything from inferior schools to overt discrimination to economic inequality, there is a competing line of thought that suggests latinos are more comparable to other catholic immigrant groups, like the irish and italians. in states like nevada, colorado, texas, utah, and others, far away from the nation’s power triangle (new they might not agree with his proposed solutions, but they’re not going to hold against him the fact that he’s brave enough to start the discussion. in fact, trump would often point to early polling from nevada that showed him beating his rivals decisively with hispanics, which is what happened. according to cnn entrance polls, among latino republican voters in the silver state, john kasich got 4 percent, ted cruz 18 percent, and marco rubio 29 percent. besides, we are talking about just latino republicans who went to vote on a given day in the state of nevada. the 54 million latinos in the united states—whose ancestors can be traced to more than a dozen countries—could yield an estimated 13 million voters in november. i can only think of two people who don’t seem surprised by trump’s strong showing with latinos. it’s the same party that has won the majority of latino votes in every presidential election since 1960: the democratic party. two weeks ago, i wrote a piece for this site "consistent with its historical focus on text-based journalism, the board will continue to place emphasis on the enduring value of words and of serious reporting," the press release read, "while also recognizing the opportunity provided by the web for integration of text with audio and visual elements to strengthen story-telling and provide information and analysis." while websites operated by broadcast news organizations remain ineligible, and the prize continues to be primarily focused on text, the pulitzer prize board acknowledges that the web has provided new and compelling ways for journalists to integrate the written word with multimedia content. pulitzer prize makes major change the pulitzer prize has broadened eligibility in feature writing and investigative reporting to include online and print magazines, the pulitzer prize board announced in a press release on monday. "he envisioned that future generations would make changes in the plan of award for the prizes that are 'conducive to the public good or rendered advisable by public necessities, or by reason of change of time.' but as an increasing number of americans turn to digital media for their daily news, and many print magazines publish weekly and operate their own websites, the decision to broaden the spectrum makes sense. in the past, publications that identified as magazines, either in print or online, were not allowed to compete for a pulitzer in any category. "pulitzer’s aim was the progress and elevation of journalism," pulitzer prize administrator mike pride said in a statement. increasingly, online and print magazines have expanded their mission. it’s time to enlarge the tent again."

a paper published in thejournal puts forward the theory that a massive asteroid did indeed strike the earth, but that its devastating effects were different than commonly thought, reports researchers – from japan’s meteorological research institute and tohuku univeristy – now believe the asteroid struck the yucatan peninsula in mexico, hitting massive oil deposits and sending a blanket of thick black smoke into the atmosphere, engulfing the planet. scientific reports journal puts forward the theory that a massive asteroid did indeed strike the earth, but that its devastating effects were different than commonly thought, reports the independent. it is thought that only 12 per cent of life on land lived through the aftermath of the asteroid impact, whereas 90 per cent of freshwater species managed to survive. the amount of sunlight fell by a huge 85 per cent, causing the earth to cool by as much as 16 degrees celsius on land for about three years. the accepted theory was that the impact caused vapours of sulphuric acid in the sky, which reflected sunlight, leading to global darkness, near-freezing conditions and widespread acid rain. however, the team from tohuku said: if this had occurred, crocodilians and various other animals would have also gone extinct. the researchers wrote: small mammals and reptiles could have lived underground where it is warmer – dinosaurs did not. scientists now know what really wiped out dinosaurs wikipedia a new study has provided an updated theory about how the dinosaurs were wiped out 66 million years ago. also, rainfall would have fallen by roughly 80 per cent causing extreme and devastating droughts. wikimedia experts had previously wondered why dinosaurs had died out while other reptiles – like the ancestors of crocodiles – had survived. these different habitats would have been key factors in determining their extinction or survival. dark times. literally.

syda productions/shutterstock though there don't appear to have been any recent developments on this issue, the internet – largely led by english tabloids – has decided that it's time to remind us all about a 2010 study by scientists from copenhagen university hospital, which found evidence that drinking too much soda can reduce a man’s sperm count by as much as thirty percent. for instance, back in the 1980s, researchers added a variety of coca-cola products to sperm in an attempt to see if it reduced their swimming ability, but ultimately did not find enough evidence to support this. a number of other studies have in the past attempted to find a connection between excessive soda drinking and poor sexual health in men, though most have found no concrete proof of any link. how these popular drinks produce this plunge in sperm numbers is not known, although the researchers have ruled out caffeine as the cause, after finding no connection between caffeine in other drinks and sperm count. though this is not actually considered to be below the healthy limit, it is pretty far short of the 56 million sperm per liter that non-soda addicts were found to have swimming around their testes. according to this study, drinking fizzy drinks can have a disturbing effect on your penis drinking too much of the black stuff could leave you with not enough of the white stuff. as such, they conclude that there is a high probability of a connection between soft drinks and soft penises, though they can’t confirm this without conducting a long-term study. for instance, they explain that high sugar intake could cause some of the blood vessels in the penis to become clogged up with fat, impeding blood flow and making it harder to get an erection. exactly why this has suddenly become so widely talked about is a bit of a mystery, since as far as we are aware there is no new research to speak of. after examining the potency of 2,500 men, the researchers discovered that those who identified as cola addicts had an average sperm count of 35 million per liter. however, the findings of the study are worth bearing in mind if you happen to be a lover of the self-appointed "real thing" (and a man). more recently, researchers published a report in which they listed several reasons why drinking too much soda could potentially cause erectile dysfunction.

christ": according to the data, in the last year worldwide, looking at only original tweets (no retweets, no replies), "jesus christ" had 3,936,585 mentions, while "kanye west" had 4,541,349 mentions. that being said, the idiomatic jesus christ doesn't directly refer to the person jesus christ, while kanye west refers to the person kanye in almost all cases, so if we're looking for an portion of the examined mentions. we looked at a sample of the hundred most recent tweets for "jesus christ" on twitter using the twitter search and found that 73 percent of uses of "jesus christ" were idiomatic, leaving 27 percent literal. there are a lot terms twitter users use to reference jesus: there's the broad "jesus," which includes other people named jesus, the more specific "jesus christ" and foreign language versions -- jesucristo in spanish, gesù cristo in italian. kanye has an advantage with foreign language tweets, because countries with the latin derived alphabets, as far 2,224,895, but they were about equal when the day-to-day totals received consideration. usage of the exclamatory "jesus christ" is probably more popular among those who are at least exposed to christianity, so it may still be a good signal for jesus's popularity among the twitterati. so, it looks like jesus is "the most high" on twitter -- except for justin bieber, who trumps jesus in popularity with 68,257,710 tweets for the search term "bieber" during the same period. kanye's numbers were skewed by a few high mention days and his median tweets/day (9,981) were, in fact, lower than jesus's median tweets/day (10,458). with kanye bringing a jesus lookalike on stage during his current tour, the huffington post decided now is a good time to compare the relative places of kanye and jesus in the popular zeitgeist. since jesus doesn't have a genuine twitter account, and kanye has a habit of deleting all of his tweets, using @ mentions didn't seem that promising or fair. when "we speculate that the blunted response to repeated acts of dishonesty may reflect a reduction in the emotional response to these decisions or to their affective assessment and saliency," the paper reads. a recent study proves that cheating is not a one-time thing, and that person will probably cheat on you again. when a person engages in dishonesty purely for the benefit of another it may be perceived as morally acceptable. it further stated that the brain rationalises with the cheating ways, and feels less guilty, responsible when caught. because some people just love to cheat and it can happen for multiple reasons - they found a better match, they just weren't loyal, the opportunity of something different, emotional incompatibility, intimacy, etc. we all remember happy faces, exhilaration, and sheer elation when two folks mutually get into a relationship, but half of them get thrown in predicament, simply because of infinitely. each time a person is caught cheating, the response to their wrongdoing is reduced. it's a region that's associated with emotions and plays "a key role in signalling, processing and assessing arousal." the study focused on the part of the brain called amygdala, which is the supplier of negative responses. gliding in a pool of despair will drag them further into it, making it harder to cope. in all this, the person on the receiving end should always be open-minded -- open to options, positivity, optimism. the venerable saying is backed in this journal titled "the brain adapts to dishonesty". "when participants were dishonest for the benefit of someone else, dishonesty at a constant rate was observed," the study says. but let's keep the mental rationale aside and see what science has to say about it. we’ve all heard the same, tired cliche about infidelity: "once a cheater, always a cheater." this absolute favourite thing in the world apart from murders or robbery is as evil as any other violation. but sadly, despite cheating, most cheaters feel belaboured when caught. it further responds to an individual when they lie. and now science is backing it. so, don't be a cheat. because, science cheating sucks! why do you ask? how convenient, right?

he has knocked fruit juices, full of added sugar and fructose on the head, as well as alcohol. he then moves onto five three minute rounds on the pads, and once that is completed, steps it up to three, three minute rounds on a heavy bag. so, unfortunately, you're not going to get as stacked as the transporter star while chugging lagers every other day of the week, and then ending the night with a sweaty kebab. of the exercises, bodybuilding.com says they include barbell front raises, dumbbell burpees, farmer's walk, pull-ups, bear crawl sled drag, close-grip pull downs, front squats, hanging knee raises, weighted step ups, and one-arm cable rows. if you eat carbs later in the day, it's harder to work off - if needs be, have them in the morning and your daily activities should work off the calories. "i'm certainly no vegan, but there's this little place down on sunset that i'll go to, the california vegan, and they do a really good steamed vegetable and brown rice," he said. credit: universal pictures well, the 49-year-old, who has studied wing chun, kung fu, karate, and kickboxing, applies himself to a strict diet, as well as a strict workout regime. he goes on to say that the latest you should ever have your evening meal is 7pm, and it should be high in protein. the times are then turned into targets so they can be used to increase the intensity of the workout as fitness levels increase. this will include the likes of front squats, dead-lifts, exercises carrying kettle bells, sandbags or dumbbells, a variety of explosive medicine ball exercises, and circuit training. statham's high intensity boxing workout begins with shadow boxing, working the back and shoulder, with lunges and some quad, groin, and hamstring stretching in between to work the legs. the time taken to complete the five circuits is recorded, and is how the level of intensity is measured. and by strict, i mean fucking strict; this is jason statham we're talking about, he's a no nonsense kind of bloke. therefore, it is vital to a successful plan to record all lifts and times so that intensities can be calculated." in an interview with men's health, the star revealed that for breakfast he goes for either granola, fresh fruits and oats, porridge, or poached eggs. all of that, grouped with his many action roles, most of which he performs his own stunts for, have required him to stay in great shape. he told bodybuilding.com that following this warm-up, he does another 10 minutes of medium intensity exercises. for lunch, he says in the interview to broaden your horizons, but fair warning, it's not going to sound too appealing. the workout is then finished off with three rounds on the speed bag and a warm down. growing up, statham was a typically sporty lad, and was actually introduced to football by none other than vinnie jones, his childhood friend, who'd he later act alongside. the martial arts expert believes in never repeating the same workout as he feels you see more results from varying your exercises. statham only eats 'good food', saying 95% of what he eats is clean - the other 5% being small treats every now and again. he went on to be a part of britain's national diving squad for 12 years, and even represented england at the 1990 commonwealth games. 2) "take notes of everything - as you progress through the workouts, it is inevitable that you will get fitter,
