a review of census bureau industry composition data shows that people in most of the states with a higher median income were often more likely to be employed in information, finance, professional and other positions that tend to pay higher salaries. to identify the states with the highest and lowest median household income, 24/7 wall st. reviewed state data on income from the u.s. census bureau’s 2012 american community survey (acs). and the richest state in the country is... from 24/7 wall st. last year, household income remained effectively unchanged, according to data released this week by the u.s. census bureau. according to the bureau of labor statistics, while 8.1% of american workers were unemployed in 2012, 14.7% were underemployed, meaning they wanted to work full time but could not. in many of the highest-income states, like new hampshire, minnesota and hawaii, unemployment in 2012 was less than 6%, compared to a national rate of 8.1%. the high proportion of manufacturing jobs in low-income states might be surprising, but, explained danziger, the makeup of the manufacturing industry in the country has changed. we also reviewed unemployment data provided by the bureau of labor statistics for 2012, as well as 2012 acs data on health insurance coverage, employment and poverty. elise gould, director of health policy for economic policy institute, explained that unemployment rates can have a significant effect on a state’s household income. all of the 10 states with the lowest median income in 2012 also had among the highest poverty rates in the country. at the same time, many of the low-income states had smaller percentages of these professional occupations and higher rates of employment in retail, manufacturing and transportation. despite the addition of jobs nationwide, median incomes remained stagnant in most states and were still generally below their 2008 levels, adjusted for inflation. maryland, the wealthiest state in the country, had the highest percentage of workers in professional, scientific and management positions. states with lower median incomes generally had much higher rates of poverty than the national rate. in 2012, maryland remained the richest state in the country, with a median household income of $71,221. in some states with lower unemployment, a higher share of the households had steady income, which bolsters the state’s median. while the economy continues to struggle, residents in the wealthiest states continue to make far more than in the poorest. "the big story is that everything was stagnant over the year" said economic policy institute’s elise gould. "we have an economy that continues to grow, with most of the gains going to the economic elite. this is despite the fact that the u.s. added nearly 2.2 million jobs in 2012. mississippi was again the poorest, with an income of $37,095 — nearly half that of maryland’s. based on census treatment, median household income for all years is adjusted for inflation. while 15.9% of americans fell below the poverty line in 2012, nearly one in four mississippians did. "when we’re talking about average families and poor families, the vast majority of income comes from wages. here are america's richest states, according to 24/7 wall st. sheldon danziger, president of the russell sage foundation, explained that this has been the nature of the recovery. i don’t see any bright prospects for the median worker, much less the poor." unemployment rates, for example, ignore those people who have given up looking for work or accept part-time work. "we’re stagnant, and continue to be in a bad place." "even when manufacturers haven’t cut wages, they are adopting labor-saving technological change." gould cautioned, however, that unemployment rates do not tell the full story. the types of jobs available in each state also affect income. "there’s a difference between unionized auto company workers and non-unionized parts suppliers," danziger said. this was an increase from roughly 10% in 2008. employment is one of the biggest factors affecting income. so it’s about jobs."
-walt disney, neal gabler because disney's job -- storytelling and managing a company -- involved constantly refocusing the brain, and because he was something of a perfectionist, being aimless for a period of time meant he happily stopped caring about work -- and gained the power to continue forging onward. because disney's job -- storytelling and managing a company -- involved constantly refocusing the brain, and because he was something of a perfectionist, being aimless for a period of time meant he happily stopped caring about work -- and gained the power to continue forging onward. when disney was emotionally broken down by the business of entertainment, upon insistence by his brother and colleagues, he reluctantly went on vacation despite all his problems at the studio: walt said that he and lillian had the "time of our life" because he had reached the point where "i didn't give a darn." i've tried numerous techniques to counter this challenge: coffee (especially when mcdonald's was giving away free smalls) splashing cold water on my face wandering around online snacking yet i've found one technique to be the most effective: going for a walk. on days i don't take it, i feel like i'm doing my employer or client an injustice -- because i can't give them my brain's full output that they deserve. not because i don't like what i'm doing, but because my brain is just fried and i'm hitting the afternoon hump. this might be the most energizing afternoon routine (it's not more coffee) every day at around 3 p.m., my brain gets weary. even recently, when the temperature dropped down to -30 celsius, i bundled up and wandered outside -- and into toronto's underground tunnel system. the longest stroll i've taken is around 10 minutes, and i just wander around the block. i recently read neal gabler's biography of walt disney. i pass by the open hotel lobby that's air-conditioned in the summer and heated in the winter. he felt he had been liberated from the burden of his own perfectionism. by the students on their way to and from art school. i've even run into friends around the block. by storeowners, by late lunchers, by buildings under construction and their builders, by many things. i look forward to this break every day.
boy dies after playing new 'game' all the kids are playing a little boy is dead and a family is heartbroken due to a terrifying game. known as 'the choking game,' kids are challenging each other to try and cut off their own airway to experience euphoria. garrett pope, sr. spoke to the principal of his late son's school to warn staff to be aware. they want parents to talk to their kids about these kinds of stunts and challenges that can be so dangerous. garrett pope, an 11-year-old sixth-grader from indian land, accidentally killed himself in an attempt to play the game. his family feel obligated to get garrett's story out there to warn others. they're not sure of where garrett jr. heard about the game. there's no history of it in their internet searches. no foul play is suspected, nor do authorities believe the young man deliberately took his life. an investigation ruled garret's death an accident in a game gone wrong. the game involved cutting off his airway. his family says 'he just took this 'game' too far.' "people need to know about this," said mr. pope. "it’s not a 'game.' unfortunately, not all kids survive it. we need to speak up." it's senseless.
everyone wants to live a carefree, happy and easy life, to fall in love and have amazing sex and relationships, to look perfect and make money and be popular and well-respected and admired and a total baller to the point that people part like the red sea when you walk into the room. but you don’t end up with one unless you legitimately appreciate the pain and physical stress that comes with living inside a gym for hour upon hour, unless you love calculating and calibrating the food you eat, planning your life out in tiny plate-sized portions. but you don’t end up a successful entrepreneur unless you find a way to appreciate the risk, the uncertainty, the repeated failures, and working insane hours on something you have no idea whether will be successful or not. i was in love with the result—the image of me on stage, people cheering, me rocking out, pouring my heart into what i’m playing—but i wasn’t in love with the process. if you find yourself wanting something month after month, year after year, yet nothing happens and you never come any closer to it, then maybe what you actually want is a fantasy, an idealization, an image and a false promise. and you say something like, "i want to be happy and have a great family and a job i like," it’s so ubiquitous that it doesn’t even mean anything. everybody wants to have great sex and an awesome relationship—but not everyone is willing to go through the tough conversations, the awkward silences, the hurt feelings and the emotional psychodrama to get there. therefore, what we get out of life is not determined by the good feelings we desire but by what bad feelings we’re willing and able to sustain to get us to those good feelings. everybody wants to have an amazing job and financial independence—but not everyone wants to suffer through 60-hour work weeks, long commutes, obnoxious paperwork, to navigate arbitrary corporate hierarchies and the blasé confines of an infinite cubicle hell. but you don’t end up attracting someone amazing without appreciating the emotional turbulence that comes with weathering rejections, building the sexual tension that never gets released, and staring blankly at a phone that never rings. any badass guitar song i heard, i would always close my eyes and envision myself up on stage playing it to the screams of the crowd, people absolutely losing their minds to my sweet finger-noodling. the daily drudgery of practicing, the logistics of finding a group and rehearsing, the pain of finding gigs and actually getting people to show up and give a shit. but even then it was never a question of if i’d ever be up playing in front of screaming crowds, but when. and it took me a long time and a lot of negative experiences to finally figure out why: i didn’t actually want it. a more interesting question, a question that perhaps you’ve never considered before, is what pain do you want in your life? the quality of your life is not determined by the quality of your positive experiences but the quality of your negative experiences. i was biding my time before i could invest the proper amount of time and effort into getting out there and making it work. people who enjoy the stresses and uncertainty of the starving artist lifestyle are ultimately the ones who live it and make it. but the truth is far less interesting than that: i thought i wanted something, but it turns out i didn’t. and what it took me a long time to discover is that i didn’t like to climb much. if you want the yacht, you have to also want the late nights, the risky business moves, and the possibility of pissing off a person or ten thousand. the entrepreneurial/start-up crowd would tell me that i chickened out on my dream and gave in to my conventional social conditioning. but i ask because that tells me far more about you than your desires and fantasies. there’s a lot of crappy advice out there that says, "you’ve just got to want it enough!" people who enjoy long workweeks and the politics of the corporate ladder are the ones who move up it. self-help would say that i either wasn’t courageous enough, determined enough or i didn’t believe in myself enough. and when the lawyers go home and the alimony check is in the mail they say, "what was that for?" and to get good at dealing with negative experiences is to get good at dealing with life. people who enjoy the struggles of a gym are the ones who get in good shape. because if you want the benefits of something in life, you have to also want the costs. our culture would tell me that i’ve somehow failed myself, that i’m a quitter or a loser. they just aren’t aware of what it is they want, or rather, what they want "enough." if you want the beach body, you have to want the sweat, the soreness, the early mornings, and the hunger pangs. who you are is defined by the values you are willing to struggle for. you can only avoid negative experiences for so long before they come roaring back to life. maybe what you want isn’t what you want, you just enjoy wanting. for most of my adolescence and young adulthood, i fantasized about being a musician — a rock star, in particular. the fantasizing continued up through college, even after i dropped out of music school and stopped playing seriously. what determines your success isn’t "what do you want to enjoy?" this is the most simple and basic component of life: our struggles determine our successes. because that seems to be a greater determinant of how our lives turn out. it’s a mountain of a dream and a mile-high climb to the top. hell, i didn’t even try hard enough to fail at it. if i ask you, "what do you want out of life?" at the core of all human behavior, our needs are more or less similar. i’d be told to do affirmations or join a mastermind group or manifest or something. people want to be rich without the risk, without the sacrifice, without the delayed gratification necessary to accumulate wealth. it’s negative experience that we all, by definition, struggle with. i was in love not with the fight but only the victory. the question is, "what pain do you want to sustain?" everyone would like that—it’s easy to like that. for years and years and until the question morphs from "what if?" it’s what defines us and separates us and ultimately brings us together. maybe you don’t actually want it at all. here’s a way better question everybody wants what feels good. the broken strings, the blown tube amp, hauling 40 pounds of gear to and from rehearsals with no car. if not for their lowered standards and expectations 20 years prior, then what for? sometimes i ask people, "how do you choose to suffer?" these people tilt their heads and look at me like i have twelve noses. what is the pain that you want to sustain? despite fantasizing about this for over half of my life, the reality never came. it’s what makes me me and you you. people want to start their own business or become financially independent. and because of that, i failed at it. i wanted the result and not the process. you probably know to ask yourself, "what do i want?" and ultimately that’s the hard question that matters. and pretty much all of us have similar answers. the positive is the side effect of handling the negative. it’s the question that can change your life. this fantasy could keep me occupied for hours on end. you can’t win if you don’t play. you can’t have a pain-free life. it’s part of the game of love. this is not another admonishment of "no pain, no gain." i wanted the reward and not the struggle. then, i needed to find the time. and life doesn’t work that way. the more interesting question is the pain. what are you willing to struggle for? it can’t all be roses and unicorns. positive experience is easy to handle. i just liked to imagine the top. that answer will actually get you somewhere. because you have to choose something. then, i needed to make money. this is not a call for willpower or "grit." and everybody wants something enough. so choose your struggles wisely, my friend. they settle and wonder "what if?" people want an amazing physique. pleasure is an easy question. into "was that it?" then ... and then nothing. and so they settle. people want a partner, a spouse. first, i needed to finish school. i hardly tried at all. everybody wants something. because happiness requires struggle. end of story. this post originally appeared on markmanson.net. follow @iammarkmanson on twitter. repeatedly.

it shouldn’t come as much of a surprise then, that a newer study has revealed such body image issues are spurring millions of men to hit the gym — even though many would probably never admit it. the study says these men are motivated by "feelings of guilt and shame rather than a desire to build muscle," which may come as a surprise to many — even men who may not be willing to admit it to themselves. according to a recent study published in psychology of men & masculinity, as many as 20% to 40% of american men are struggling with body image problems in some shape or form. specifically, it’s "men’s hidden fears about body fat" that are driving gym attendance, according to a team of researchers from the university of lincoln (u.k.) and australia’s curtin university. some men even go to experience a place of solace; somewhere outside of the house and away from work where they can relax, hit the steam room, or just burn off some calories on the treadmill. the secret reason so many men go to the gym for millions of men, going to the gym is a daily ritual. body image issues aren’t typically associated with men, though they are fairly widespread. but new research indicates there are actually body image issues at play driving more men to fitness centers than you might expect. their reasons may vary widely — from looking to lose weight to building muscle and getting chiseled.

however strange "i'm going for a run slash walk in the park" sounds to your ear, it gets across the same basic message as the much wordier alternative, "i'm going to run in the park but probably do a fair amount of walking, too, because running is hard." in digital scenarios where time is of the essence, it might seem counterintuitive that typing "slash" in the written form would so often take the place of the shorter and equally comprehensible "and" or "or" if convenience is such a concern. if it is, in fact, here to stay, some grammar-sticklers will undoubtedly be scandalized at the prospect of a new coordinator, which curzan called "a category of words that doesn't often show much creativity and/or admit new members." the most common use corresponds most closely to "and/or," but she said a fair number are "used to connect one idea to another, perhaps meaning something like 'following up' or as something like a spoken semi-colon." the person with whom we share a responsibility for rent is also our friend, and whatever discreet container we bring to the theater will help us avoid paying five dollars for a box of sour patch kids. english speakers are pretty comfortable with this idea, as geoffrey k. pullum, professor of linguistics at the university of edinburgh, explained on his blog back in 2010. the strange word everyone is saying/texting not long after noticing friends and coworkers using "slash" in everyday conversation, i started seeing it cropping up everywhere, all the time. the slash works as a stand-in, whether written or spoken, helping the writer express multiple ideas without going through the trouble of stringing them together using appropriate grammar, or else risking a series of awkwardly short bullet-point sentences. "with clauses," he wrote, "i think there is no possibility of using it at all: consider 'i think i'm having hallucinations slash someone is playing tricks on me.' abbreviated by a lack of time or screen space or both, our technology has allowed instant messaging to flourish, so we might make our always-important thoughts known as quickly as possible. after so much time being delegated to such boring utilitarian functions as dates ("8/30/2014") and fractions ("3/4 cup"), the humble slash mark seems to be getting a linguistic makeover. the slash gives us a perfect opportunity to say two or more things at once like this, especially if one or more of those things is our own unsolicited snarky commentary. either spelled out in five characters ("slash") or just one ("/"), i saw it used to tack on subsequent ideas that could have been expressed in other, perfectly conventional ways. but everyone owns the english language -- or, maybe, no one does -- and we're not that great at sharing. "the most interesting implication to me," she said, "is that this coordinator is expanding in use ... and taking on new meanings." still, other examples use the slash as a way to indicate "truth values for the elements it connects," curzan explained. tell that to anyone who considers themselves a "slash dj," to indicate their interest in the turntable arts outside of a regular nine-to-five. while it'd be difficult to pin down exactly why we started going slash-crazy, it sure seems to correspond nicely with our culture of digital communication. a 1977 edition of theodore bernstein's "the careful writer" referred to the simple "and/or" as "a visual and mental monstrosity that should be avoided." since we aren't yet giving other punctuation the same treatment ("hello exclamation point" still sounds odd), it didn't make much sense. coordinators, also called coordinating conjunctions, include "and," "but," "or" and other words that function to link independent and dependent clauses. typing is second nature to us, and the slash is an almost mindlessly simple way to link our related thoughts. since then, curzan told me in an email, she's been studying examples of slash usage on twitter. for example, we might invite our friend/roommate to go see "boyhood" while planning to stuff our purse/backpack/pockets with cheap candy. so maybe it speaks, then, to our comfort with digital communication tools like keyboards and touch screens. in other words, saying one thing when what you really mean is the next. when the style guides and writers' handbooks i consulted mentioned the slash at all, they called it "rarely necessary." grammatically speaking, outside of its role as punctuation, the slash also functions as a "coordinator." anne curzan, professor of english at the university of michigan, described the practice among students in her classroom last year. correction: this story has been amended to reflect the correct spelling of geoffrey k. pullum's last name. or to jezebel editor kara brown, who described robin thicke's "paula" as the singer's "most recent album slash lame ass attempt at gaining publicity saving his marriage." change means that people are using a language, and using a language keeps it healthy. (there's not a lot of new slang being formed, for example, in latin.) curzan explicitly noted that the slash can now be used to connect full clauses. the slash was being vocalized where it might otherwise appear in written form, integrated smoothly into audible discussion. like saying you need to rest when what you're really planning is binge-watching tv. it was invading texts, instant messages, email and even in-person dialogue. doesn't seem like english at all, does it?" pullum suggested, however, that it really only makes sense in "lexical rather than phrasal categories." using "slash" assigned more "truth value" to "walk" over "run." @ max's restaurant, sm mall of asia http://t.co/osswgvkla4 — uriel yu medellin (@itsmeuriel) august 4, 2014 but will it stick around? to certain linguists, though, change is actually a great sign. it's a match made in, um, some factory in china. the slash helps us present alternative descriptions. usage guidelines are, of course, still very restrictive in formal writing. we can't say. these days, many english speakers would disagree. (writer-slash-dj. financial-consultant-slash-dj. our meaning is clear. but they weren't. animal-whisperer-slash-dj.) breakfast slash lunch! "review slash indictment.") ("friendship slash rivalry." yum!

by knocking off 10 hours of work each week for a year, employees at a swedish nursing home were able to improve their health, cut back on sick leave, and enhance the care of their charges, the new york times reports. the owner of a start-up in stockholm, which operates on a six-hour day but didn’t take part in the study, says the shorter days have assisted the small company to double its revenue and profit for the past three years. "we thought doing a shorter workweek would mean we’d have to hire more, but it hasn’t resulted in that because everyone works more efficiently," the owner tells the times. while workers reported feeling better about the jobs and their contribution, employers that took part in the experiment found a 30-hour work week sharply reduced absenteeism, improved productivity, enhanced creativity, and reduced turnover. "we’ve had 40 years of a 40-hour workweek, and now we’re looking at a society with higher sick leave and early retirement," daniel bernmar, leader of the political party running the trial, said. under the experiment, which focused on the future of work in gothenburg, employees began working six-hour days at the same pay rate as their previous eight-hour days. in sweden, an experiment turns shorter workdays into bigger gains [the new york times] in sweden, an experiment turns shorter workdays into bigger gains [the new york times] while the trial initially cost the hospital an additional $123,000 a month, it reduced sick calls, and increased the efficiency of the healthcare workers. "we can’t pay people to not work," maria rydén, gothenburg’s deputy mayor, who is working to put an end to the trial, tells the times. there are 120 hours in a 5-day workweek, and for most working americans at least a third of that time is spent earning a living. sure, you’ve got 16-ish hours away from the job each day, but is that enough time to enjoy all your personal, family, community, and social commitments without becoming a harried, frazzled unproductive mess? an ongoing study out of sweden seems to indicate that a shorter work day may actually result in more productivity. "we want a new discussion in sweden about how work life should be to maintain a good welfare state for the next 40 years." one employee says that after just one week he was more energized and residents said their standard of care had improved. "what’s good is that we’re happy," one employee tells the times. although the tests have been helpful to both participating companies and employees, the concept hasn’t been greeted with open arms by everyone. some opponents of the option contend that the country’s economy would suffer from reduced competitiveness and strained finances, the times reports. "since we work fewer hours, we are constantly figuring out ways to do more with our time." the hospital’s orthopedics unit switched 89 nurses and doctors to a six-hour day. but unlike the start-up, it had to hire 15 additional workers. are shorter work days better for your health &amp; productivity? "and a happy worker is a better worker." sahlgrenska university hospital in gothenburg tried a similar trial last year.

3 things to know about the future of virtual reality delegates use the gear vr (virtual reality) headset, manufactured by samsung electronics co., at the samsung unpacked launch event ahead of the mobile world congress in barcelona, spain, on sunday, feb. 21, 2016. a wireless rift or vive won't happen soon there are two classes of virtual reality devices available today: cheaper, portable devices like the samsung gear vr and google cardboard, and beefier, expensive systems that offer more immersive experiences like the rift and the vive. "by the time we solve that, as an industry we're going to want to give you version two of the product, which is going to become the new benchmark," azor said. time sat down with frank azor, general manager of the dell-owned gaming pc manufacturer alienware, and nelson gonzalez, alienware's cofounder and former ceo, to discuss what they have learned about vr and where they believe it's headed. it's unlikely that we'll see a high-performance device like the rift go wireless anytime soon, mostly because wireless technology isn't advancing at the same pace as vr hardware. once you begin catering to the rest of the senses, like what we feel body-wise, temperature-wise, and smell, the reality factor of virtual reality [becomes] stronger and the virtual piece begins to fade." the former plug into your smartphone to deliver vr that's wireless and convenient, while the latter must be tethered to a pc to power their higher-end performance. although it may look like you're swinging a golf club, the device in your hand still feels like a video game controller. "headsets today are doing an excellent job at catering to your visual senses, and a little bit of audio as well," said azor, also alienware's fourth employee. pcs became better equipped to deliver high-end gaming experiences as companies like intel, amd, and nvidia developed more powerful chips and graphics processors. the vive and its two controllers are equipped with sensors that allow players to swing a virtual golf club or wield an imaginary paintbrush. leap motion, a startup which launched a motion-sensing camera for computers in 2013, is now building technology for interacting with vr environments without a controller. vr is an industry-wide effort the oculus rift will likely be remembered as the first modern virtual reality headset. virtual reality will get more physical anyone who's seen or tried the htc vive knows that some physical activity is involved. that's the promise of virtual reality (vr) headsets, like the oculus rift and htc vive. strap on a rectangular black headset, and you can traverse a sunken ship at the bottom of the ocean or climb to the top of a snowcapped mountain. but the latest crop of gadgets are seen as more promising, thanks to their much-improved graphics, head-tracking abilities and more. this is going to be one of the first areas in which virtual reality will improve, says gonzalez. "and not just sitting down; if you're a quarterback, you actually get to throw a football, and you can interface with the team. azor believes future vr devices could refine concepts first introduced as far back as 1962 with the sensorama , which incorporated elements like wind and smells. but it takes more than just one device to impact the industry in a meaningful way, says azor. (the oculus rift doesn't yet support any motion controllers, although the company plans to launch such devices later in 2016.) few have watched virtual reality evolve as closely as the companies building the hardware that powers it. "everyone rallied around [the pc gaming] industry and now we have what we have today," he said. "the next evolution of vr would be where you participate physically in that vr world," gonzalez said. but what systems like the vive or playstation vr currently lack is a sense of touch. "vr is the same type of thing; no one company can solve all of the problems." as impressive as the technology already is, many believe it's still in its early days. "wireless technology is on a different schedule, that's where the issue comes in . startup thalmic labs also makes an armband capable of controlling electronic devices through gestures that works with the rift. so that kind of stuff, it's there, it's going to happen." that's because previous virtual reality-style efforts have flopped in the past. games became more accessible on pcs as companies like steam created platforms for easily buying and browsing content. azor draws comparisons to the way the gaming industry developed over the past decade. the latest and greatest will be wired for a fair amount of time moving forward." it's unclear exactly how — and if — technologies like those azor described will ever take shape. "well that's just two of the senses . incorporating better touch controls will only be the start. but some companies are certainly trying. (nintendo's virtual boy comes to mind.) below are the key highlights from our conversation. .

"the dreamliner has a composite fuselage and that allowed us to pressurize it at whatever altitude we wanted because the material is not as susceptible to fatigue," blake emery, director of differentiation strategy for boeing commercial airplanes, told business insider in an interview. however, because barometric pressures in aircraft cabins are similar to those at the terrestrial altitudes at which acute mountain sickness occurs, it is possible that some of the symptoms are related to the decreased partial pressure of oxygen and are manifestations of acute mountain sickness." while the engineering of the composite airframe may have been a challenge, it's a decision that allowed boeing to make a major change to its aircraft that could greatly reduce the effect of jet lag on its passengers. in a study conducted by oklahoma state university with the help of boeing, researchers wrote: "some passengers on long commercial flights experience discomfort characterized by symptoms similar to those of acute mountain sickness. in 2015 boeing annouced it had made the lightest metal ever the study found that passengers who go from sea level up to 8,000 feet of altitude saw the oxygen content in their blood fall 4%. why does air pressure matter to passengers?​ for most of us, a long flight is usually followed by some combination of symptoms that include headaches, lack of appetite, lack of energy, nausea, and sleeplessness. one of which was the decision to build much of the plane out of carbon-fiber reinforced plastics and other composite materials instead of the aluminum most commonly used on commercial airliners. "aluminum aircraft can be pressurized to 6,000 feet," kent craver, boeing commercial airplanes regional director of passenger satisfaction, told business insider in an interview. boeing is making a major change to its planes that could solve the biggest problem with air travel during the development of the 787 dreamliner, boeing encountered countless engineering hurdles. the very symptoms we attribute to jet lag may actually be attributed to acute mountain sickness, which affects individuals exposed to altitudes above 6,500 feet. according to emery, since there isn't a perfect one-to-one correlation between altitude and jet lag, boeing has taken additional measures to mitigate the symptoms. as a result, we can achieve it with a few local reinforcements and change those loads out to accommodate lower cabin altitude." airplane makers have traditionally avoided lowering the cabin altitude because boosting the air pressure inside the cabin puts greater stress on aluminum airframes. at 6,000 feet, the cabin air is more dense and has a greater level of oxygen saturation. although this didn't trigger full on acute mountain sickness, it did bring on what the study called "increased prevalence of discomfort after three to nine hours" of exposure. all of these afflictions have been conveniently bundled together with a disruption of one's internal body clock to form something we call jet lag. "to lower the cabin altitude, we actually increased the air pressure inside the cabin," emery added. however, boeing believes it can successfully lower cabin altitude on the 777x without going to a composite body. however, unlike the composite dreamliner, the 777x, boeing's successor to landmark 777, will be primarily made of aluminum. "we also understand the requirements of the lower cabin altitude in terms of cycles and pressures on the fuselage. "the research showed passengers' bodies reacted at 6,000 feet similar to that at sea level," emery said. "we know the 777 fuselage, its structural qualities, and its fatigue margins really well," a boeing spokesperson told us in an email. currently, most airliners have cabin air pressure equivalent to that of an altitude of 8,000 feet. the dreamliner won't be the only boeing jet to have a have a lower cabin altitude. in addition, airbus is also working to lower the cabin altitude on its next generation of airliners. as result, the body does not have to work as hard to oxygenate blood and sustain itself. the company's upcoming 777x wide-body mini-jumbo jet will also be pressurized at 6,000 feet. these measures include an increase in cabin humidity as well as a new air-filtration system. this increases the likelihood of metal fatigue and shortens the service life of the airplane. the symptoms are often attributed to factors such as jet lag, prolonged sitting, dehydration, or contamination of cabin air. for the dreamliner, boeing cut that down to 6,000 feet. "so we decided to pressurize the dreamliner at 6,000 feet." "in fact, most business jets are already pressurized to that level." the boeing 777x is set to enter service in 2019. but the reality is that jet lag is far more serious. why haven't we had this all along? "it's a bit counterintuitive for most people."

and unwanted possessions out of their windows on new year’s day. according to swedish legend, witches visited the forest of blakulla before easter, to party with the devil as he held his earthy court. when mr. ballmer retired as chief executive of microsoft in 2014, he was only 57 and quickly realized "i don’t, quote, ‘have anything to do.’" as he looked for a new endeavor — before he decided to buy the clippers — his wife, connie, encouraged him to help with some of her philanthropic efforts, an idea he initially rejected. at one point, as he showed me the value of certain tax deductions and blurted out, "if you look at these tax deductions for employer-provided health or for state and local taxes or mortgage-interest deductions, they’re really subsidies to the affluent, which i guess i hadn’t thought about them." on tuesday, mr. ballmer plans to make public a database and a report that he and a small army of economists, professors and other professionals have been assembling as part of a stealth start-up over the last three years called usafacts. "because i’m a citizen, i don’t care whether i give my money to a, b or c. i just want to know how it lands, how it impacts what’s going on." "you know, when i really wanted to understand in depth what a company was doing, amazon or apple, i’d get their 10-k and read it," he told me in a recent interview in new york. "now people might not think they’re government employees, but your tax dollars are helping somehow to pay 24 million people — and most of these people you like," mr. ballmer said. "most of the not-for-profits we work with would be 50 to 90 percent government funded," mr. ballmer said, referring to various efforts to fight poverty that he has supported. that conversation led mr. ballmer to pursue what may be one of the most ambitious private projects undertaken to answer a question that has long vexed the public and politicians alike. with an unlimited budget, he went about hiring a team of researchers in seattle and made a grant to the university of pennsylvania to help his staff put the information together. "it’s wonky, it’s this, it’s that, but it’s the greatest depth you’re going to get, and it’s accurate." suddenly, he explained, the faceless bureaucrats who are often pilloried as symbols of government waste start to look like the people in our neighborhood whom we’re very glad to have. after all, he pointed out, he happily paid a lot of taxes, and he figured that all that tax money should create a sufficient social safety net. i pay this with after-tax money, no pretax money, because i don’t want anybody being able to think that factors in. in an age of fake news and questions about how politicians and others manipulate data to fit their biases, mr. ballmer’s project may serve as a powerful antidote. her answer: "a, it won’t, because there are things government doesn’t get to, and b, you’re missing it." the database is perhaps the first nonpartisan effort to create a fully integrated look at revenue and spending across federal, state and local governments. but as he speaks, you can tell that some of his findings from the new data — which rebut his preconceptions — could change his own politics. for example, mr. ballmer, said: "you know it’s not legal to know how many firearms that are in this country? using his website, usafacts.org, a person could look up just about anything: how much revenue do airports take in and spend? one rule mr. ballmer said his team made early on was to use only government data — no outside providers — to avoid accusations of bias. mr. ballmer calls it "the equivalent of a 10-k for government," referring to the kind of annual filing that companies make. "i mean it’s funny, but i didn’t realize all these not-for-profits were in a sense almost like government contractors." for mr. ballmer, the experience has been worth every cent simply for the surprises that he has discovered looking at the data. there is data for the number of firearms manufactured, licenses, inspections, "along with other data, but not a total," he said. "people can disagree about what to do — i’m not going to tell people what to do." what he found surprised him guess what steven a. ballmer has been up to for the last several years. "and by the way, i check it with google, just to make sure there’s nothing i’m missing." he created a database to "figure out what the government really does with the money." he sought to "figure out what the government really does with the money," mr. ballmer said. want to know what percentage of americans suffer from diagnosed depression and how much the government spends on it? want to know how much revenue is brought in from parking tickets and the cost to collect? source:  harvard business review imagine that you're teaching a geometry class, and you've volunteered to stay after school one day a week to help one of your students, alex, improve his understanding of geometry. dr grant and mr rebele explain that you need to remember three key things when giving to other people: 'being thoughtful about how you help, when you help, and whom you help.' 'when they don’t protect themselves, their investments in others can cause them to feel overloaded and fatigued, fall behind in their work goals, and face more stress and conflict at home', they said. their answers allowed the authors to predict how well their students would do in their exams at the end of the year. c. tell alex that it's nice that he wants to help juan, but he really needs to focus on his own work in order to catch up. their work shows it's about balancing time so when you help other people you don't set yourself back in the process. not only in teaching, but selfless people suffer most in workplaces and find themselves drowning in admin and unable to pursue their own goals as a result. 'although givers are the most valuable people in organizations, they’re also at the greatest risk for burnout', the authors wrote in the harvard business review. in an article for the harvard business review, wharton school of the university of pennsylvania professor, dr adam grant and wharton people analytics researcher reb rebele explore the 'generosity burnout'. their research also showed people who protect their own time can give the most long-term contribution. schedule a separate after-school session to help juan, so you can better understand his individual needs. they believe that selflessness at work leads to exhaustion, and ironically often hurts the people you intended to help. at the start of the year they asked them questions about their approach to helping others. surprisingly, the pupils with teachers who answered (a) did the worst in their end of year exams. and in the workplace putting your needs before those of your colleagues is often seen as selfish behaviour. why you should be selfish at work we're always being encouraged to help others before we help ourselves. giving at the expense of your own well-being damages your chance of long-term success. give in a way that is in your own interest and preserves your own energy resources. he asks if you'll also help his friend juan, who isn't in your class. don't be afraid to refer work to other people when you don't have time. in the end, they were damaging the very students they wanted to help. in their currently unpublished research, authors dr grant and mr rebele studied a range of jobs. one data set came from a study conducted with more than 400 teachers in schools throughout the us. d. tell alex that juan should ask his own teacher for help. the teachers who protected themselves and were less selfless got their students better marks. no one can be available all the time to help other people. 5- dedicate blocks of time to giving rather than doing it all the time. here's how the times summarizes it: "the poor in some cities—big ones like new york and los angeles, and also quite a few smaller ones like birmingham, ala.—live nearly as long as their middle-class neighbors or have seen rising life expectancy in the 21st century. "it is as if the top income percentiles belong to one world of elite, wealthy us adults," wrote nobel prize–winning economist angus deaton in an article that accompanied the study in jama, "whereas the bottom income percentiles each belong to separate worlds of poverty, each unhappy and unhealthy in its own way." poor people in and around birmingham had a surprisingly high life expectancy, but there too there has been an investment in health services, according to the times, and banned smoking in restaurants and other places in 2012. the big finding from stanford economist raj chetty and his seven co-authors is not that rich people live longer, it's that the life expectancies of americans in poverty varies wildly depending on where they live. in many ways, this is a punishingly unfair city, but when it comes to having a healthy populace, it seems like other places could benefit from some new york values. in poverty-pocked areas in the midwest and the south, poor people die sooner; in other words, in places that lack the services and infrastructure that wealthy big cities usually provide, people are less healthy. the places where the poor lived the longest include new york and san francisco—rich cities that can afford to provide a lot of services and have proactive public health departments. in that context, the publication, in the journal of the american medical association (jama), of a new study that looks at income and life expectancy after age 40 contains no bombshells. but in some other parts of the country, adults with the lowest incomes die on average as young as people in much poorer nations like rwanda, and their life spans are getting shorter." and the authors adjusted the statistics for race and ethnicity in order to correct for racial differences in life expectancy (for instance, black people generally live less long than whites), something they've been criticized for. good schools, crime-free neighborhoods, childhoods spared the trauma of family dysfunction, and other factors all contribute to whether someone is happy and healthy as an adult, or whether they're trapped in that old cycle of poverty begetting stress begetting illness begetting more poverty. one reason poor people in major metropolises have longer life expectancies could be that they have higher proportions of immigrants, who tend to live longer than native-born americans. for the wealthy, it doesn't matter where they live—they seem to have the access to the same sorts of advantages wherever they go. the one strange trick that will make you live longer meditating inside a beautiful stock-photo room filled with plants is just one health benefit not available to poor people. but if we accept the broader findings here, there seems to be almost a trickle-down affect when it comes to long life and health. "the jama paper found that several measures of access to medical care had no clear relationship with longevity among the poor," noted the times. that's beyond the scope of the paper, but it's clear that the answer isn't simply that some places have fewer or worse doctors. photo via getty reports on the income inequality gap and the separate lives of the wealthy and the poor have become depressingly rote. the report, covered widely by the new york times and pretty much every other outlet on monday, drills down into how income and longevity correlate. the poorest people in america are now on average not making enough to meet their basic needs—that sounds pretty bad, but can i interest you in a $700 juicer? new york's example suggests at least the bones of a solution: higher taxes to fund a local government that develops policies to discourage people from eating crappy food and smoking. "race/ethnicity is inseparable from the economic consequences and stress associated with segregation, past and present marginalization in the distribution of resources, structural racism, persistent poverty, and violence." seen from this angle, inequality looks like not just a matter of unfair numbers but a public health problem. but the ability of money and the things it buys—access to better medical care, leisure time, healthier food—to stave off death is well known. the rich are not like you or me: they can buy their way into exclusive clubs, special social networks, even elitist sex parties. the richest 1 percent of men lives, on average, 15 years longer than the poorest 1 percent; for women that gap is ten years. some people have lower incomes because their poor health damaged their earnings power, not the other way round. "social marginalization is not reducible to single variables," wrote steven woolf and jason purnell in a jama editorial. the obvious question, then, is what makes those individual islands of scarcity more or less healthy than other communities? san francisco was a pioneer in smoking bans; new york abolished trans fats. "health is about more than healthcare," woolf and purnell wrote. any study like this comes with some caveats. "but there were correlations with smoking, exercise, and obesity."

but when flynn was only 7 months old, a stranger accidentally put hailey in harm's way by stopping to pet flynn — and the incident illustrates exactly why working dogs should never be pet or played with while they're working. why you should never pet a service dog flynn the dog does a lot to help out his 17-year-old human, hailey ashmore: he can open and close doors, fetch her parents and, most importantly, alert her to oncoming seizures. "it becomes almost an extension of that person, just like someone's wheelchair ... besides the fact that the dog is part of who you are, that touching can distract the dog from what they need to do." hailey ashmore reiss explained that assistance dogs are trained to go from "being on to off in a few seconds," from hanging out with a chew toy to helping their human in the blink of an eye. hailey ashmore "since flynn was only about 7 months at the time of the accident, he was, and still is, learning to ignore people petting him," hailey explained. hailey ashmore hailey was visiting her dad at work when someone began petting flynn like he was just a regular pup. but in just a moment of distraction flynn had missed a crucial opportunity to warn hailey about an oncoming seizure. cci is a nonprofit that trains assistance dogs, including companion dogs and service dogs, and then matches them to people with disabilities. hailey's story illustrates just how important service animals are for their humans — and why their vests shouldn't be ignored. dogs like flynn provide crucial medical assistance, and while they're working, they need to be 100 percent focused. hailey has had flynn since november 2014, when the australian shepherd puppy began his training with her as a medical alert dog. hailey sums it up this way: "if you wouldn't do it to a wheelchair, please don't do it to our dogs." "the dog is part of a team," jessica reiss, of canine companions for independence (cci) told the dodo. "i thought i had 10 minutes to get safe, take medication and call somebody for help," hailey told the dodo. when strangers stop to play with assistance dogs, they can interfere with their work. "i immediately told him to stop," hailey told the dodo. cci does not train medical alert dogs like flynn. "we understand our dogs are super cute, but they are really important for our safety and health." "unfortunately, i didn't and ended up getting a nasty rug burn." when he did warn her, it was too late. "they're not a piece of equipment," reiss said. "they can be distracted."

a man who retired at 34 explains one bad savings habit that everyone should avoid in august, brandon — better known as the mad fientist — retired at just 34 years old to get there, brandon (who doesn't use his last name online for privacy reasons) chose to live frugally in rural vermont, where he managed to save and invest about 70% of his after-tax income in 2014, brandon and his wife —who has no interest in retiring early and keeps her finances largely separate from her husband's — moved to scotland, where he continued to work for a few more years, eventually putting away enough to allow him to retire at 34. when an audience member asked brandon and this panelists to share what kept them motivated on the path to financial independence during an episode of his "financial independence podcast," he responded that instead of struggling to stick to his savings goals, he coped with putting away too much. "focus on the power that you're getting along the way with all that money that you're saving up, and use that power to make your life a lot better along the way," he says. "i never wanted to stop working, but rather i wanted to have the time and freedom to work on things that are important to me." by avoiding anything that involved spending money, brandon ended up dodging his friends and depriving himself of even the little things that brought him joy. while brandon advocates financial independence, he stresses that anyone striving for early retirement should avoid becoming so obsessed with it that they isolate themselves. "it's always been about 'financial independence' for me and not really 'early retirement,'" he told business insider . "one extra dollar in your bank account is not going to make you really happier," he warns. "i just didn't want to do anything that involved spending money. "[i] went so hardcore that i made myself really unhappy during the process," he says. but his journey to financial independence taught him a valuable lesson: saving isn't everything. i just wanted to get there as soon as possible." early retirement is supposed to be freeing and empowering, not constricting. "don't sacrifice happiness for that final number in the bank."
our society is full of all kinds of families, but our leafy suburb just outside of new york city often feels like there is one kind: traditional two-parent homes where one parent (usually the dad) works full-time while the long-suffering mother does everything with her kids. when i went on a business trip for a week two years ago, a friend confided in me: "my husband wouldn't even be able to pack a lunch if i left." and my son might get a b on a spelling test instead of his usual a, because my husband doesn't ride him as hard as i would've if i was home. the annoying question no mom wants to hear when she goes on vacation last month, i left my three children for almost two full weeks to travel across nicaragua with my stepmother and sister. but what was perhaps the most baffling part of the whole thing was the one question i was asked again and again from fellow moms: "who is watching your kids?" the trip was full of surprises: lizards in our suitcase, a couple days on islands with no wi-fi (and no english), and days spent doing yoga on the beach to round it all out. the list of daily tasks for the care and upkeep of three children is seemingly endless — from the moment they leap out of bed between 7 and 7:15 to the moment they hit the pillows around 8 or 8:30. but as a married mom whose husband has an equal hand in raising our brood to adulthood, it's quite astonishing to be asked that question again and again. not once, in all those weeks of lonely nights and busy mornings, did anyone ask him who was watching the kids. he picks up from gymnastics every wednesday, and takes charge of math homework and making sure our son reads for exactly 20 minutes every night. and i promise when you do, i will never ask you who is taking care of them. he changes diapers and also has access to the giant family calendar that hangs in our mudroom to track everyone's doctors appointments, playdates, birthday parties, and after-school activities. my 9-year-old and 7-year-old have homework to supervise, friend dramas to negotiate, permission slips to sign, and activities to attend. i might be behind the wheel mostly, but he's always next to me in the front seat reading the map. because i knew that back home, even though he felt like he was drowning, he would doggy paddle his way back to shore somehow. most popular truth be told, i work part-time, so the bulk of the child duties does fall to me. the 2-year-old must be changed, washed, brushed, soothed, fed, held, rocked, amused, and watched multiple times a day. they dress and bathe themselves, but someone must be vigilant at all times to keep them on track. last year, there were long periods where he left every tuesday and returned on friday afternoon. no, i didn't hire a babysitter (at least not for the nights or weekends). being alone with the kids is a challenge even for the most organized and dedicated among us. but my children would be clean, well-fed, and (mostly) smiling when i got back. kids need to know their daddies can care for them as well. upon my return, a friend said she could "never do what you did." fathers have an equal part in creating them and should have an equal role in raising them. her husband wouldn't be able to keep it together. if i were a single mother, the question might be valid. no, i didn't leave them with the grandparents. my toddler's cot sheet might not get washed for preschool. he texted me on wednesday, six days into my 11-day trip. but that doesn't make daddy less capable of it. he is a parent just like me. and that's exactly the reason to go. daddies get to go out in the world. but it's not easy when one spouse travels. a job that really belongs to two people suddenly falls to one. this is why i needed a vacation. my husband is not a babysitter. he is responsible for preschool drop-off every morning. but that is all i did. it's a fact my husband understands well. my husband regularly goes to california for work. leave the kids with daddy. but my husband knows the score. my husband was with them. so why the question? why are we accepting this as normal? why would anyone find this shocking? because i will already know. "how long are you gone again?" it's good for everyone. mommy has it all under control. and i do. and they were. so go on. ok, so it's true. it's obvious, right? mommies stay home. i had to laugh. not without massive amounts of help. mostly. alone.
foursquare's dennis crowley: this mistake will get you called out on social media building loyalty with your customers is crucial for growing a business, but trying too hard can also get your company skewered on social media. "there are a lot of brands that don't do it that well, and it's a little bit like watching a train wreck as they try to be authentic, funny, and witty," he says. to ensure you're building a good rapport with users, don't be disingenuous or misrepresent your brand's identity on social media. take it from foursquare co-founder dennis crowley, who attributes much of his geolocation company's success to early engagement with users on social media channels. "prioritizing that and making it an important part of what we did at foursquare was one of the things that got us to where we are today." "it's really clear when you're trying too hard and being really inauthentic," he says. "we had a nice, playful, flirty tone with a lot of the users back in the day," he says. "you'll definitely get called out for it," crowley says. so what separates strong social media interactions from disastrous ones? according to crowley, the key is authenticity.
google celebrated what would have been celia cruz's 88th birthday monday with a doodle honoring the cuban singer who rose to international stardom as one of the world's greatest salsa singers. born úrsula hilaria celia de la caridad cruz alfonso to a working-class family in havana in 1925, cruz took up singing as a child -- an interest later encouraged by her aunt, who introduced her to the world of cuba's nightclubs, according to billboard. it was in the united states that cruz would become an international icon and earn the moniker "the queen of salsa," after launching a solo career with percussionist tito puente, and performing with the fania all stars in the 1970s. "there have been many posthumous tributes to celia in these last ten years, but this one by google is certainly one of the most important and far-reaching," omer pardillo-cid, sole executor of the celia cruz estate, said in a press release. today would have been her 88th birthday — jacquellena carrero (@jacquellenac) october 21, 2013 yesssss today google's page is dedicated to celia cruz! a student of cuba's conservatory of music, cruz's career took off in 1950 when she joined la sonora matancera, one of cuba's most prominent dance orchestras. #lavidaesuncarnaval — carla saavedra (@carlasaavedra) october 21, 2013 the outpouring of emotion wouldn't surprise those familiar with the artist's work. by the time of her death at 77 two years later, she had raked in 10 grammys, honorary doctorates from yale and the university of miami, and a smithsonian lifetime achievement award. "it's as if the earth opened her mouth to talk and sing," marvette perez, curator of latino history and culture at the national museum of american history in washington, told npr in 2005. the cuban government refused to let her visit the island to attend her father's funeral years later, according to the new york times. as celia told the new york times in an interview: "when people hear me sing, i want them to be happy, happy, happy. the outpouring of emotion wouldn't surprise those familiar with the artist's work. thank you, google, for dedicating today's doodle to one of salsa's greatest singers. the singer left the island while on tour with la sonora matancera in 1960, shortly after the cuban revolution, and never returned. the salsa legend behind the google doodle web surfers woke up monday to a sprinkling of azúcar. it's celia cruz birthday and there's azucar in the google page. she continued cutting records and performing as a solo artists well into her seventies, including the award-winning "la negra tiene tumbao" in 2001. the doodle won plaudits from celia's dedicated fans, who took to twitter to cheer the internet mammoth's artwork. i don't want them thinking about when there's not any money, or when there's fighting at home. — arlene davila (@arlenedavila1) october 21, 2013 loving this @google doodle honoring celia cruz! she became famous for her booming voice, energetic performances punctuated by her signature outbursts of "azúcar!" — theresa socash (@tsocash) october 21, 2013 celia cruz would've been 88 today. "she would have loved it!" -- spanish for "sugar" -- and her over-the-top dresses and wigs. my message is always felicidad — happiness."

ottessa moshfegh's stories of selfish people doing foul things are must-reads the protagonist of "malibu," the third short story in ottessa moshfegh’s new collection, spends his time making up job applications so he can continue to receive unemployment benefits and try to coax money out of his aging uncle, who has a colostomy bag and does little but eat fatty meals in front of daytime tv. after her book, a noir novel about a miserable and self-loathing young woman who works in a detention center, was nominated for the man booker prize, she notoriously confessed to the guardian that she’d written the book as a joke to get attention. this may sound unappealing, yet moshfegh’s talent is a sheer delight ― and the heedless misbehavior of her characters is a reminder, needed now more than ever, that we’re not such an elevated species as we’d like to think, and that following our base impulses can lead us nowhere fast. what other reviewers think: the new york times: "if there’s a thematic thread weaving through this collection, it’s the complicated relationship between entrapment in the physical body — her characters are often probing, picking and searching with their fingertips, as if seeking beauty and potential grace — and entrapment in social landscapes." ‘i forgot the broom.’" homesick for another world by ottessa moshfegh penguin press, $26.00 published january 3, 2017 the bottom line is a weekly review combining plot description and analysis with fun tidbits about the book. it’s not a book to reassure readers of the essential goodness of the human race; it’s a queasy jolt to our optimistic selves, a reminder of the lowest, most id-driven proclivities of humanity. he’s handsome but pimply and given to throwing up after eating; he daydreams of the beautiful woman he’ll one day fall in love with, but treats the real women he meets like inconveniently sentient kleenex. she quietly loathes him, the way he clenches his muscles constantly to stay in shape, his devotion to a crystal skull he keeps by his bed, the yellow women’s blazer he bought secondhand and considers the height of manly fashion. when he goes to a meet-up he’s planned with a strange woman, he shoves his hand down her throat, enjoying that he can see how his intrusive hand bulges her neck. the bottom line: moshfegh’s stories of selfish people doing foul things capture the dark side of human nature, which is easy but self-deluding to ignore. the young one talked to me sometimes, asked me what i would do for the long weekend, if i’d see my folks over christmas, and so forth. they’re constantly squeezing their acne, having sex with people they despise, eating candy and drinking until they’re sick, developing meth addictions just for kicks, and always feeling slightly superior to their own surroundings despite their listless lives. though it’s out of focus and context-free, he’s convinced that it was a picture taken by his late wife ― of a male prostitute from the island. in much fiction, writers draw us in by painting the relatable, lovable vulnerabilities within even their most nominally unsympathetic characters, complicating our impulse to divide the world into "good" and "bad." as in her debut novel, eileen, the narrators of the 14 stories in homesick for another world are gloomy, narcissistic and self-pitying. he recalls taking a prostitute to a motel room: "i sat down next to her and splayed my hands out on the bed. ottessa moshfegh has previously published a novel, eileen, which was shortlisted for the man booker prize and was given the hemingway foundation/pen award. the bottom line is a weekly review combining plot description and analysis with fun tidbits about the book. in either first-person or close third-person narration, the blunt, unemotional words with which her characters relate their petty cruelties, addictions, and even bodily functions never ceases to be slightly jarring. suddenly, he’s revolted by her, the woman he thought was a lady, but who he’s now certain was unfaithful. he finally manages to secretly court her via text, but quickly loses his interest in her once she seems attainable: "he took out his phone and reread all her texts again. she has a brief fling with a local: "i still remember the humility it took for me to agree to take him home." in a story called "the beach boy," a man’s wife dies suddenly after their 29th anniversary celebration on a tropical island. she hires a heavily pregnant young woman to clean her home, then calmly ignores it when her housekeeper begins to hemorrhage on the job. moshfegh’s talent is unique, and her characters — unfiltered, cold, frequently pathetic — are all the more memorable for their faults and obliviousness." the old one looked the other way and twisted her robes in her fists when she saw me coming." officials in washington and riyadh were already on edge because president obama is said to be seriously considering declassifying 28 pages of a congressional report into the 2001 attacks that some say indicate the hijackers, 15 of whom were saudi arabian, received support, explicit or otherwise, from the country’s vast royal family. the treasury department’s disclosure answers one of the questions surrounding the relationship between the two countries and shows that the monarchy, while an important player in the u.s. financial system, doesn’t have as much leverage as many likely believed. last month saudi officials warned the country would sell off $750 billion worth of treasuries and other assets in the states if congress approved a bill that would allow the monarchy to be sued in american courts for any role in the sept. 11, 2001, terror attacks. saudi arabia holds roughly $117 billion of the u.s. government’s debt, according to treasury department data that disclosed the country’s holdings for the first time in over 40 years. the kingdom’s holdings of american treasury bills have previously been grouped in with the 14 nations that comprise the organization of petroleum exporting countries (opec), like kuwait and venezuela. the $116.8 billion saudi arabia owns puts it in the top 12 foreign nations with holdings of u.s. debt, falling between india and singapore. the u.s. started releasing data on foreign ownership of treasuries in 1974, but had never specified how much saudi arabia holds. intelligence officials have been reviewing whether to make the pages public since 2014 and are due to deliver a recommendation to the president. together, those countries own about $281 billion in u.s. debt, down from $298.4 billion in january. a freedom of information act request filed by a freedom of information act request filed by bloomberg news led to the treasury department breaking down the assets by country. saudi holdings of treasuries peaked at $123.6 billion in january, the data released monday show. whatever the recommendation, the white house has said obama could ultimately use his executive authority to make the pages public. the numbers were made public as part of the treasury’s regular monthly reports. the disclosure comes during an unusually tense time in u.s.-saudi relations. just how much us debt does saudi arabia own? its total pales in comparison to china’s whopping $1.3 trillion and japan’s $1.1 trillion.

the physical waste produced by a society obsessed with the latest electronic gadget. planned obsolescence growing up in qatar provided a unique vantage point from which to witness the rapid evolution of history, in a commercial and technological sense. while the rise of the internet was a key aspect of her formative years, her work often deals with the isolating nature of the digital space. maybe it doesn't create community in the way that people think because with the ability to post whatever you want at any time, you also get the ugly side," al-maria says. the exhibition "posits the thought that shopping malls have become a kind of replacement for religious structures in our contemporary consumer society," she says. as al-maria puts it: "there's planned obsolescence in the devices, so there's planned obsolescence in the art. still from "between distant bodies" (2013) by sophia al-maria "a few years ago i had a real feeling of heaviness through things like facebook, like i was dragging the ghost of every person i had ever met. born to an american mother and a qatari bedouin father, she spent her childhood in the us before moving to qatar. exemplifying of a new generation of creative polymaths, the writer-filmmaker-artist has produced photos, directed films, written articles and screenplays, and published a critically acclaimed memoir, "the girl who fell to earth." the reality is probably not that bad, but also not as click-worthy: research from the transamerica center for retirement studies indicates that nearly three-quarters of millennials are saving for retirement and that we started doing so at an earlier age than previous generations. but you can also pay taxes now and spare your future self the burden by choosing a roth ira (check roth contribution limits to gauge your eligibility) or the roth version of your 401(k), if your employer offers that option. use a roth ira or a roth 401(k) contributions to a traditional 401(k) or ira are made with pre-tax dollars; you pay taxes when you take distributions in retirement. what you can mostly control are investing costs   fees charged by your index funds (called expense ratios), administrative fees in your 401(k) and transaction fees incurred when you buy and sell investments. take that risk through index funds about 70% would be a reasonable stock allocation for your retirement portfolio   and even that might be on the low side. and because you're not getting a tax benefit now, you get to pull out the money   both your contributions and investment growth   tax free in retirement. you can buy a couple of funds that hold the stock of u.s. companies, one that holds international companies and one that holds emerging-markets companies and you'll be reasonably diversified. to put that into real-money terms, if you invested $5,000 for 50 years at a 10.1% return, you'd have $614,000. but a 2015 study from blackrock found that millennials might have as much as 70% of their money in cash, meaning a savings account, a pillowcase, old sneakers. the best way to do that is not by dumping your money into apple stock, but with low-cost index and exchange-traded funds. history illustrates this: a portfolio of 100% stocks had an average annual return of 10.1% between 1926 and 2015, according to a study by vanguard. that's a problem, because investing the money you save is nearly as important as saving it in the first place. if your income is lower now than it will be later   a likely scenario for many young professionals   you're locking in at lower tax rate. many of us are frightened or confused by the topic and even inclined to put our money in a sock and call it a day. investments that require you to take on risk, like stocks, have to offer you a premium for doing so. 5 essential investing moves for millennials if you believe recent reports from the web, you probably think millennials are financial floozies, trading their retirement money for venti lattes. there might be heartache in the day-to-day, but in the long run, you'll be glad you stuck it out. khan academy is a good place to start, as is nerdwallet's guide on how to invest in stocks. there are plenty of resources to guide you through the basics; you just have to put in the time. you can learn more about building a diversified portfolio in nerdwallet's piece on investing in your 20s. if an index fund's expense ratio is more than 0.25%, you can likely do better with another. factor in inflation   a force that millennials may soon notice for the first time in their adult lives   and you're actually losing money. at this age, you should have most of your long-term savings invested in stocks. that $5,000 becomes just $8,000 at a 1% return; in your shoe, it stays $5,000. wells fargo data show that of those who are saving, half are putting away 6% of their income or more. put a lid on fees you can't control the ups and downs of the stock market. what we're not so hot at, according to many of these same surveys, is investing. until you learn what you're doing, it feels an awful lot like gambling in vegas without the free drinks. sure, but that's unlikely when you're in it for the long-term. keep transaction costs down by limiting unnecessary trading and using commission-free and no-transaction-fee funds. say hello to risk risk is kind of like that friend who regularly cancels plans but always comes through in a pinch. morningstar has a good, if slightly dated, investing classroom, and online brokers often have a ton of beginner-focused educational materials on their websites. a portfolio of 100% bonds returned roughly half that, averaging 5.4%. at a 5.4% return, you'd have just $69,000. every dollar that goes to these costs is a dollar that reduces your returns. at today's historically low interest rates, it's all roughly the same. those funds pool investor money to buy many different investments in one swoop. most brokers will have a list of both types of funds. get an education at least this one will be free. in investing, more risk means the potential for more reward. to see how valuable that is, use a roth ira calculator. here the american veterinary medical association supports the procedure, but "only after attempts have been made to prevent the cat from using its claws destructively or when its clawing presents an above normal health risk for its owner(s)." the veterinary procedure has been offered for many years, but that could cease to be the case, at least in new york, if legislation to ban the practice goes though. "it's the equivalent of taking a cigar cutter and cutting the end joint off," veterinarian jennifer conrad, who helped lobby for the cause, told a daily freeman reporter. declawing your cat could become illegal if you live in this state depending on who you ask, cat declawing is either feline torture or a necessary evil. to that, assemblywoman linda rosenthal, who is sponsoring the bill, says: "i've heard so many times: 'i have expensive furniture! to remove them, vets have to cut through tendon and nerves in order to fully remove the nail and bone. the human equivalent, as the human society of the united states describes it, is "cutting off each finger at the last knuckle." most popular many cat owners opt for the procedure to avoid a cat's destructive behavior, particularly against their furniture. the gravity of the procedure is why lobbyists are hoping to make it illegal in new york. for those who don't own cats, declawing may sound like simple nail clipping, but it's a very serious medical operation. this ban marks the first time the issue has reached statewide level in the u.s, the associated press reports. the bill is currently with the senate and assembly, but no voting date has been determined, reports the huffington post. i have nice drapes!​ if your standard is, 'i need pristine furniture,' don't get a cat." but when the alternative is condemning the cat to a shelter or to death? conclusion i started out this test as a sceptic, but after winning two apple products for less than 20% of their value, i can say without any doubt that this new form of online shopping is a great way to save money on high tech, expensive products! i started out this test as a sceptic, but after winning two apple products for less than 20% of their value, i can say without any doubt that this new form of online shopping is a great way to save money on high tech, expensive products! after researching which one of the different competitors to test, in terms of trustworthiness and reliability, i came to the conclusion that swoggi seemed to be the best candidate to serve as an example for this new form of online shopping, due to its excellent reputation. the workings of this new type of shopping can be intimidating at first, so i will try to explain in a few steps how you can get the same savings achieved. the starting price being extremely low, you only need a few credits to get amazing discounts, which can go up to 90% of the retail value of the products!
