why americans think we are having stronger storms most americans think climate change, and more frequent and severe natural disasters are linked, according to a new huffpost/yougov poll that also finds most think human activity is at least partially responsible for the changing climate. among republicans, only 15 percent said that human activity is the primary cause of climate change, although a total of 53 percent said that humans are at least a contributing factor. according to the new poll, conducted after typhoon haiyan devastated the philippines earlier this month, 55 percent of americans think climate change is related to more frequent and severe natural disasters, while only 23 percent do not. eighty-five percent of democrats said humans are at least partially responsible for climate change, including 55 percent who said human activity is the primary cause. only 10 percent of respondents said human activity is not contributing to climate change at all and 9 percent said climate change is not occurring. sixty-eight percent of independents said humans are at least contributing, but only 29 percent said they are the primary cause. in total, 70 percent of respondents said they think human activity is having at least some impact on climate change. the poll shows that the vast majority of americans think humans are contributing at least somewhat to climate change, but differ on just how much. although scientists can't say with certainty whether a specific storm was caused by climate change, rising sea levels make storm surges from hurricanes and typhoons potentially more deadly in coastal areas, contributing to increased destruction. seventy-two percent of democrats and 52 percent of independents, but only 39 percent of republicans said that they are related. the huffpost/yougov poll was conducted nov. 14-15 among 1,000 u.s. adults using a sample selected from yougov's opt-in online panel to match the demographics and other characteristics of the adult u.s. population. the poll finds that 28 percent of americans think typhoon haiyan specifically was caused by climate change. another 36 percent said human activity is not the cause, but contributes to climate change. another 32 percent said it was not, and 41 percent said they weren't sure. but only 34 percent said human activity is the primary cause. forty-four percent of republicans said that they're not. factors considered include age, race, gender, education, employment, income, marital status, number of children, voter registration, time and location of internet access, interest in politics, religion and church attendance. but republicans and independents were less convinced.
the ups and downs of the campaign had gnawed at wiles for weeks when she took over following a campaign shake-up that left her in charge of winning must-win florida without much of a budget to advertise or turn out republican voters who tend to disproportionately cast absentee ballots by mail. despite hillary clinton’s large margins in miami-dade county and broward county, trump ran up the score elsewhere in the state -- from the deep south panhandle to the interior of florida to peninsula’s southwest, a bastion of working-class whites and retirees from the midwest who pushed him over the top. donald trump’s stunning win in florida was a microcosm of what unfolded nationwide on tuesday: despite losing big to hillary clinton in diverse, urban areas of south florida, trump dominated in every other corner of the state and outperformed past republican candidates with older, white and blue collar voters. but after that, as election day votes poured in, trump began building a margin that stretched to more than 100,000 by 8:30 p.m. by 9:10 p.m., trump’s margin started to peak at just under 150,000 votes over clinton. two weeks ago during a meeting at trump’s golf club in doral, sources said, wiles successfully made the case to trump to spend more on mail, advertising and paid callers to reach out to more republican absentee ballot voters. by the end of the night, trump’s lead was so big that, even if turnout in florida was modeled at 80 percent – far higher than recent elections – clinton would still not win if she beat trump by double digits. with nearly all precincts reporting,trump carried a nearly insurmountable 134,000 vote lead – 1.4 percentage points -- leaving democrats crushed and trump’s team elated with a win that, at one point, they felt wouldn’t come. he held vote leads of 144,000 in naples-fort myers market, 126,000 in the pensacola market, 83,000 in the panama city market and 58,000 in the orlando market, which anchors the eastern end of the i-4 corridor. trump began election day down by at least 57,000 votes to clinton, according to results posted on the florida division of elections website just after the last florida polls closed at 7 p.m. central time. trump’s strength was no surprise to republican party of florida chairman blaise ingoglia, who earlier in the day said republicans had more energized voters who couldn’t wait until election day to cast ballots. instead, trump had his outsized personality, his knowledge of florida – his second home where he owns the palm beach mar-a-lago estate – and his plane that could carry him to any spot on a moment’s notice in florida, where thousands of supporters materialized for his rallies seemingly spontaneously. by tuesday morning, democrats felt confident they could ride out the wave of what they knew would be a surge of republican voters who tend to vote in greater force on election day. she won a stunning 571,000 more votes than trump in the miami-fort lauderdale media market, one of ten in the state, according to state elections data posted after midnight. one of trump’s pollsters, tony fabrizio, said the results showed that clinton exceeded president obama’s margins in the florida markets he won in 2012. trump ran up huge margins with white florida voters -- who comprise 64 percent of the state’s voting rolls -- and have always been the most reliable voters in terms of turnout. "this was a data defying feat that captured a populist fervor we just couldn’t measure," said one republican pollster who was surprised by trump’s numbers. new: how trump won florida with more than 95 percent of precincts reporting, donald trump carried a 140,000 vote lead in florida. but not fast enough for the liking of democrats, who just two hours before were musing about how trump had lost florida and therefore the white house. though obama won the state twice, both times were by narrow margins built on the strength of his appeal to minority voters in the state. trump’s campaign initially didn’t run a robust absentee-ballot program to get voters to fill out and mail back their votes. in early october, as hurricane matthew left part of the state damaged, wiles realized the campaign had mistakenly not run an absentee ballot program at all. now democrats face a bleak prospect of the coming midterm elections, when liberal-leaning voters tend to stay away from the polls while republicans keep voting. the spending was noteworthy because trump, notoriously tight-fisted with campaign money, believed that campaigns dropped too much money on tv and get-out-the-vote "ground game" efforts. clinton allies expressed increasing optimism about their chances in the state heading into election day, energized by early vote results that showed hispanic turnout exploding. sen. nelson’s team fears a showdown with scott, who has won twice based on the strength of white voters and an outsider message. "the difference here is that trump did far better than mitt romney did in almost every county on election day," fabrizio said. trump’s positions put him at loggerheads with the spanish-language powerhouse network, univision, which has studios in the same city as his doral golf club. you could make an argument that his past statements [about immigration and illegal immigrants] made it impossible," said curt anderson, top adviser to gov. the size of the vote was historic in populous democratic strongholds like broward, miami-dade and palm beach counties. their outsized support counteracted the votes of hispanics and blacks – 16 percent and 13 percent of the voter rolls, respectively. black and hispanic voters cast record numbers of absentee ballots and flocked to the early voting polls. her tone was a 180-degree turn from early in the evening when she called the day "tense and nerve wracking." she won three lesser markets: west palm (a 44,000-vote lead); gainesville (10,000 more votes) and tallahassee (11,000 more votes). trump blew away records in the tampa bay media market, the western edge of the vaunted i-4 corridor that helps swing elections. but even with all of the new trump spending, hillary clinton’s campaign began to surge. sweden recently voted down an initiative that would have implemented a relatively generous basic income for adults on top of the country’s existing social services, britain’s labor party is considering advocating for a basic income, finland may implement a version of ubi next year, and a city in the netherlands is also pursuing a basic income experiment . some on the political left have supported ubi a tool to redistribute wealth to the poor and provide a means to improve people’s quality of life, while some on the right have seen it as a way to make the existing welfare state more efficient while promoting individual choice and reducing "welfare traps." while it’s far from mainstream acceptance, ubi is viewed by some as a means to provide workers with economic stability as an increasing amount of the world’s labor is automated. another concern is whether providing a basic income is the best way to spend public funds that could be specifically targeted to certain groups in need, the model most welfare programs currently follow. sending money to every single citizen is expensive, so most ubi proposals involve some limits on who is eligible for the money — minors and the already-wealthy, for instance, might get smaller checks. a recent oxford university study found that as many as 47% percent of jobs are at risk of being computerized (although another study found that number may be as low as 9%). "i think we are moving towards a world with less job security," says matthew krisiloff, who is managing y combinator’s ubi study. in its most pure form, a government would send all citizens a certain annual income to everyone, regardless of their salary, age or employment status, typically in installments throughout the year. "there’s political consensus around it, and there’s relative simplicity in the sense that it’s just direct cash and you can spend it however you want." a recent however, a confluence of factors have started to push basic income into the mainstream. "i think part of the reason it’s back in vogue is because people are more accepting of unconditional programs," he says. rising inequality and persistently slow economic growth have spawned concerns about the ability for working people to get ahead without increased assistance, for instance. limits aside, the general point remains the same: (almost) everyone gets a check from the government to spend without restrictions. y combinator’s krisiloff says the newfound discussion of a basic income represents a fresh attitude towards government welfare programs. why this tech company is giving 100 people free money the firm is about to give about 100 people between $1,500 and $2,000 every month to spend on whatever they please. however, a confluence of factors have started to push basic income into the mainstream. the program, to be carried out in nearby oakland, is meant to test a scheme called universal basic income, or ubi. "people are starting to think there are more cost effective, less paternalistic, hands-on ways to help." many worry that a basic income could reduce the incentive to work, slowing the economy. meanwhile, advances in automation and artificial intelligence have raised the prospect of a future with significantly fewer jobs for human workers. no nation has implemented a universal basic income, but the idea has gained traction in a few countries. despite sporadic support on both sides of the aisle, ubi has historically remained on the policy fringes. here’s what you should know about ubi: what is universal basic income? the basic concept has intellectual roots dating back to at least the 18th century . in reality, it gets a little more complicated. why is it popular? is anyone getting paid yet?
the global gender gap report ranks 136 countries (which collectively contain over 93 percent of the world's population) based on 14 indicators used to measure the size of a nation's gender gap in four key areas: 1. in a year that has brought us national conversations about working women, leaning in and whether or not the patriarchy is in fact "dead," you might expect that all this talk signaled a real improvement for gender equality in the united states. this year the united states ranked 23rd and received a score of 0.7392, nearly the same as in 2012 when the u.s. ranked 22nd with a score of .7373. as always, these rankings show us the places where we have made incredible progress when it comes to gender parity in the u.s. -- and the areas where there is still much more work to be done. but the u.s. has a serious gender issue when it comes to politics, receiving a score of .159 for overall political empowerment, mostly because we have so few women in legislative and ministerial positions. where the u.s. really seems to falter is not in educational attainment -- we have near-perfect gender equality when it comes to enrollment in primary, secondary and tertiary educational institutions. in fact, there are 22 countries where women have far more parity with their male counterparts than women do in the u.s. according to the 2013 global gender gap report released on oct. 24 by the world economic forum, that, unfortunately, is not the case. and though we ranked an abysmal 67th when it came to closing the wage gap, overall the u.s. ranked 6th for economic participation. canada, with a score of .7412. according to the report's authors, the index scores represent the "percentage of the gap that has been closed between women and men." political empowerment, which examines the number of women holding political office as well as the number of female heads of state over the last 50 years. sweden flickr: mr phil price 2013 score: 0.8129 in 2012, sweden ranked #4 and don’t forget that supermarkets have actively undermined our national food handling experience and skill by telling us that we’re too "time poor" to cook from scratch, largely because it is much more profitable for them to sell us value-added, processed foods whose apparent freshness is validated by reassuring dates. if the untouched remnants of last week’s order are stacking up in the fridge when the supermarket van arrives at our door, most people will consign them to the bin, schooled to believe, thanks to supermarket use by and best before dates, that judging freshness is best left to distant experts. ideally, from a supermarket pr point of view, the term "food poverty" would appear in every headline that contains "supermarket food waste", for that allows our giant retailers to bask in the role of philanthropists who use their corporate might for the common good. but sell-by dates – the progenitor of use by and best before – were introduced by supermarkets as stock rotation tools, to help clunky, mammoth chains keep tabs on the unprecedented amount of product passing through their system, not primarily as safeguards against food poisoning. what’s more, the red herring of food poverty draws attention further away from one essential fact about supermarkets we must digest if we are ever to make any progress: waste is hard-wired into the supermarket system. once we sniffed the milk and pared mould off cheese; now we live in dread of food poisoning four decades on, it’s becoming obvious that supermarkets are incapable of delivering this promise. there aren’t, to my knowledge, any robust statistics on levels of food waste in british households before the supermarket era, but i’d hazard a guess that they were much lower than they are now. on the day that his chain’s depressing results were published, chief executive dave lewis addressed a food industry summit where he exhorted food manufacturers to do more to reduce their waste across the supply chain. probably wisely, the others don’t publish their waste figures, but let’s just assume that if they had a better story to tell us, we’d already know all about it. the bottom line here is that such dates are absolutely no guarantee that food is truly fresh or safe, yet they shape our daily decisions about what we eat and what we bin. just in case you aren’t finding the plot line 100% credible, a further emotional strand is woven in: tesco promises to redistribute all its unsold edible food to charities from 2017. there you have the dramatis personae in tesco’s food waste script: profligate consumers, suppliers who earn a "must work harder" rating, and enlightened tesco, leading the vanguard in the national war on waste. they encourage us to hazard a weekly guess about what we’ll consume, rather than focusing on what’s in our fridges and larders day-to-day. our rubbish bins really started filling up when, instead of shopping for a little, as was needed, every day or two, we were persuaded to adopt the one-stop supermarket shopping trip. they promised vast economies of scale by virtue of their collective buying power and state-of-the-art distribution logistics that would bring every agricultural product on the planet to our shelves, 365 days a year. if we are to stop waste at source, we must look to and learn from the burgeoning grassroots initiatives that aim to relocalise and scale down our food chain. battalions of quangos, non-governmental organisations, government agencies and charities see supermarkets as allies in the war on food waste, but in reality, they are a huge part of the problem. crumbs from the rich man’s table is a shallow, and too easily self-aggrandising response to the unacceptable reality that millions of fellow citizens can’t afford to eat good, fresh food. when the supermarkets began colonising the uk grocery market in the early 1980s, they appeared to be a newer, more efficient way of feeding the nation. yet again supermarkets point the finger of blame at the stupid, sloppy home cook who fails to slay the bacteria through thorough cooking, rather than eradicating infection at their factory farms. if you’re finding that figure hard to envisage, it’s the equivalent of 119m meals, and an increase of 4% on the year before. once we sniffed the milk and pared mould off cheese, now we live in dread of poisoning. so supermarkets egg us on to overlook what we already have and to buy much more than we need. around two thirds of their raw chickens are contaminated with potentially lethal campylobacter at the point of sale, even though they are well within their use-by dates. putting a gloss on your waste problem by repackaging it as a food poverty solution is a tactic increasingly deployed by our major supermarkets. tesco’s waste tally is certainly grotesque, but pr executives expert in techniques for smoothing over corporate difficulties would doubtless applaud the masterly way tesco deflected criticism. who needs parades of small, independent shops when chains can feed us so much more efficiently, and for less? this precision shopping model, we were assured, would produce dividends for consumers in the form of lower prices and more convenient shopping. from this we can deduce that tesco’s voluble commitment to reducing its edible detritus has yet to yield results. "while the majority of food waste arises from the home, industry recognises the need to lead by example." theoretically, armed with a list, we could buy all the food we needed for a week. after deftly passing the waste ball back to his supply base, lewis reprised a favourite supermarket refrain: blame the consumer. but is tesco any worse in this respect than any other supermarket chain? they are retail dinosaurs, locked into a system that’s riddled with problems. far from discouraging it, the supermarket business model actively begets it. it places a halo of saintliness around all their business activities. l ast year, ast year, tesco’s food waste mountain amounted to 59,400 tonnes . [th guardian] we shoppers aren’t to blame for food waste. nowadays, supermarket online ordering makes that even easier to do. but a waste prevention strategy should never be confused with a poverty reduction strategy. undoubtedly, certain foods sold by supermarkets do pose a very real risk to health. one such glaring issue is food waste. just press the same-as-last-week option. guess who is. better safe than sorry, surely? why?

"the textbooks market is broken and students are paying the price," ethan senack, a higher-education associate at us pirg, told us news & world report in 2014. one of the biggest ways college students are ripped off is getting out of control college affordability has recently become the preeminent issue in higher education, as student-debt figures have hit staggering levels. the us public interest research group (us pirg) conducted a survey of 156 different college campuses across 33 states and found that 65% of students decided against buying a book required for class due to its high cost. and the high prices are beginning to discourage some students from purchasing textbooks for their classes, despite the fact that they realize it may hurt their grades. they can, however, mitigate the rising cost of textbooks by looking for alternatives, such as buying used books and selling their books after the course has come to an end. since 1977, the price of college textbooks has more than tripled the rate of inflation, meaning a 1,041% rise, according to nbc news, which cites bureau of labor statistics data. "[students] can't shop around and find the most affordable option, meaning there's no consumer control on the market," senack said. some publishers contest the idea that textbook prices have risen exorbitantly, claiming that what may look like stark increases in percentages actually represent more modest increases in whole dollars. they have to buy whatever books they're assigned," nicole allen, a spokeswoman for the scholarly publishing and academic resources coalition, told nbc. but most conversations center on ballooning tuition costs, rather than a less well-known expense that strains the wallets of college students: textbooks. and 94% of those students acknowledged that they were afraid that the move would hurt their grade. still, students and experts following the trend say that the prices are becoming prohibitively expensive. "they've been able to keep raising prices because students are 'captive consumers.'

he explained that he doesn’t feel uncomfortable doing nothing, if nothing has captured his interest - and it’s better to do nothing than waste time trying not to waste time. the secret to being successful is a lot easier than you think if you’re reading this in bed after a lie-in don’t worry. lewis said he doesn’t see laziness as a trait to avoid, because it focuses his efforts on the things that matter. this is coming from the man who’s written six books in the last ten years, while also working as an editor at vanity fair – so his advice may be worth listening to. laziness, he said, stops you from wasting time on things that aren’t worth your time. if you mistake busyness for importance, which we do a lot, you're not able to see what really is important. michael lewis, author of the big short, told the audience of the insight summit that being lazy isn’t necessarily a bad thing. he said: people waste years of their lives not being willing to waste hours of their lives. something has to be really good before i'll decide to work on it. laziness might not be a terrible trait after all. if you can be  bothered, that is. in fact, it can make you more successful. my laziness serves as a filter.

how stephen hawking has lived so long with als an expert on lou gehrig's disease explains what we know about this debilitating condition and how hawking has beaten the odds editor’s note: renowned theoretical physicist stephen hawking died on march 14, 2018, at age 76. it's now well recognized that 10 percent of these patients can develop degeneration in another part of the brain, such as other parts of the frontal lobe that don't contain the motor neurons or the temporal lobe. we spoke with leo mccluskey, an associate professor of neurology and medical director of the als center at the university of pennsylvania, to find out more about the disease and why it has spared hawking and his amazing brain. most patients with als—also known as lou gehrig's disease, for the famous baseball player who succumbed to the disease—are diagnosed after the age of 50 and die within five years of their diagnosis. if he really isn't on a ventilator, then it's his biology—it's the biology of his form of the neurodegenerative disease that determines how long he will live. it's just an incredible, incredible example of the variability of the disease—and the hope for patients who have it that they could also live a long life. for much of his time in the public eye, though, he has been confined to a wheelchair by a form of the motor-neuron disease amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (als). this story, originally published on his 70th birthday on january 7, 2012, is being resurfaced to explain how he beat the odds and lived so long with the disease amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (als). how much do you think stephen hawking's longevity has been due to the excellent care that he has received versus the biology of his particular form of als? these are controlled electrically and are synaptically connected to motor neurons that reside lower down in the brain—as well as motor neurons that reside in the spinal cord. als, which is also known as a motor-neuron disease—and colloquially as lou gehrig's disease in the u.s.—is a neurodegenerative disease. i'm sure there are also at-risk genes for als, but there are now multiple genes that have been identified as potentially causing the disease. beginning in 2006 it became clear that like a lot of other neurodegenerative diseases, als was determined by the accumulation of abnormal proteins in the brain. the guys in the brain are called the upper motor neurons, and the guys in the spine are called the lower motor neurons. one thing that is highlighted by this man's course is that this is an incredibly variable disorder in many ways. however, pathologically, if you do an autopsy of a patient, they will have evidence of deterioration of upper motor neurons. but that means that half the people live longer, and there are people who live for a long, long time. one of the misconceptions about als is that it's only a motor-neuron disease, and that's not true. and the other thing is the deterioration of swallowing muscles, and that can lead to malnutrition and dehydration. if you don't have these two things, you could potentially live for a long time—even though you're getting worse. he's a very good example of the sparing of the non-motor parts of the brain that can occur. why has hawking lived so long with this malady when so many other people die so soon after diagnosis? juvenile-onset is diagnosed in the teenage years, and i don't know enough about his course to say. each one of them are interesting in that they lead to the accumulation of different proteins in the brain. the other classic syndrome is called progressive baldor palsy—or progressive supranuclear palsy—which is weakening of cranial muscles, like the tongue, face and swallowing muscles. hawking obviously has quite the active mind, and previous statements that he has made seem to indicate he has a pretty positive mental outlook, despite his condition. has he lived so long because he got the disease when he was young and had the juvenile-onset type? each muscle is controlled by motor neurons that reside in the brain in the frontal lobe. hawking's condition was first diagnosed when he was 21, and he was not expected to see his 25th birthday. i have patients in my clinic who were diagnosed in their teens and are still alive in their 40s, 50s or 60s. there is also primary lateral sclerosis—pls—and clinically it looks like an isolated upper motor-neuron disorder. and since 1985 he has had to speak through his trademark computer system—which he operates with his cheek—and have around-the-clock care. but it's probably something similar to juvenile-onset disorder, which is something that progresses very, very, very slowly. and it was thought for quite some time that these disorders were limited to motor neurons. is there any evidence that lifestyle and psychological well-being do much to help with patients' outcomes? i just know him from television, so i don't know what kind of interventions he's had. the disease causes weakness of either upper motor neurons or lower motor neurons or both. the famous theoretical physicist has helped to bring his ideas about black holes and quantum gravity to a broad public audience. what have we learned about the disease recently that might help us find one—or at least better treatments? stephen hawking turns 70 on sunday, beating the odds of a daunting diagnosis by nearly half a century. but not having ever examined him or taken a history, it's a little hard for me to say. it's been known for quite some time that there are variants of als. knowing specific genes gives us particular mechanisms in the brain, and would potentially give us targets for therapies. life expectancy turns on two things: the motor neurons running the diaphragm—the breathing muscles. for trouble swallowing you can elect to have a feeding tube placed, which basically takes malnutrition and dehydration off the table. so some of these patients can actually develop dementia, called frontal-temporal lobe dementia. what does stephen hawking's case mean for people who have the disease? and he is currently the director of research at the school's center for theoretical cosmology. what is als—and is there more than one form of it? it appears to be an isolated illness of the lower motor neurons. how frequent are these cases of very slow-progressing forms of als? hawking spent 30 years as a full professor of mathematics at the university of cambridge. but like his mind, hawking's illness seems to be singular. but his disease seems hardly to have slowed him down. unfortunately, it's a small percentage of people for whom that actually happens. however, pathologically they also have lower motor-neuron disorder. those are the four classic motor-neuron disorders that have been described. it's now clear that that's not true. what has stephen hawking's case shown about the disease? or is the disease usually too quick for that to make a difference? but mostly it's about the biology of the disease. on average people live two to three years after diagnosis. ten percent of als is genetic and based on a gene mutation. i would say probably less than a few percent. it's probably a little bit of both. what's happened to him is just astounding. so the common way people die is of respiratory failure. but none of this has given us any robust therapies yet. but it pretty much always spreads to limb muscles. one is referred to as progressive muscular atrophy, or pma. i don't believe that adds to longevity. als still doesn't have a cure. he's certainly an outlier.
although the scientists were actually looking at manganese oxide for some of its electronic properties, one of their reactions inadvertently birthed a new pigment: the catchily named "yinmn blue." he added: "then one day a graduate student who is working on the project was taking samples out of a very hot furnace while i was walking by, and it was blue, a very beautiful blue. not only that, the highly reflective properties of the new pigment means it could be used in paints that could help keep buildings cool by reflecting infrared light. subramanian told artnet in a recent interview that the pigment has become a popular choice among artists because of its vivid color and resistant properties. this burst of blue came about when scientists at oregon state university (osu) heated manganese oxide, along with other chemicals, to over 1,200°c (2,000°f). the paint manufacturers shepherd color company have also licensed a patent and is now selling samples of yinmn blue. additionally, unlike prussian blue or cobalt blue pigments, it doesn’t release cyanide and is not carcinogenic – that's always a plus. after being heralded as "the creation of a near-perfect blue pigment," this coincidental eureka moment is now being manufactured for artists’ brushes. he added: "our pigment is useful for art restoration, because it is similar to ultramarine but really more durable." "basically, this was an accidental discovery," said mas subramanian, a milton harris professor of materials science in the osu department of chemistry, in a statement. the findings of the original study were published in the journal of the american chemical society. back in 2009, a lab full of chemists stumbled across a new pigment, more or less by sheer chance. scientists accidentally discover a new color, and it's beautiful! "our work had nothing to do with looking for a pigment. this pigment is far more stable when exposed to heat or acidic conditions. so, what’s so special about this blue? [h/t: mental floss] [h/t: mental floss] [h/t: mental floss] i realized immediately that something amazing had happened."
research has shown the benefits to sleep of manipulating and controlling exposure to blue light: a study of 20 adults who wore either blue-light blocking or ultraviolet-light blocking glasses for three hours before sleep found that both sleep quality and mood improved among those in the group who wore blue-light blocking glasses, compared to the ultraviolet-light blocking group. being aware of the effects of nighttime exposure to light and making some basic changes to bedtime routines can go a long way toward getting you the darkness you need to sleep well, even in this ever-bright modern age. a study of 94 office workers found that daytime exposure to blue light during work hours resulted in improvements both to sleep and to daytime functioning, compared to exposure to white light. blocking this color light may help you sleep better the disruptive effects of artificial light on sleep are well documented, and have received an increasing amount of attention in recent years -- with good reason. rather than switching on hallway or bathroom lights -- and flooding your system with melatonin-suppressing light -- use low-illumination night lights to guide you when you need to get up in the dark. daytime exposure to light -- both sunlight and artificial light -- can help strengthen circadian rhythms and boost daytime alertness, leaving you better prepared to sleep when the time comes. but you don't need special goggles or eye lens implants to protect your circadian rhythms and your sleep from the negative effects of artificial light. you don't have to sit in a pitch-black room, but you should think about beginning to limit your exposure to bright lights, whether from your computer screen or your television. nighttime exposure to artificial light -- which for the great majority of us happens without much thought or awareness -- disrupts the body's circadian rhythm, altering the 24-hour biological clock that controls our sleep-wake cycle. in a study by scientists at quebec's universite laval, nightshift workers used blue-light blocking glasses at or near the end of their overnight shifts for four weeks. studies have shown that blue wavelength light has uniquely harmful effects on humans and suppresses melatonin levels more vigorously than other light wavelengths. in particular, research in recent years has shown that blue wavelength light is especially harmful to circadian rhythm function. research investigating blue-light blocking -- most often in the form of goggles that filter out this particular wavelength of light -- has shown promise. this area of research is critically important, and i expect we will see a great deal more investigation into the effects of blue wavelength light on sleep and health. but there are other, less-invasive ways to filter out blue-light that are also being investigated by sleep scientists. here are some low-tech suggestions that can help you: limit exposure to artificial light in the hours before bed. while nighttime exposure to blue wavelength light is damaging to circadian rhythms, exposure to blue light isn't always detrimental. scientists at china's sichuan university studied the effects of blue-light blocking artificial lenses implanted during cataract surgery. in addition to wreaking havoc with sleep, disruptions to circadian rhythms also have been associated with a number of serious diseases, including cancer, diabetes, depression and heart disease. the study subjects -- 26 women and 14 men, with an average age of 74 -- were given artificial lenses with blue-light blocking capability. the last 1-2 hours before bed should be a time of winding down and preparing for sleep. subjects who were exposed to blue light experienced improvements to daytime alertness, mood, and concentration. blue light is emitted by electronic devices, energy-efficient light bulbs, and other common light sources. cataract surgery commonly involves removal of the eye's damaged lens and insertion of an artificial lens. make the last 60 minutes of your bedtime ritual electronics-free -- and keep electronic gadgets and devices out of the bedroom altogether. a new study of cataract patients indicates that artificial lens implants can help improve sleep. they found patients' sleep had improved significantly across several measures: patients were sleeping more during the night. cataracts are a common condition among older adults -- approximately 60 percent of people over the age of 60 experience cataracts. at the end of study period, their overall sleep amounts increased, as did their sleep efficiency. shift workers are at especially high risk for circadian rhythm disruptions because of their non-traditional schedules. these subjects also experienced decreases in daytime sleepiness and they slept better at night. if you're using a tablet to read, bring the screen's brightness level down. the study involved 40 patients who required surgery for cataracts in both eyes. if you need access to light in the middle of the night, use small nightlights. daytime exposure to blue light can stimulate alertness and help sleep later on. decreasing your exposure to light is an important part of this process. the number of subjects who met the criteria for "poor sleepers" had decreased. unfortunately, many energy-efficient light sources produce high concentrations of blue light. researchers assessed patients sleep quality before surgery and again two months after surgery. their levels of daytime dysfunction due to sleepiness had diminished. lens replacement surgery is necessary for cataract patients. their sleep quality had improved. get light exposure during the day. reading under moderate lamplight is fine.
it is the second 'spoon' to be found on mars in recent years, with alien hunters claiming it could be proof of developed life on the planet. forget whether or not there is water on mars - if this photo is to be believed, there is fresh beer on the red planet's surface. on the red planet, one of the most famous is the 'face on mars' spotted by one of the viking orbiters in 1976. vigilante mars 'anomaly hunter' thomas miller, 64, spotted the strange shape while he was sifting through curiosity's latest snaps of the red planet. in december last year, nasa's curiosity rover took footage that appeared to show a large spoon on the red planet's surface. an eagle-eyed mars 'anomaly hunter' has spotted a strange object that looks like a green bottle in nasa rover imagery. the curiosity video was uploaded to youtube by ufo hunter account 'secure team' with the description: 'there is a giant spoon on mars! 'this find is exceptionally clear; the design of the bottle is a bit different but recognisable,' mr miller, a canadian musician, told mailonline. the pictures were taken by nasa's spirit rover during a mission on the surface of mars in november 2007. given the thousands of images of mars, you are bound to find something that looks a bit unusual,' he told mailonline. 'of course there's no way to know for sure it's a beer bottle, i'm going out on limb calling it that. 'if someday we visit their planet it would be nice to think we could sit down and have a beer with them.' 'i think they are looking for anything out of the ordinary, and our minds like to see patterns in things. the bizarre bottle shape appears to have a red, green and white label and even a cork or cap at the end. the anomaly hunter found the bottle while browsing through panoramas of nasa images stitched together by other mars enthusiasts. 'usually clearer pictures or those taken from a different angle show that such anomalies are really rocks or tricks of the light.' but nigel watson, an alien expert and author of the ufo investigations manual, is sceptical of the bottle find. scroll down for video  pareidolia is the psychological response to seeing faces and other significant and everyday items in random stimulus. and some users were amazed at the discovery - one said: 'wow, it couldn't possibly be natural, could it?' there have been multiple occasions when people have claimed to see religious images and themes in unexpected places. the strange bottle shape is not the first oddity to be spotted on mars. other objects such as rings and gloves have also been found in recent years. some folk see the face of jesus in tea-leaves, others see the man in the moon.' 'i think it is evidence of current habitation on mars,' he told mailonline. it is a form of apophenia, when people see patterns in random, unconnected data. i tend to see artifacts on the martian surface as part art gallery and part garbage dump.' 'we find trash, tools, machine parts, bits of paper, as well as sculpture and carved stone tablets. is this image proof of beer on mars? however, others were more sceptical, suggesting it could be an optical illusion. one user commented: 'we see what we want to see. this was later proven to just be a chance alignment of shifting sand dunes. this thing is amazing! probably left over from a lost civilisation.'

here's why summer in new york city smells so awful for travelers with the gleam of the big apple in their eye, nothing seems better than new york city in the summertime. new york city has the highest population density in the us, and with 8,550,405 people roaming the nation’s melting pot, it’s bound to get smelly. to many, new york is the city of dreams, but you have to be willing to accept it for the good, the bad, and the smelly. but even after most of this waste has been incinerated across the river, strong winds can still carry the stench back over to the city on a hot day. garbage piles up in dumpsters until it can all be taken across the hudson river to be incinerated in new jersey, or, if possible, recycled locally and overseas. with such an insanely huge number of people living in just one city, it should come as no surprise that there is also an insanely huge amount of garbage produced. although residents of the city produce 12,000 tons of waste every day, new york city doesn’t have any of its own landfills or incinerators. let this sink in: that’s the same as driving around the earth 312 times, and that's just for one city. here's why it's hard to escape the stench of the city in the heat of summer. there also has to be a way to get all of it out of the city. all this driving only adds to pollution and the greenhouse effect, causing the city to become warmer and smellier as time continues. you may also be wondering why those subway vents on every block smell so much more putrid on a steamy summer day. it turns out the combination of heat and humidity allow bacteria to grow faster and smells to travel further. a census conducted in july 2015 showed that the city had a population density of over 27,000 people per square mile. but long-time city dwellers know the horror behind the mystique: those awful smells that dominate every daily commute to and from the office. or how it is possible to smell a food cart from all the way down the street. restaurants have outdoor seating, there are festivals all over town, and you don't have to worry about bringing your jacket to top of the rock. so when you get stuck with one those incredibly humid we should all be interested in what will create the best learning environment for all these kids, for all these little people who will be making big decisions some day like what to do with your social security or how to fix your city infrastructure or how best to treat that cancerous mass in your body. i invite you to join a class when they do a simple sorting and gluing project that gives the kids one more opportunity to understand all the "-augh" words and their various pronunciations and watch multiple children go through half a stick just for that one project. i mean, are we willing to take a step (or 200) backward and fill in gaps caused by something as silly as a distracted kid (who then distracts others) because he can’t find a glue stick to finish his project? watch kids "clean" the floor at the end of the day and, in a rush to get home, throw away all the "trash" they found, which includes half used pencils and crayons that would take too long to find a home for. and if it’s teaching your kid how to multiply better or be able to compose a sentence without referring to spell check, isn’t that extra $10 a little worth it? i mean, who in their right mind thinks it’s a good idea to request that our kids purchase expo markers in bulk or boxes of kleenex that should be supplied already? get in a classroom and watch children solve problems at their desks (sometimes on them) with them and really engage in the process because it all of a sudden became colorful and perhaps a little bit taboo. i’m not going to buy just the one extra box of tissues because (let’s all be honest here) i can afford more than that. supplies that were an extra $10 from you at the beginning of the year for one kid become extras in your kid’s teacher’s cart at target during a grocery run. and yes, the theory is that you teach them to use less, but let’s be honest: some just use what they use. why i won't buy one extra box of kleenex for my kid's school supplies so we started doing the school supply shopping this week. we act like we’re doing the schools and the teachers a favor when we fill that backpack with tissues and markers. i guarantee if it is something that will actually get used to educate your children, the teacher will be able to explain how. and yes, we went through school without some of these things, but these kids are more accustomed to bright and shiny. add to that the hysterical mobs crowding the $1 pencils like they were the last chance to win tickets to a 21 pilots concert, and we have a joyfest that keeps on giving. glue sticks that still have some in them but are not the easiest to use just aren’t worth it anymore. if you don’t agree with something on the list and think it’s excessive, have a conversation with the teacher. i’m frustrated that we can’t see just how big a job these incredibly underpaid teachers are undertaking. gone in my house are the days when the most expensive item on the list was the ever-elusive "just this size" binder. well, then, haven’t i done a good deed for the year for less than the cost of a coffee? do the right thing and thank that teacher for all the efforts to make our future decision-makers great ones. the supplies are no longer new and shiny, and more than a few have met their untimely trash can demise. dry erase markers are dried up because they have been used to solve, spell, create. and if bright and shiny go away, attention spans shorten, and kids are more disruptive. i put on my thickest armor because nothing will be just right for my kids. does your job ask you to shell out a couple hundred bucks to upgrade your software or buy staples? you think you have to buy too many glue sticks? multiply that sucker by – how many kids were in that classroom? used and broken crayons look better in that circular file than in pencil boxes. who thinks it should be my job to bring ziploc bags to school? but i sigh, watch the ads, and get out there and do it. a daunting task even as the kids get older and the lists get shorter. the kitty folders are too childish; the more mature ones are $200 a piece. and *gasp* what if someone other than my precious timmy uses them? aren’t they the ones doing us the favor? so, my suggestion is to watch for sales and stock up. kids don’t learn as well then. and let’s talk about that list, shall we? pencils that have no erasers have lost their appeal. especially when those might not get used by my kids? how free dlc helped turn a small steam game into a hit keeping dlc mostly free has keeping dlc mostly free has worked well for big developers like cd projekt with the witcher 3 , who can garner reams of publicity from players used to being nickled-and-dimed to death by other big-budget releases. they recently published a blog post about how that’s gone for them as it turns out, the as it turns out, the first free dlc —which included 70 new events, a new main quest line, new building types, new voice acting, an event editor, and a bunch of smaller features—didn’t up sales enough to justify tearing off the price tag. they recently published in the wake of a more successful than expected launched (the game recouped costs within a day of release), its developers decided its major dlc packs would be free. in the wake of a more successful than expected launched (the game recouped costs within a day of release), its developers decided its major dlc packs would be free. "working with a publisher was a huge saving grace here, as we did not carry the costs of the localization which the publisher invested in, to eventually regain from the box sales. our sales this month had a +1572% increase from the previous month on steam, and while the sale is likely the main culprit here, we still think combining the two was the jackpot." "if like us, you have a small team, limited resources and a tight budget that simply cannot stretch to huge marketing campaigns, you need to think outside the box. it’s more of they’ve since released another piece of dlc that’s, well, not really dlc at all. thea: the awakening is a turn-based 4x strategic survival game inspired by slavic mythology that came out late last year. create a good product, respect your client and the rest will fall into place—sounds idealistic, but it certainly worked for us and i am sure it can work for you." "the dlc was free and about 8,000 of our players have enjoyed it within the first two weeks after the release. we stuck to our deadlines, used a faster service to do our shortened localization, and we released the multiprayer dlc during the steam summer sale. is a turn-based 4x strategic survival game inspired by slavic mythology that came out late last year. "people began to create forum threads encouraging others to buy thea for their friends," the developers wrote, "organised their own giveaways and even doing their own community translations." free dlc can be good for players and developers, but developers have to be strategic about it. sales after the dlc brought about 10,000 euro above what we were usually selling without the dlc, and normalized in about 10 days." "the cost of development of this dlc ended up being around 90,000 euro," thea ’s developer wrote. they’ve since released another piece of dlc that’s, well, not really dlc at all. this one added multiplayer, and they decided to release it close to the steam summer sale, to drum up additional interest. you probably have heard of it, but folks who like it really, really like it. still, for us, the giants did not prove to be a huge financial hit and it was disheartening." for us, this meant putting a lot of emphasis on our community in hopes of the power of the ‘word of mouth’. for their for their second major free dlc , they decided to take a more tactical approach. sponsored "so if we were to judge things by those figures alone, we would have lost a big chunk of cash," they added. they explained: "i mentioned earlier how timing was an issue for giants, and i believe we have learnt our lesson. this strategy has paid off and we do believe it is a valid route for other indies. in the meantime, they saw players recommending the game, mentioning substantial free dlc as a big plus. you probably have heard of it, but folks who like itreally, reallylike it. it was made by four people with a bit of aid from a publishing partner. despite that, they decided to stick with their free dlc plan. it’s more of a glorified donate button that grants players some snazzy cards. "the indie market is a tough one," they wrote. the thea team’s takeaway from all of this? what happens, though, when a steam indie takes a similar approach? it’s currently got 1,053 reviews on steam, of which 90 percent are positive. game-changing dlc, it seems, will remain free. sounds like it worked. some even went a step further.
mad men suggested every cable channel should have its own scripted drama series in development — and now they pretty much all do contrast that to today, when a show like the americans can't get the same sort of readership traction as mad men (even though it has a loyal, dedicated audience that likes reading about it), simply because there's so much more stuff out there. mad men also benefitted from the rise of tv recapping in general thus, there was a huge opening in the "reading about tv on the internet" marketplace that was beginning to boom in the late 2000s, and mad men filled it as surely as it filled the slots vacated by sopranos at the golden globes and the emmys. this is why the media can’t stop writing about mad men one of the most consistent criticisms of mad men from those who aren't mad men fans is that — sniffs derisively — it's only beloved by the coastal media elite, because it's about rich white people who live glamorous lives and work in advertising. the mad men audience overlaps so neatly with the audience of people who read about tv on the internet that the venn diagram of the two might as well be a single circle this has carried right over to vox. 3) there just wasn't as much good tv on when mad men started, it was popular to suggest that the end of the sopranos, the cancellation of hbo's deadwood, and the impending end of the wire signaled the end of tv's golden age. but the kinds of people who read our websites are also far more likely to want to take a deep dive into the latest episode of mad men than they are to want to read a careful analysis of even several episodes of ncis. but, really, in that summer of 2007, the established shows worth writing about were few and far between — especially if you didn't want to publish weekly, in-depth reviews of comedies (a later development, largely driven by content-hungry sites like, well, the a.v. 4) mad men was actually pretty popular, when all was said and done though it never pulled in big bang theory numbers, amc told vulture's joe adalian that at the show's height, a total of just under 7 million people watched it. the mad men audience overlaps so neatly with the audience of people who read about tv on the internet that the venn diagram of the two might as well be a single circle. this most recent season of that fx drama received the kind of acclaim mad men did in its heyday — but it's much, much harder for a series to cut through the noise from all those other shows out there. that number's not insignificant, and even a tiny percentage of that audience consistently reading pieces about the show online would be more than enough to drive significant traffic to most websites — especially back in 2007, when the overall online readership was smaller. that strain of criticism became all the more pronounced in the buildup to the amc drama's series finale, with vulture launching the latest broadside against the show's popularity as author michael idov argued that it wasn't truly popular, just overhyped. we write a lot about the show because there's a huge audience out there ready to devour mad men content — far beyond any other show i've written about here that's not game of thrones. lost was the king of the recap roost at the time, but those who wrote about it usually focused more on grand, unified theories of why the show worked, rather than the sorts of symbolic interpretations the sopranos invited. 2) mad men debuted right after the sopranos ended and filled the void the show left when mad men began, in the summer of 2007, the sopranos had ended just a few weeks before. those of us who write about television do too often ignore the shows that a majority of americans are actually watching, shows like the big bang theory and ncis and even empire. but by season two, the awards and critical attention mad men garnered ended up boosting those numbers to more comfortable levels, and even if the show was never a smash hit, it had a long, healthy run. that number would explode in years to come — and mad men was a natural fit for publications that wanted to write tv recaps and people who wanted to read them. but tv sites have said that about a lot of shows over the years, and few of them held up, readership-wise, as well as mad men did. yes, the early push might have been a bit much, but mad men ended up having the goods — at least for the people who cared about it. 5) never underestimate passion as my colleague matthew yglesias wrote about the popularity of bernie sanders' presidential candidacy online, a small but rabidly passionate audience for a particular topic can be lifeblood to a website that craves readers. yes, the huge explosion of commentary in the days preceding the show's finale was driven by how much many of us in the media liked the show. mad men suggested every single cable channel should have its own scripted drama in development — and now they pretty much all do. the show was consistently among the top five series we wrote about in terms of readership, and a well-timed thinkpiece always had the potential to blow up. early on, the media positioned mad men as a sort of lifestyle choice the media is, of course, at least somewhat complicit in this. the first season's viewership numbers dipped below the 1 million mark a few times — a much more perilous event in an age when dvrs and streaming services were less prevalent. alan sepinwall began his seminal blog what's alan watching in late 2005, and by that final sopranos season, dozens of publications were dipping their toes into the recap waters. early on, we positioned the series as a sort of lifestyle choice — if you were cool, you would watch mad men. thus, it was easy to get the "serious tv" audience to tune in to mad men, because there weren't a ton of other options. instead, mad men and later breaking bad picked up that ball and ran with it, while fx entered the early stages of a hot streak that continues to this day. 1) readers wanted to read about it in my pre-vox life, i was the tv editor of the a.v. the answer to why the media keeps pushing mad men on the people is simple: the people keep pushing it on us. back when the series debuted, the media wrote about mad men to a level far exceeding its actual ratings. still, there are a bunch of good, mostly reductive reasons for the media to keep, in idov's words, shoving mad men down readers' throats. but it was also driven by the fact that our readers wanted to see this sort of material. the wire (never as popular in terms of raw readership numbers, though no slouch itself) would end in early 2008. what holds true for sanders is also true for mad men: there are very few casual mad men fans. club, a position that gave me unique insight into what sorts of tv a meta-analysis of 32 randomised control trials, involving around 2,100 people, found bigger reductions in total cholesterol (a mix of good and bad types) and ldl cholesterol when plant sterols were added to margarines or spreads derived from canola or rapeseed oil, rather than sunflower or soybean oil. a review of eight trials that included 350 people consuming high phenolic olive oil found medium effects on lowering blood pressure and small effects on lowering oxidised ldl (a type of ldl), with no significant effects on total or ldl cholesterol. in contrast, another trial randomly selected over 7,400 men and women at high risk of heart disease to follow three diets: the mediterranean diet plus extra-virgin olive oil, or mediterranean diet plus nuts, or a control diet (low fat). avoid junk food  in our study, we found people were able to make a number of smaller changes across a range of the foods that lower blood cholesterol levels, including increasing nuts, soy foods and plant sterols. in a recent trial, 47 men and women were randomised to substitute 4.5 percent of their usual foodintake of olive oil or butter for five weeks, and then crossed over to the other group for another five weeks. in a review of 25 intervention trials, eating approximately 67g of nuts a day (about half a cup) led to a 5.1 percent reduction in total cholesterol and 7.4 percent for ldl. after 4.8 years follow-up, those in both the olive oil and nut groups had a 30 percent lower risk of heart attack, stroke or death from heart disease compared to controls. one caution is that half a cup of nuts contains about 400 calories (1600kj), so you need to eat nuts instead of another food, or eat less each day but have them every day. plant sterols compete with two other types of cholesterol for absorption from the gut: pre-made cholesterol, which is found in some foods like prawns, and cholesterol, which is made in your liver. here are 5 foods to eat and avoid high fat, low fat, no carb, more carb: when it comes to getting information on eating to manage high blood cholesterol, confusion reigns. more than 80 percent of olive oil's healthy compounds (called phenolic compounds) are lost during the refining process, so less refined varieties, such as virgin olive oil, are a better choice. a big study examined changes in diet quality scores and heart disease risk in 29,000 men from the health professionals follow-up study and 51, 000 women from the nurses' health study (1986-2010). eat plant sterols, margarines and spreads  plant sterols, or phytosterols, are chemically similar to blood cholesterol and are found in some plant foods, including nuts. the results of 26 randomised control trials (the gold standard of research trials), which included 1,037 people who had either normal or high cholesterol levels, were added together. this is equivalent to one small can or about a third of a 400 gram (large) can of baked beans. but the biggest change people made was cutting back on energy-dense, nutrient-poor foods (junk foods) and eating a wider variety of healthy foods. those who had the biggest improvement in their diet quality score had a 7-8% lower risk. the most recent australian health survey found fewer than one in five australians ate them on the day of the survey. when it comes to heart disease risk factors, get your cholesterol and blood pressure checked next time you see your gp. a review concluded that two grams of plant sterols a day leads to an 8-10 percent reduction in ldl cholesterol. researchers found total cholesterol and ldl-cholesterol levels were significantly higher after consuming butter compared to olive oil. eating more nuts, legumes, plant sterols (molecules found in plants) and olive oil helps lower blood cholesterol. use olive oil  olive oil is a major component of the mediterranean diet and the predominant source of fat. eat nuts  nuts are high in protein and fat, but the amounts of polyunsaturated, monounsaturated and saturated fat vary. they are concentrated from plant sources and then added to some commonly eaten foods such as margarines, spreads or milk. it didn't matter what type of nuts people ate; the more nuts, the bigger the cholesterol reduction. the soluble and insoluble fibres assist with lowering cholesterol absorption in the gut, while they promote growth of beneficial gut bacteria in the large bowel. we checked the most recent research from trials that tested the impact of specific foods on blood cholesterol. eat legumes  legumes and pulses, including baked beans, kidney beans, chick peas, lentils and split peas, can help lower cholesterol levels. the data showed ldl cholesterol was reduced by 5 percent in response to eating 130 grams of pulses per day. the reduction was biggest in those who had high blood cholesterol to start with. this 'competition' process lowers the total amount of cholesterol that eventually ends up in your blood. people with higher ldl cholesterol at baseline or who were not overweight had a bigger improvement. after four years of follow-up almost 11,000 people had a heart disease 'event'. the type of fat the plant sterols are mixed with is important. you can check your diet quality using our healthy eating quiz. they lowered their cholesterol, lost weight and lowered their blood pressure. this means you tend to eat less when they're part of a meal. switching to a healthier spread makes sense for those with high cholesterol. legumes and pulses take longer to digest compared to processed foods. discretionary foods (aka junk) raise blood cholesterol, especially bad cholesterol (called ldl). over a third of australian adults have high cholesterol. they lower blood cholesterol in a number of ways. olive oil contains a high proportion of monounsaturated fat. if you don't, ask your gp to check it. pulses are high in vegetable protein and fibre. do you know your blood cholesterol level? do you have high cholesterol? the sales taxes, like the one in pennsylvania, are applied when a customer uses a billing address in a city or state with an applicable sales tax. i cant even afford to pay tax on a bagel how do you think im gonna pay for this — not ricky (@ricky_tran_) august 2, 2016 when and how to tax consumers buying services and goods from internet companies has long been a difficult question to answer. though it's called the netflix tax, colloquially at least, the fee will also apply to streaming and downloads for music, e-books and apps. netflix even battled in kentucky over telecommunications taxes there, a way some states have tried to tax digital services without imposing a sales tax. the state legislature there recently extended its 6 percent sales tax to digital downloads and subscription services like netflix and hulu. one bill to charge online sales take, the marketplace fairness act, has been debated for years and remains up for debate. amazon avoided charging sales tax for years before starting to charge it in some locations. so if you want to avoid the netflix tax, borrow a billing address outside the state. pennsylvania joins a select group of locations that have begun to put local taxes on digital services. at least until the netflix tax comes for us all, that is. chicago already has a similar 9-percent tax, often called its "cloud tax." similar taxes have come up in canada. pennsylvania is taxing netflix spotify and apple music. digital goods are also taxable in minnesota. digital versions of newspapers, magazines and the bible, will be exempt. amazon now collects sales tax in 28 states. watch out: the "netflix tax" is coming. the 'netflix tax' is starting...but where? at least in pennsylvania.

livingston pointed out that, since younger demographics have tended to delay marriage -- the average age of first marriage is now is about 27 for women and 29 for men, as opposed to 21 for women and 24 for men in 1960 -- perhaps this group is content to cohabit with partners or advance the relationship in other ways, rather than jump into marriage number two. "maybe newlyweds don't look quite as fresh-faced as they did in the late '60s," livingston said, noting once again that 40 percent of today's newlywed couples involve at least one person who's been married before. but not everyone is jumping to remarry -- after combining the hard data on remarriage patterns with the results of a recent pew survey about marriage, livingston found that specific demographics are actually less likely to remarry than others. "the older you are, the more likely you are to have ever remarried, because you have more time in your life to have married once, gotten divorced or widowed and found someone else and remarried," livingston said. younger americans went the opposite direction: 75 percent of people ages 25 to 34 and eligible to remarry were remarried in 1960, while only 43 percent of that same demographic were remarried in 2013. livingston analyzed data from the 2013 american community survey as well as the 1960 and 1980 censuses and found that the number of remarried adults in the us has hit 42 million, which is almost double the amount recorded in 1980 and triple the amount in 1960. while only 34 percent of those who were 65 and older (and eligible to remarry) had remarried in 1960, 50 percent of that same demographic had remarried in 2013. if you consider that 39 percent of first-time newlyweds (and 21 percent of remarried couples) are within a year of each other's ages, this age gap among remarried couples becomes particularly noteworthy. for one, the divorce rate is higher now than it was in 1960, so the number of people who are, as she put it, "eligible" to remarry has also risen. livingston said it's quite possible that widowed or divorced men have more motivation to jump back into a new marriage and regain those aforementioned comforts. when pew polled participants for the aforementioned survey on marriage, they asked single men and women who had been married before if they would be willing to marry again. another interesting finding combined both age and gender: in remarriages, 16 percent of couples involve a husband who is at least 10 years older than his wife. in comparison, 43 percent of women said they'd be willing to remarry and 54 percent specifically didn't want to ever marry again. there was a clear gender divide: divorced or widowed men were more likely to want to remarry than women in the same position. in fact, according to pew, previously married people these days are just as willing to remarry as they were back in 1960. new data reveals who's likely to get married more than once good news for romantics: the divorce rate may be dismal, but remarriage is on the rise. according to new findings from the pew research center, 40 percent of marriages involve one spouse who's been married before. "there's so much dialogue right now about the retreat from marriage in general," gretchen livingston, senior researcher at pew and author of the study, told the huffington post. it's very possible that this younger group of contemporary divorcees and widows hasn't soured on the institution of marriage completely, however. a majority of once-married, eligible men -- 65 percent -- either expressed a desire to remarry or were still considering it. while today's divorce rate might make newlyweds of the 1960s cringe, that doesn't mean that today's society has lost faith in marriage. (but it's worth noting that the divorce rate peaked in 1981 and has been slowly declining and leveling off ever since.) there are two demographic shifts that can account for this general surge in remarriage, according to livingston. "but i think it's very striking and just another example of how the definitions of family and the norm are changing." the more influential factor in the high remarriage rate, however, is a longer life expectancy for partners, particularly among baby boomers. but don't make too many assumptions about newlyweds -- it's a demographic that's still in flux. overall, women were less likely than men to want to walk down the aisle again. only 30 percent of men were completely against the idea of a second walk down the aisle. among those who are divorced or widowed, age made a big difference in desire to remarry. previous studies have suggested that men enjoy more health benefits, relationship satisfaction and economic perks from marriage than women do. in 20 percent of new marriages, both spouses have previously said "i do." this age gap falls to a mere 4 percent in first-time married couples. taken together, these findings can add more detail to an ever-shifting image of the american family. "i was really curious to juxtapose that with what's going on with remarriage." age wasn't the only differentiating factor, though.

as explained via a recent blog post by krebsonsecurity, there are websites that can read the barcodes on your boarding pass and provide someone else access to your travel information--your phone number, frequent flyer number, and information not only about the flight in question but also all future flights booked through the same number. you're heading somewhere exciting and you just can't wait until you get there to share the news with your friends on social media. with access to your boarding pass, someone could even change your seat on the plane, cancel any future flights, and reset your account pin number. you may love your friends, but would you trust everyone you know on facebook or twitter with your private travel information? so you snap a picture of your boarding pass and post it to facebook. the takeaway here: don't post pictures of your boarding pass on social media. because the information printed on your boarding pass actually reveals a lot more than you think. the one thing you should never do with your boarding pass you're at the gate. you've got your boarding pass. didn't think so. maybe not. harmless, right?
what’s come to be known as the "delaware loophole" — the unassuming building at 1209 north orange street — has become, as the guardian described reportedly dozens of fortune 500 companies — coca-cola, walmart, american airlines, and apple, to name a few — use delaware’s strict corporate secrecy laws and legal tax loopholes by registering the north orange street address for official business. "a magnet ... which individuals and corporations can use to evade an inestimable amount in federal and foreign taxes," as a delaware’s incredibly business-friendly structure that allows for such a crowded address is completely legal, though the ability to create shell corporations lends to shady dealings and isas a report by the institute on taxation and foreign policy has described. trump and hillary refuse to explain why they both share the same address (antimedia) wilmington, de — as it turns out, hillary clinton and donald trump share something pertinent in common, after all — a tax haven cozily nested inside the united states. while the legitimacy of taxes as a concept may be up to personal interpretation, what matters in clinton’s use of the so-called delaware loophole, in particular, is her constant harping on the need for corporations and elite individuals to pay their fair share. "big corporations, small-time businesses, rogues, scoundrels, and worse — all have turned up at the delaware address in hopes of minimizing taxes, skirting regulations, plying friendly courts or, when needed, covering their tracks," the new york times’ leslie wayne "it’s easy to set up shell companies here, no questions asked." in fact, some have claimed — all revelations of panamanian documents aside — the use of tax-friendly locations inside the u.s. makes it the biggest tax haven in the world, with delaware, alone, costing other states some $9 billion in lost taxes over the past decade. as rupert neate explained for the guardian, being registered in the tiny state allows "companies to legally shift earnings from other states to delaware, where they are not taxed on non-physical incomes generated outside of state." of the 515 companies trump officially registered with the federal election commission, "we have 378 entities registered in the state of delaware," the billionaire told the guardian, "meaning i pay you a lot of money, folks. "some of you may have just heard about these disclosures about outrageous tax havens and loopholes and superrich people across the world are exploiting in panama and elsewhere," clinton "we are going after all these scams and make sure everyone pays their fair share here in america." and, as the guardian notes, both of "the leading candidates for president – hillary clinton and donald trump – have companies registered at 1209 north orange, and have refused to explain why." as it turns out, hillary clinton and donald trump share something pertinent in common, after all — a tax haven cozily nested inside the united states. still, clinton’s constant moralizing on tax transparency — and her spokesperson’s claims she hasn’t benefited from the north orange street address — proves, yet again, her stances offer little in the way of a solid foundation. according to neate, a clinton spokesman explained, "zfs [holdings, llc] was set up when secretary clinton left the state department as an entity to manage her book and speaking income. why, if what the spokesman claims to be true, would clinton bother using an address in delaware? clinton has repeatedly touted the needs for tax transparency and to shut down foreign havens with similar loopholes. no federal, state, or local taxes were saved by the clintons as a result of this structure." this brick-and-mortar, nondescript two-story building in wilmington, delaware would be awfully crowded if its registered occupants — 285,000 companies — actually resided there. in other words, clinton’s employment of north orange street amounts to a telling,. "famous for helping tens of thousands of companies avoid hundreds of millions of dollars in tax." the’ leslie wayne described in 2012. do as i say, not as i do. clinton told the pennsylvania afl-cio annual constitutional convention earlier this month. i don’t feel guilty at all, ok?" oh, the irony.
