however, sgt kempton said that for rank and file officers, policing cannabis was another matter, and that many officers sympathized with the path taken by durham police in going easy on low-level cannabis offenses : "with dwindling resources, forces are having to focus their limited numbers on areas which represent the greatest harms to wider society. but after years fighting at the apex of the drug war, his conclusion—and that of other experienced officers who have chosen to speak out—must be heeded if we want to find a solution to a problem that has been trashing communities around the world for decades. but the reason it's worth doing is because the drug is not just about the drug trade: it's weapons, terrorism, people trafficking, money laundering; it straddles the spectrum of the most serious crimes, such as murder, kidnapping, serious assault—which all go hand in hand with the drug trade. over the years writing about the drug trade, i've met drug cops who have told me that their job is similar to that of the drug user or trafficker—a series of almost addictive drug bust "hits" that perpetuate the game. when i went stop and searching in soho with one of the met police's sniffer dog teams in 2013, i was surprised to hear from a regular beat officer and his colleague that they thought cannabis should be legalized entirely. to the anti-drug teams bacon shadowed, heroin dealers were one of the most despised groups in society, so much so that they were seen as "police property"—objects that police could do with as they wished. one detective sergeant told bacon: "sometimes i think we're like those [japanese] soldiers in world war ii—you know, those ones on the island who just kept fighting because they didn't know the war was over. yes, people can feel demoralized that they've put themselves on the line, and then someone ends up getting just a coupe of years, but that's the way it is sometimes." he spent two years embedded with drug detectives in a town and a major city (the identities of which are secret) in the uk and wrote about his experiences in taking care of business , published last month. despite all this, there was acceptance—often expressed by officers off-duty after a few pints—that they were not waging a "war on drugs," but managing an unbeatable problem in order to "keep the public happy." it will also make it easier for heroin and crack users to get the help they need and free up police time to go out on patrol and deal with other crimes," he says. i call up simon kempton, a police sergeant from dorset who has specialized in drug enforcement and sits on the national board of the police federation, a body that represents rank and file officers. there are some who have crossed the line completely to become dependent drug users themselves, and others who are disgusted by the stigmatization of drug users and even dealers. "the logic of the drugs war only leads one way: the police get smarter, so the criminals get nastier; things can only ever go from bad to worse, from savagery to savagery," says woods. woods' book will open the public's eyes to the raw violence and canniness of the drug world, and the lengths police will go to in order to disrupt it. good cop, bad war is the story of an undercover police officer, neil woods, who spent over a decade infiltrating britain's biggest drug gangs. but within this, recreational drug users, social dealers, and nightclubs were far less of a crime problem than alcohol, a drug which few officers had a problem with. on the surface, it's a counter-intuitive line to take for a senior officer working within an agency for which the drug trade is a key target. expressing sympathy for anything other than hardline prohibition—even to their colleagues—is something of a risk in the black and white, "them and us" world of police culture. while policing cannabis is still a legitimate action, i believe most officers and the public would support a focus on other areas of crime." the more we try, the harder it gets: increased enforcement keeps these people looking over their shoulder; they become more covert about their activity, and that makes our job harder." in 2012, a former undercover officer who disguised himself as a heroin user-dealer, told me: "it made me realize how bad cops can be to drug addicts. the book , released last week, provides a unique insight into a world of mind games and violence, where the drug trade acts as a production line for the creation of ruthless gangsters. one female drug cop i spoke to told me: "there are some pretty nasty pieces of work out there, but some of them are just ordinary people. fisher's solution is to take the portugal route: decriminalize personal use of all drugs, from cannabis to heroin, and look at legalizing production and supply. photo courtesy of neil woods i spoke to mike fisher*, a senior drugs investigator for britain's organized crime busting bureau, the national crime agency (nca). now, after having left the force, he is chairman of leap uk (law enforcement against prohibition), a pro-drug legalization activist group consisting of ex-law enforcement officials. "a lot of people say drug addicts and drug dealers are scum of the earth, but they don't know anything about them."  photo: andoni lubaki fisher tells me that arresting people on the streets for drugs is an endless cycle, and that it's the same with the larger fish.  photo: marco tulio valencia drug cops, who saw themselves as "elite crime fighters," had sufficient respect however for the the mr. bigs of the drug world. to gauge what they truly think about their daily task, you need to be a fly on the wall—so that's the exact position that university of sheffield criminologist dr. matthew bacon took. he agrees with woods—that the drug trade houses the most violent people in the country—but believes prohibition is crucial to taking them out. they saw those who ran professional outfits and had families at home as worthy adversaries, and a "good collar" for which they would earn respect among their colleagues. he asked for his name to be changed to avoid disciplinary action, as his views will definitely not be found anywhere near the pages of the nca's annual report. even so, every now and then drug cops open up about the realities of clearing the streets of dealers and drugs. surprisingly, he tells me around half of britain's elite drug detectives at nca have similar "liberal" attitudes to the drugs problem. but to what extent are woods and his colleagues at leap uk—and those currently employed in the police force—rare specimens? "law enforcement against drugs is completely ineffective and has been since the misuse of drugs act came into force in 1971," says fisher. we've spent billions of pounds trying to prohibit drugs, but there's less chance of it working than canute stopping the waves. it's perhaps not surprising, given the police's moral code, that most of the officers he hung around with viewed "junkies" as lazy, undeserving scumbags. it's rare to get a not guilty after undercover work because of all the evidence that's been gathered. "undercover police officers would not take the huge risks infiltrating gangs if they did not think it was worthwhile. british police officers reveal what they really think about the war on drugs  a met police officer with some confiscated drugs. another officer told him: "we've thrown everything at it, even the kitchen sink, but drug problems just keep getting worse. "i get it: it can seem futile when we take out someone knocking out kilos of cocaine, [who's] replaced within two hours. "i can't speak for everyone, but in my opinion drug policing is worthwhile, all day, every day," he says. in the end, the drugs are still on the streets, no matter how many people we lock up." when they assault people it's not just a punch-up outside a pub; we are talking about sending a message through retribution and torture. i was abused, assaulted, and threatened with being fitted up by having drugs planted on me on a regular basis." you have to be the scariest, biggest person on the block, otherwise they will take your money from you. these people have to protect their trade from others, so they use extreme levels of violence. but what about those drug cops working below nca level, in towns and cities across the uk? how thin on the ground are drug cops who think they are fighting the wrong fight? but it may give us more of a chance to deal with crimes such as homicide." "if someone wants to turn the sky green and the grass blue, then it's up to them. "i believe consenting adults have a choice as to what they put in their bodies. ultimately, his experiences led woods to reject the way drugs are policed in the uk. drugs were seen as being behind all that's bad in society. "if the nca stopped targeting drug gangs, it would change nothing," he explained. the official line is that drugs are under control, but they are not." all that would happen is that dealing would be more open. behind every user and runner, there's a story," she said. "we are taking out the worst people in our society. i can't see the difference between alcohol and cannabis. "whenever we remove a big guy, someone else—usually a lieutenant—replaces him within days. "the idea of the state protecting you from yourself just doesn't work. "ideally, production should be wrested from organized criminals and managed by governments." only difference is, we'd lost the war before we even started fighting." undercover drug policing is not cheap, but it's very cost effective. there are rebellious notions even among the rank and file. most officers were anti-drugs and fully supported prohibition. "they were made the scapegoat of the drug problem." "i say legalize the lot," one said. "you would see little change in the high street. "legalize it and tax it," said the other. this gave them a "righteousness" in their actions, observed bacon. "almost without exception, dealers were depicted as deplorable and dangerous outlaws," says bacon.  neil woods buying crack while undercover in 1995. as it is, drugs are freely available now. photo: tom johnson this post originally appeared on vice uk. society would not collapse.
for it to be considered kleptoparasitism, the biologist erika iyengar explains , the parasite has to steal food from the host, and the host has to suffer as consequence. but this is not the reason a seagull loitering at a food factory in gloucestershire, england, fell into a vat of it this past monday. gulls are what's known as "opportunistic kleptoparasites," meaning they don't derive 100 percent of their diets from heist but rather just steal when the opportunity arises. basically, the gulls have realized, why search for your own food when there's some perfectly good food in another animal's possession? seagulls are what biologists called kleptoparasites , animals that rob the food of other species. according to seabirds: feeding ecology and role in marine ecosystems, kleptoparasitism is a survival strategy that minimizes the energy expenditure needed to obtain food. and a big vat of tikka masala is an opportunity no gull can afford to miss. gulls and some other birds will steal food right from the clutches of other birds, mid-flight. (the people who were not able to eat that delicious spiced chicken because, gross, a bird was in it, definitely suffered.) this seagull fell into a vat of chicken tikka masala. birds that are kleptoparasites tend to have bigger brains than birds that live the straight and narrow. seabirds breaks down the percentage of which species of seabirds get their food from robbing. i think i can explain why chicken tikka masala is undoubtedly delicious. there are some, like the arctic skua (a.k.a. it looks like he’s trying to cosplay as an angry bird. the parasitic jaeger), that feast primarily on the food of others. and it's not just human food. and the birds can be damn cunning about it. they need to be clever to do so. perhaps you've seen photos of the bird, colored orange from his dip. (turmeric, a key ingredient in curry, contains a potent orange pigment.) but why?

he cried twice that day, once when i asked about the moment in his interrogation when he began to implicate himself in angie’s murder, and a second time when michael usry showed him a video of something that was shot for a documentary usry is making about this case. a new high-tech, controversial law enforcement procedure has some people worried it threatens the privacy of our dna cbs news correspondent anne marie green writes about how she came across this story, and the angie dodge murder investigation, which she reported for "48 hours" in "the dna of a killer." i think there are many lessons in this case, but writing strictly as it relates to the privacy of dna databases, the lesson is this: when you trade your dna for information you are also giving it away -- and the database you give it to, owns it. after getting my dna report i learned that there are a number of genealogy sites, educational institutions and companies that are willing to offer you further insight into what your dna may reveal, as long as you’re willing to upload your dna profile to them. years later, in an attempt to crack the 20-year-old cold-case murder of angie dodge, police conducted a familial dna search in that very database, and found an anonymous donor who appeared to be a very close match to the killer’s dna. a little more searching and i stumbled across a blog post about a young filmmaker named, michael usry jr. a familial search conducted by idaho falls police landed usry in a stark interrogation room, where he was grilled by detectives and asked for his dna, without any explanation. both men said they knew nothing about the murder of angie dodge , both men had their dna tested and both men did not match that of the killer, yet one man went to prison and the other man went home. there is nothing wrong with wanting to know where you came from and what your genes can tell you about your health; just make sure you know what you are signing up for. that search sent me down a rabbit hole that lead me to the story of michael usry jr., a young filmmaker who became a suspect in the angie dodge murder investigation. police hunting for a killer in a high-profile murder case wanted to use his dna to search new york state’s criminal database for a relative of his. how his father had participated in a genealogical study through their church, giving a sample of his dna to a public database, which was later purchased by ancestry.com. i first learned about the 20-year-old murder of angie dodge in a roundabout way, after getting my dna analyzed by one of those commercial dna databases. the infamous "grim sleeper," lonny franklin jr., had a son who was serving time on a felony weapons charge, and his dna had been uploaded to the california criminal database. as i talked with michael usry, he told me he was very angry about being caught up in the investigation, but he was even angrier about something else. chris tapp, serving time for the murder of idaho teen angie dodge, shows cbs news correspondent anne-marie green what his life is like inside the... a quick search of the phrase "familial dna" and i learned authorities in california had used it to apprehend a serial killer, who had eluded them for 25 years. some of these sites charge money, while others are simply willing to analyze your dna profile in exchange for adding your profile to their database. the day both michael usry and i went to see chris tapp in prison, i was struck by how soft spoken and kind tapp was. after obtaining a search warrant for ancestry.com to reveal his name, detectives learned it was a man named michael usry sr. what if an insurance company wants to know if you carry a specific gene that could increase your chances of getting cancer, or indicates a penchant for risk taking? the interview was conducted shortly before lori was killed in a car crash, and this was the first time tapp had heard her voice since the accident. then i heard that the new york city police department was trying to get permission to do something called a "familial dna" search. if they could find someone related to him they would have a family name, making it easier to track down the killer. despite what happened, michael usry’s father does not regret participating in a dna study, but rest assured that his son never will. tapp was convicted and had at that point served nearly 20 years because of his own words, a confession he made to police. i was immediately struck by the fact that michael usry jr. and chris tapp had found themselves in similar situations, 20 years apart. i gave no thought to how my profile could be used by these companies or institutions down the road. there was a man serving time for angie’s murder, christopher tapp, who usry believes is innocent. one told me the type of workout supplements i should be taking, another searched public family trees for family connections. it was an interview with tapp’s wife, lori, who tapp had met and married while in prison. there was even one that promised to create a diet tailor made for me based on my dna. right now, the judicial system is playing catch up when it comes to your rights and protections, so we should all be aware and read the fine print. in the video, lori spoke of how much she admired her husband and believed in his innocence. after i hung up the phone, i started researching angie dodge’s murder and the case against chris tapp. they had already searched for the killer, but he was not in the database. when cops built out his family tree they found usry had a son. i learned that authorities had never found tapp’s dna at the crime scene. a familial search connected father and son, allowing police to finally make an arrest. but i did wonder if i could learn anything more from the dna report. i tracked usry down on facebook and asked him to call me. there were no big revelations and, just as i suspected, i am not related to royalty. what if that company goes out of business and sells the database? that was the story i pitched to "48 hours" executive producer susan zirinsky. when we finally spoke, he told the whole story. cops tracked him down and began investigating. i probably uploaded my profile to about four sites. do the protections you have been promised still stand? when i got my results back i was not surprised. how safe is your dna? what does that mean?

he had a vision for something that he could make with the ice and snow that would be much more interesting than your ordinary run of the mill snowman. when the east coast was hit with a major snowstorm, ice hockey player mitch fritz decided to take the opportunity to build something special. he started out by filling all of these bread tins with water and food colouring. he then left them out overnight during the snowstorm, so that they would freeze. using the snow as packing material to cement them together, he made this stunning colourful igloo. he places colored water in bread pans outside during a snowstorm. take a look at what he did! 3. what he makes is stunning! 2. 1.
six years before he was being driven to high-pitched distraction by those muthafuckin’ snakes on that muthafuckin’ plane, hollywood’s keenest scenery-stealer took to the screen with uncharacteristic restraint as embittered comic-art dealer elijah price, barely raising his voice above a murmur throughout (and his one concession to theatricality, the berating of a customer intending on buying a limited edition print for his kid, works as a nice metaphor for how the film wants to treats its audience like adults). nor that, as its camera glides affectionately down the aisles of comic-book stores drinking in vintage illustrations, it shows a genuine passion for the original form that is unmatched by anything that has come since (with the possible exception of sam raimi’s spiderman films). admittedly the film’s slow pacing can seem a bit strained at times, but it’s a directorial style that takes guts to pull off this effectively – and one that’s aged well over a 16-year period in which frenzied spectacle has become the new normal. the scene where he repeatedly sabotages a book store clerk’s attempts to wheel him out of the shop is a more effective, more affecting demonstration of directionless rage than any of the extravagant acts of terrorism enacted by his screen successors. bizarro looks and acts like superman but lives by the exact reverse logic: he says adjectives to mean their opposite, he sees it as a crime to do good, and so on. two years after unbreakable was released, raimi’s first spider-man film became the highest grossing film of that year, taking close to half a billion dollars worldwide and effectively igniting the superhero movie boom. we see the reluctant hero, played here by bruce willis, come to terms with his powers, use them for civic protection and watch him win the girl before finally overcoming his nemesis. it may be anathema to the box-office behemoths of today, but there’s no doubt that m night shyamalan’s film is a superhero movie in the truest sense. in today’s age of superhero movie ubiquity, it’s tempting to read 2000’s unbreakable as a bizarro version of everything that proceeded it. why unbreakable remains the ultimate superhero movie i n the superman comics there is a character called bizarro, a twisted, villainous inversion of the iconic hero. between them, these studios are working hard to ensure that the summer blockbuster season remains choc-a-bloc with superhero movies, a trend which shows no sign of letting up. and yet it by no means and exaggeration to say that unbreakable is the exact antithesis of marvel and dc’s current output. but while ledger used a manic physicality to unnerve, jackson achieves the same end through the opposite means: his resolutely undemonstrative "mr glass" is straight from the john doe school of dead-calm supervillainy. indestructible hero and indestructible villain throwing each other through brick walls ad nauseum, cgi skyscrapers reduced to cgi rubble at a rate of knots, the level of peril remaining at precisely zero throughout. the film is shot and cut with a near-maddening degree of patience, its soundtrack almost noiseless for long spells, and it resorts to eye-catching cgi not once. the present glut of cinematic universe-forging comic-book adaptations has born some decent films and some terrible ones, but none can claim to rival the atmosphere and immersion of unbreakable. it’s also significant that the other character at the heart of unbreakable is samuel l jackson’s villain. while today’s superhero movies aim for excitement via loud action and bloated narratives, unbreakable is deadly quiet, only lightly dusted with plot and told with an everyday realism that verges on mundanity. if heath ledger’s joker was so arresting because of his lack of motive, jackson’s cane-clutching baddie chills precisely because his are so plainly stated. instead, we see willis’ david dunn defeat his arch-nemesis by dobbing him in to the authorities. it is a scene of understated gravitas, perhaps the most affecting showdown of any modern superhero movie. a decade on, marvel’s list of past and prospective releases stands at 45, while dc having latterly leapt aboard the gravy train. unbreakable’s final encounter includes not a single building flattened, not a single punch thrown and lasts all of five minutes. we get both characters’ origin stories in flashback, and both are played by hollywood a-listers. for starters, it clocks in at 106 minutes and its cast barely extends beyond the four central actors. its sole fight sequence is unpleasant and ungainly, actively un-thrilling, shot from a distance in one unbroken take. "these are mediocre times, mrs dunn," jackson tells robin wright’s audrey dunn in unbreakable. remember the face-clawing tedium that was the final hour of man of steel ? the basic similarities are all there: a cloaked protagonist with superhuman strength locks horns with a scheming, criminally insane supervillain. nothing explodes, erupts or is shot at from beginning to end. there’s a great seinfeld episode based on the character. he didn’t know the half of it. it’s the preeminent blockbuster blueprint. there is no shouting. published 21 aug 2016 published 21 aug 2016 "people are starting to lose hope."

as quartz reports thursday, "around a third of all developed-country government debt—or more than $7 trillion, in terms of market value—is now trading at negative yields," meaning that buyers are willing to pay more for these bonds than they will eventually get back if they hold them to maturity. as matt o'brien notes at the washington post, low bond yields around the world can make it hard for central banks to ever raise rates, since the second they do, investors will rush to buy that government's bonds. it may even be a sign that some investors see deflation on the horizon, since a bond with a negative yield could theoretically be profitable if prices fall enough in a country. the fact that long-dated bonds are going negative also means that the markets don't expect inflation to rise much down the line, which means they don't expect world growth to pick up much either. this is playing out all over, but right now, people are looking very nervously at italy's banks in particular, which are parched for profits while sitting on a pile of bad loans. countries like germany have been selling short- and midterm debt at negative yields for a while, but now it’s happening with bonds dated for 10 years or longer. when long-term interest rates fall too low, for instance, it makes it very hard for banks to earn a profit by borrowing and lending. something crazy is happening in switzerland, and its a bad sign for the world economy harold cunningham/getty images investing in government debt used to be a boring, pretty straightforward proposition. investors are now expected to pay for the privilege of lending money to the swiss for a half-century at a time. all of which is to say: today's sub-zero bond yields are a sign of how deeply pessimistic investors have become about both the near and somewhat distant future. yields on government bonds from all around the world have been plunging thanks to anxious investors buying them for their safety. investors are basically banging down the door for the guarantee that they will only lose a little bit of money over the next decade or two. even economically wounded spain can borrow for a few years at a time and theoretically make a profit. these days, things aren't so straightforward: the sovereign-debt markets have devolved into a bizarro world of upside-down expectations. it's like a bad financial-world play on a yakov smirnoff joke: in switzerland, lender pay you! so they're willing to pay governments to essentially hold their euros or yen or swiss francs. last week, yields on all of its government bonds, out to 50 years, turned negative. among other things, that can push up the value of a currency, hurting exports and risking deflation. meanwhile, stashing cash in a vault somewhere costs money and effort—you need to cover the cost of security and storage. and if they stay down, they could create some nasty problems of their own. fifteen-year german and japanese bond yields have also drifted below zero. the world economy still feels shaky, especially after the brexit vote, which sent bond yields even lower. and in many instances, the returns have cratered below zero. for one, they don't see many other safe options. (bond yields fall as prices rise.) why are investors settling for these kinds of terms? the most mind-blowing example of this trend is switzerland. so easy, even your great uncle mort can do it. other countries are getting nearly as good deals. jordan weissmann jordan weissmann is slate’s senior business and economics correspondent. then you get back interest payment. you buy a bond. this is remarkable.

"one reason is practical because the movies are 80 or 90 minutes long, and disney films are about growing up" says hahn. now some skeptics might point out that there are also a lot of characters who don't have any parents at all – like in aladdin. but even in those films, there are side characters who have a father and no mother. but that's not the only possible reason for the lack of motherhood in his movies. belle only has a father, but he gets lost, so she has to step into that position. for as long as i can remember, disney films have been a major part of my life. and let's face it – most disney movies are about growing up. well if you've been trying to think of a reason behind this common plot structure, look no further. peter dinklage's voice-over work on this video game is pretty unbearable peter dinklage’s voice-over work in the upcoming shooter game "destiny" has not been well received. in response to the negative reception, bungie, the studio behind "destiny," and formerly "halo," has confirmed that the dialogue has been updated and will be fixed by the game’s sept. 9 release. according to re/code bungie has even offered fans a limited edition t-shirt sporting one of dinklage’s most poorly delivered lines: "the wizard came from the moon!" "every time he begins talking i’m pulled out of the game and reminded that, oh yeah, the guy who plays tyrion lannister isn’t particularly interested in convincing me to give a s**t about what’s happening around me." to be fair, dinklage’s work has been seen only in the game's "alpha" version, for early adopters. "he sounds like an actor unsure of his character, without a director to indicate who he’s supposed to be," writes a reviewer from kotaku. dinklage voices the artificial intelligence unit ghost, which follows the player’s character throughout the game, offering advice, commentary and history of the environment. unfortunately, many fans are less than thrilled with the results of the "game of thrones" actor’s voice work. watch the video above to see "destiny" gameplay footage featuring some of dinklage's terrible voice-overs. "we love that you can lean in and laugh with us," the developer wrote on its blog. on its blog, the developer told fans not to worry. check out the two videos below for even more cringe-worthy footage. "we call this a part of the climate debt owed to us, and it is needed if we are to confront climate change while still responding to the needs of people," lidy nacpil, director at jubilee south asia pacific movement on debt and development, said in a statement. the environmental groups created an online tool showing how much each country should cut emissions and how much money should be given to developing countries not fully responsible for global warming but that would be devastated by climate change nonetheless. the tool’s calculations are based on the latest international panel on climate change report, which puts precise figures on emission cuts and money amounts needed to hold an increase in global temperatures to 1.5 degrees celsius by 2025. kartha added that the online calculator shows not just what the whole world has to do to mitigate climate change but also helps answer the fundamental question in u.n. climate talks of what each country should do. the u.s. also would need to cut carbon emissions 55 percent to 65 percent, according to the stockholm environment institute, friends of the earth, and jubilee south asia pacific movement for debt and development. that means poor, populous, undeveloped countries would be the beneficiaries of funds from rich, developed nations to cut their emissions and help produce access to energy for the 2 billion people living largely off the grid. here’s how much every country would have to pay to stop climate change what would it cost to avoid a climate disaster that would affect poor countries the most? sivan kartha, a senior scientist at stockholm environment institute, said that ipcc’s numbers show that temperature increases greater than 2 degrees could have irreversible effects on the world’s climate. "that’s why they are focused on making sure the u.n. green climate fund is not established in a way that makes it easy for big multinational corporations to capture the finance there, for example." alex rafalowicz, a fellow at the washington-based institute for governance and sustainable development, said the creation of a transparent u.n. green climate fund is paramount to the plan. "based on those limits on climate pollution for the whole world, it is striking just how quickly emissions need to come down, across the world. worldwide, developed nations would have to pay more than $1.1 trillion annually to developing nations on top of massive emission reductions to keep climate change in check. to be realistic means if we want a hope of stopping climate change, these transfers have to happen. "the organizing of democratic, accessible, and people-first financing systems is a core part of many organizations’ demands," rafalowicz wrote in an email. it may be hard to do, but it’s dramatically easier than surviving 2, 3, 4 degrees of warming," kartha said. but how do we know all those billions transferred among nations would be put to good use and not squandered? the first scientific attempt to calculate each country’s "fair share" factored in historical emissions, its wealth, and its current population. that’s the realistic demand from people facing the full brutal force of climate change." for the united states, the bill comes to $634 billion owed to developing nations. "it’s not just a question of being fair. that even includes nations such as china, now the world’s largest carbon emitter. how did the environmental groups come up with such exact figures? these deep cuts have to happen. it’s about being realistic.

malaria is the number one killer of humans, so it makes sense that a mutation eventually arose that makes human red blood cells resistant to the malaria parasites, and for the gene to rise in frequency in malaria-prone populations (sub-saharan africa). we all have two copies of every gene in our body (one from mom, one from dad), and if one copy is the malaria-resistant mutant hgbs, you're fine, but if both are the mutant, you get sickle cell disease. the good news is that many other genes confer resistance to malaria, and we are also seeing leprosy and tuberculosis resistance genes appearing, too. today, 35% of people lack wisdom teeth, although the genes involved in this are unknown so we aren't quite sure why this is happening yet. our teeth aren't quite changing as fast, which is why orthodontics and wisdom teeth removal still exist ... for now. so what will we look like 100,000 years from now, assuming we still exist that far in the future? tolerance for milk is supposed to have evolved only 3,000-8,000 years ago, and is now found in nearly 95% of north europeans. primitive man would drink milk as a baby, and then never again, so the amount of lactase enzyme (which breaks down a common sugar in milk) would fall after a few years of age. as expected, the lactose-tolerant trait appears most often in the regions where dairy farming arose first and became an important part of the diet (caucasians). genetic analysis says the first blue-eyed human appeared 6,000-10,000 years ago somewhere in the black sea region. changes we are seeing include smaller brains (more efficient, not dumber), resistance to diseases, increases in adhd and blue eyes. for whatever reason, the phenotype became very popular (conferring a 5% greater chance for reproduction) and today about half a billion blue-eyed folk exist. answer by matan shelomi, organismic and evolutionary biologist, on quora: all life on earth is constantly evolving; the process doesn't stop. another famous example is hgbs (sickling hemoglobin), a gene that makes humans immune to malaria. more and more people are being born without wisdom teeth, or have their wisdom teeth erupt later if at all. originally appeared on quora: the knowledge sharing network where compelling questions are answered by people with unique insights. even if we ignore new technologies, moving off the earth, and various selection pressures, evolution still holds surprises just by chance mutation. wisdom teeth were useful before knives and cooking, when humans would probably lose molars to chewing hard food and needed the wisdom teeth as replacements. how will humans look 10,000-100,000 years from now? who can guess what evolution has in store for us ten thousand years hence? what will humans look like 100,000 years from now? thousands of genes have evolved recently (in the last 40,000 years). over time, however, humans have evolved so that certain populations will keep producing the enzyme into late adulthood. another example is the gene for lactose tolerance. more questions: this question originally appeared on quora. since we became homo sapiens, has evolution changed us in any way? ten thousand years ago nobody had blue eyes. this question originally appeared on quora. unfortunately, the same gene also causes sickle cell anemia. you can follow quora on twitter, facebook, and google+. they are getting smaller and more bullet-shaped. as living things, humans are still evolving. ask a question, get a great answer. our mouths are changing, too. darwin's theory of natural selection evolves. yes, blue eyes. more questions: learn from experts and access insider knowledge. actually, yes.
there was danger to her life due to an abnormality in the foetus coming to rescue to a 24-week pregnant woman facing danger to her life due to an abnormality in the foetus, the supreme court on monday granted her permission to terminate her pregnancy. the apex court had appointed the board of seven senior doctors to conduct a medical examination of the lady and directed it to file a report about her "condition and advisability of permitting a medical termination of pregnancy". the court said that it was not necessary to go into "medical and medico-legal aspect of the identity of the foetus and the matter is to be decided from the standpoint of the petitioner to preserve her life". the court had allowed her to abort on the basis of a medical report from kem hospital which said that foetus had serious abnormalities with slim chances of surviving the full term. on the basis board's suggestion, the bench allowed the lady to undergo an abortion and directed that the termination would be done under the supervision of the board. the bench allowed a plea of a mumbai-based 22-year-old woman to terminate her pregnancy after taking into account her medical report which of a team of seven doctors of king edward memorial(kem) hospital in mumbai. the law permits a woman to terminate her pregnancy till 20 weeks if two registered practitioners express the unanimous opinion that continuation of the pregnancy would threaten the mother's life or the foetus has severe abnormalities. the report says that the there was very little chance of survival of the foetus and the lady's life would be engendered if it was not aborted. "in these circumstances, we consider it appropriate and in the interest of justice, particularly the right of the petitioner to preserve her life, that she be allowed to undergo the termination of pregnancy. the woman approached the court after doctors refused to terminate the pregnancy as it was not allowed under the medical termination of pregnancy act, 1971. in july last year, the court had allowed a rape survivor's distress plea to abort her 24-week pregnancy citing serious abnormalities with the foetus. this is the third incident in recent years when the apex court has allowed women to abort beyond the period prescribed by law. complying with its order, the board filed a report and favoured medical termination of the pregnancy. further, the termination shall be supervised by the same medical board," the bench said. it said that the foetus was detected with anencephaly, a serious defect where parts of the skull are not adequately developed. the termination shall be done by the doctors of kem hospital. equally, rather more important, the continuance of the pregnancy would endanger the physical and mental health of the petitioner". the court said, "the foetus is not compatible with living outside the uterus. originally published in the times of india just in just in just in in other words, the foetus would not be able to survive.
these are the five latest polls rcp used to calculate trump’s narrow lead: abc news/washington post: trump leads by 2 percentage points nbc news/wall street journal: clinton leads by 3 percentage points rasmussen reports: trump leads by 5 percentage points fox news: trump leads by 3 percentage points cbs news/new york times: clinton leads by 6 percentage points these polls have different results in part because they use different methodologies for assessing public opinion. although they were all conducted during a relatively similar period of time (which is essential when trying to get a snapshot of what the public thinks now), the polls by nbc/wsj and fox news only spoke to registered voters, rasmussen interviewed "likely voters", while the abc news/washington post poll simply spoke to adults (82% of whom were registered voters). just as it took pundits a while to wake up to the fact that trump was a sufficiently popular candidate to win the republican nomination, it seems that they have also been slow to switch focus to his chances of winning the white house. although this might be the first time that trump has come out on top in the rcp polling average, he has come very close to doing so on two prior occasions – in september and december of last year. that’s problematic in itself; this election can’t be predicted on the basis of just one number, not least because a candidate’s vote share does not neatly translate to their chances of winning the white house. democratic victories in highly populous states, which have more electoral votes to award, could cause the performance of the democratic candidate in the electoral college to outstrip her or his performance in the popular vote. to understand what will happen when the country votes this november, pundits would do better to look at the electoral map, demographics and – most importantly of all – listen to the concerns of voters. part of the reason why they didn’t panic before was a belief that measuring american public opinion a long time before a national election is a bad predictor of voting patterns. for those concerned about the prospect of a trump victory, it’s been time to panic for a while – zooming out from a single statistic shows it. the polling data site realclearpolitics (rcp) takes an average of national polls that ask americans who they would choose in a contest between the two candidates (a scenario that now looks inevitable). so far, polling suggests neither candidate has a significant lead in those states which could provide extra cause for concern for those worrying about a trump win. that means that trump’s reported lead of 2 percentage points could have actually been as high as 5.5 percentage points. looking backward, rather than forward, results from the last six presidential elections suggest that 31 states are "safe" – based on the fact that the same party has consistently won them. that gap might be narrow, but it has still led some (including a senior elections analyst at rcp) to conclude "it’s probably time to panic". perhaps rasmussen reports had to adjust their findings to account for the fact that they only managed to speak to two people in iowa – we just don’t know. on sunday, rcp updated their numbers to show that trump is now, on average, 0.2 percentage points ahead of clinton. the polling average has become the go-to number for those trying to make quick sense of the state of the presidential race. polling on a pedestal all that said, the rcp polling average is not the perfect political barometer it is so often held up to be. take the abc news/washington post poll for example – those numbers have a margin of error of +/- 3.5 percentage points. for the first time, republican donald trump seems to have edged ahead of democrat hillary clinton in presidential polling. each state wields a different number of electoral votes, so it matters how a candidate’s support is distributed throughout the country. since september, clinton’s lead has fluctuated significantly from being as large as 11 percentage points to as narrow as 0.6. there’s another, much bigger problem with the rcp average, though: it’s only as good as the individual polls that make it up. unsurprisingly, polling companies are investing their time and resources in states they think might "swing" and therefore determine electoral outcomes nationally – states like arizona, florida, north carolina, ohio and west virginia. two of the polls mentioned above conducted their interviews in spanish and english – it seems that the others did not. all polls claim to speak to a "nationally representative" sample of adults, but virtually none will publish data showing where their respondents were based. clinton may be buoyed in the 2016 election cycle by traditional democratic strength in populous states such as new york, new jersey, illinois and california. in other words, there have been many other periods when trump’s opponents should have been worrying before now. once you peek under the hood, you’ll see that an average of 0.2 percentage points flattens out some very different findings. in 2008, barack obama won 68% of the electoral college vote with only 53% of the popular vote. or it could be that hillary clinton actually led by 1.5 percentage points. donald trump takes poll lead over hillary clinton – is it time to panic? rcp always takes a straight average of the five most recent polls that were conducted. they’re one reason why the footnotes in each poll mention slightly different degrees of accuracy. what does it mean and should those opposed to trump be worried? the alternative view is that preferences may be becoming hardened now, making voter behavior less likely to shift. polling is far from perfect. november is still six months away. because people change their minds. but only just. methodologies matter. why? delayed panic? languages matter too. i’d disagree.
the team, led by sascha usenko, a environmental scientist at baylor university in waco, texas, extracted an earplug from a blue whale (balaenoptera musculus) killed in a collision with a ship off the coast of santa barbara, california, in 2007 and found it had come into contact with several organic pollutants and contained high levels of the stress hormone cortisol as it reached sexual maturity. "it’s difficult to recover time-specific information on chemical exposure for almost any animal," says stephen trumble, a biologist also at baylor and a co-author of the study, published in proceedings of the national academy of sciences this week. exposure to the most persistent chemicals was greatest in the first year — and accounted for one-fifth of his total lifetime contact — suggesting a transfer of contaminants from his mother in the womb and during nursing. "some of these chemicals are no longer in use, such as flame retardants that were outlawed in 2005, but they can stick around for 50 or 60 years," says usenko. (michelle berman-kowalewskic, ph.d., santa barbara museum of natural history, santa barbara, calif.) usenko and his team are now hoping to investigate that question by analysing some of the 1,000 or more whale specimens in museums worldwide. wax inside a whale’s ear stores all sorts of useful information on the animal’s exposure to pollutants and stress levels throughout life, researchers have found. the research is "exciting", says jeremy goldbogen, a marine biologist at cascadia research collective in olympia, washington, but "the inability to distinguish baseline stress levels from those associated with anthropogenic disturbances is a limitation of the study." "if we can look at individuals that lived in an environment without some of the stresses we see now, then we could tease out the causes of the cortisol increase," he says. but it is unclear whether the overall increase was caused by natural events, such as weaning, or by human activities, such as pollution and noise. decimated by historic whaling practices, blue whales number just 5,000–12,000 individuals worldwide, and they are threatened by entanglement in fishing nets, environmental noise and pollution. scientists have long used whale blubber as a record of the chemicals that these enormous creatures absorb as they traverse the ocean. but it also records time — similarly to the rings of a tree, the wax is laid down in light and dark bands, with each band correlating roughly to a six-month period. the peak was directly after the whale reached sexual maturity, at about ten years old, suggesting stress from sexual competition. the whale earplug from a blue whale that was used in the study. during his brief life he came into contact with 16 persistent organic pollutants, including pesticides and flame retardants. chemical signatures usenko and his team identified their specimen as a male aged about 12 years. maternal transfer of pollutants is known to happen in other mammals, such as seals and humans. in baleen, or filter-feeding, whales, earwax forms a solid plug that may be tens of centimetres long and remains intact even after its death. whale earwax is a fat-rich deposit that stores the same chemical data as blubber. mercury — which can cause brain damage — spiked twice in the sample, at around five and ten years. over the whale’s life, concentrations of cortisol, a stress hormone, doubled. the male blue whale whose earplug was harvested for the study. but analysis of blubber does not indicate when chemical contamination occurred, or how long it lasted. that is especially true of the relatively rare blue whale, the world’s largest inhabitant. once these compounds enter the food chain, they are passed on and accumulate. other toxins uncovered from the earwax were probably picked up along the way. this story originally appeared in nature news. can "wax" help save endangered mammals?
a temple in mussoorie did something that helps save water without breaking tradition mussoorie may be a picturesque town of himachal pradesh but like many places in the country, it too grapples with severe water crisis. whatever may be the efforts of the government to tackle the crisis, a famous temple in the town decided to do something that is worth a standing ovation. also see download our android app and stay up-to-date the report says that at the start of the summer season – when water scarcity is particularly severe – the temple bought two dozen small vessels. according to this report in the toi, the temple officials decided to replace all the larger vessels with those of smaller sizes. "symbolic gestures like these help spread awareness of the need for water conservation," the report quotes an environmentalist as saying. the devotees continue to follow rituals and traditions, and the temple has sent out a strong message in water conservation. and this is what gave the temple authorities an idea to help save water without breaking tradition. as is tradition, people pour water over the lingam with vessels made from copper of various sizes. the town needs around 14.5 million litres per day but gets only about half of it from local springs and brooklets. thronged by scores of devotees all through the year, the temple is frequented by many shiva bhakts. they are gradually phasing out all the big and medium size vessels. sanatan dharma mandir is one of the oldest temples of mussoorie. the result is that everyone is happy, including environmentalists.

gulag archipelago by aleksandr solzhenitsyn hailed as one of the greatest nonfiction books of the twentieth century, gulag archipelago is the first-person account of soviet dissident aleksandr solzhenitsyn’s eight years spent as a prisoner inside the russian gulags for criticizing stalin and the soviet communist system in his private letters. hailed as one of the greatest nonfiction books of the twentieth century, gulag archipelago is the first-person account of soviet dissident aleksandr solzhenitsyn’s eight years spent as a prisoner inside the russian gulags for criticizing stalin and the soviet communist system in his private letters. a staunch defender of the classical "canon" of great works every thinking person must read, bloom explained how the intellectual corruption of the humanities and arts led to an erasure of students’ understanding of the proper moral order that undergirds western civilization. as the populist-conservative movement continues to grow and expand in the age of president trump, a new generation of energized voters and young people will do well to arm themselves with the intellectual firepower of the giants upon whose shoulders today’s movement rests. one of america’s most lucid conservative economists, sowell’s book draws upon everything from rousseau to hobbes to adam smith to illustrate the intellectual impulses that drive conservatives and progressives to think and act the way they do. any nobel prize winner who can string together a sentence like this deserves to be read: "if you put the federal government in charge of the sahara desert, in 5 years there’d be a shortage of sand." hayek in the age of bernie sanders, today’s young generation of would-be socialists would do well to read friedrich hayek’s 1944 classic broadside against socialism, the road to serfdom. a choice not an echo by phyllis schlafly the late great matriarch of modern conservatism, phyllis schlafly, did more to advance and win the battle of ideas than many young conservatives understand. one of america’s greatest conservative intellectuals and an esteemed twentieth-century rhetorical scholar, richard weaver erected an intellectual fortress around absolute truth long before progressives mounted their frontal assault on notions of right versus wrong, good versus evil. a member of the austrian school of economics and a winner of the nobel prize in economics, hayek warned of the totalitarian realities of socialism’s conceits. the original anti-establishment crusader, schlafly’s book argued that conservatives must be willing to fight for a voice within the republican party’s establishment leadership and helped pave a path for barry goldwater’s nomination. the closing of the american mind by allan bloom long before anti-milo rioters sparked violence at uc berkeley, a university of chicago professor named allan bloom lit academia ablaze with this 1987 classic taking the professoriate to task for eroding higher education curriculum with progressive pablum. but a conflict of visions crystalizes the stakes involved in the clash between conservative and progressive ideologies—and how radically different outcomes are when one side prevails over the other. ideas have consequences by richard weaver originally published in 1948, ideas have consequences foresaw the corrosive influences of moral and cultural relativism decades before the left harnessed those forces to undermine western civilization. the tip of her intellectual spear, a choice not an echo, reshaped the contours of american conservatism and has sold an astounding three million copies since its release over a half-century ago. a winner of the nobel prize in literature, solzhenitsyn’s ability to combine lyrical prose with piercing reportage of communism’s moral horrors are virtually without equal. a conflict of visions by thomas sowell there are no "bad" thomas sowell books, so we could have easily recommended many of his other classics. as he put it elsewhere: "a claim for equality of material position can be met only by a government with totalitarian powers." in addition to being an intellectual titan, he was a sterling writer with a knack for distilling complex topics with wit and clarity. here, then, are seven conservative classics that should be on every american’s bookshelf: 1. capitalism and freedom by milton friedman nobel prize-winning economist milton friedman redefined the field of economics. how many of these do you have on your shelf? 5. the road to serfdom by f.a. 7. 6. 2. 4. 3.
mit researches can read a book without opening the cover researchers from the massachusetts institute of technology (mit) have developed a prototype imaging system that’s able to read pages of a book without opening it. the project led barmak heshmat, a present-day research scientist at mit’s media lab, to question just how deep one could look through a closed book using terahertz waves. a decade ago, a group at mit demonstrated the ability to look through a sealed envelope using terahertz waves – the band of electromagnetic radiation between microwaves and infrared light. in terms of practicality, the team says the technique could be used to study ancient books that are so fragile that they can’t be opened without risk of destroying their contents. as technology continues to advance, the team no doubt hopes to be able to peer deeper into a book without opening it. working closely with researchers from georgia tech, heshmat and company have demonstrated the ability to identify letters up to nine pages deep. a paper on the matter, terahertz time-gated spectral imaging for content extraction through layered structures, has been published in nature communications for those interested in learning more. found is a techspot feature where we share clever, funny or otherwise interesting stuff from around the web.

it is not known for sure why kiwis may help with sleep, but researchers believe that it could relate to their antioxidant properties, ability to address folate deficiencies, and/or high concentration of serotonin. these benefits may come from the fact that tart cherries have been found to have above-average concentrations of melatonin, which is a hormone that helps regulate circadian rhythm and promote healthy sleep. researchers believe that fatty fish may help sleep by providing a healthy dose of vitamin d and omega-3 fatty acids, which are involved in the body’s regulation of serotonin. this study only identified an association and cannot demonstrate causality, but it supports prior research that showed that eating foods with a high glycemic index around four hours before bedtime helped with falling asleep. for example, a combination of a moderate amount protein that has tryptophan, a sleep-promoting amino acid, and carbohydrates may make it easier for the tryptophan to reach the brain. the best foods to help you sleep whether it’s a jolt after a cup of coffee or drowsiness after thanksgiving dinner, most people have personally experienced how food and drinks can affect their energy and alertness. when cows are milked at night, their milk has more melatonin, and this milk may be useful in providing a natural source of the sleep-producing hormone. malted milk and nighttime milk malted milk is made by combining milk and a specially formulated powder that contains primarily wheat flour, malted wheat, and malted barley along with sugar and an assortment of vitamins. with as many as 35% of american adults suffering from symptoms of insomnia, it’s understandable that there’s a strong desire to take advantage of food and drinks for better sleep. in a study, people who ate two kiwis one hour before bedtime found that they fell asleep faster, slept more, and had better sleep quality. specific foods that can affect sleep researchers, including nutritionists and sleep experts, have conducted different types of studies to try to discover the best foods for sleep. though the exact amounts can vary, nuts contain melatonin as well as essential minerals like magnesium and zinc that are essential to a range of bodily processes. at the same time, sugary beverages and sweets have been tied to worse sleep, so it appears that not all carbohydrates and high glycemic index foods are created equal. the study over a period of months found that people who ate salmon three times per week had better overall sleep as well as improved daytime functioning. in a clinical trial using supplements, it was found that a combination of melatonin, magnesium, and zinc helped older adults with insomnia get better sleep. dietary choices affect more than just energy and sleepiness; they can play a major role in things like weight, cardiovascular health, and blood sugar levels just to name a few. in one study, people who drank two one-cup servings of tart cherry juice per day were found to have more total sleep time and higher sleep efficiency. sometimes this is based on a particular research study and in other cases on the underlying nutritional components of the food or drink. the explanation for these benefits is uncertain but may have to do with the b and d vitamins in malted milk. doing so helps ensure that your food choices support not just your sleep but all of your other health priorities as well. in addition, the range of varieties of cultivars of most foods means that their nutrient profile can be inconsistent. fatty fish a research study found that fatty fish may be a good food for better sleep. however, there are some foods and drinks that may make it easier to get a great night’s sleep. tart cherries and tart cherry juice as the name indicates, tart cherries have a distinct flavor from sweet cherries. a study of adults in japan found that those who regularly ate rice reported better sleep than those who ate more bread or noodles. both diet and sleep are complex, which means there’s no silver bullet or single food that is guaranteed to help with sleep. rice studies of carbohydrate intake and sleep have had mixed results overall, but some evidence connects rice consumption with improved sleep. kiwi the kiwi or kiwifruit is a small, oval-shaped fruit popularly associated with new zealand even though it is grown in numerous countries. that said, there are indications that certain foods can make you sleepy or promote better sleep. it is popularly known as horlick’s, the name of a popular brand of malted milk powder. for that reason, it’s best to consult with a doctor or dietician before making significant changes to your daily diet. for example, some varieties of red grapes have high levels of melatonin while others have virtually none. in general, there’s a lack of direct evidence about specific foods that are good for sleep. kiwifruit possess numerous vitamins and minerals, most notably vitamins c and e as well as potassium and folate. several studies have found sleep benefits for people who drink tart cherry juice. this study focused particularly on fish consumption during winter months when vitamin d levels tend to be lower. additional research is necessary to fully identify the sleep-related effects of different carbohydrates. tart cherries may also have an antioxidant effect that is conducive to sleep. nuts nuts like almonds, walnuts, pistachios, and cashews are often considered to be a good food for sleep. turkey is an example of a protein with high levels of tryptophan. some research has found that eating kiwi can improve sleep. in the past, small studies found that malted milk before bed reduced sleep interruptions. there are both green and gold varieties, but green kiwis are produced in greater numbers. the impact of carbohydrates on sleep may be influenced by what is consumed with them. they may be sold whole or as a tart cherry juice. milk itself contains melatonin, and some milk products are melatonin-enriched. climate and growing conditions may further alter the nutrients in any particular food product. sometimes called sour cherries, these include cultivars like richmond, montmorency, and english morello. while this research provides important clues, it’s not conclusive.

stop using a heavy coverage foundation stay away from pressed powders  avoid nude lipsticks don't skip the moisturiser always do your brows with powder don't apply blush to the apples of your cheeks avoid dark eyes  beware of the blush: denise rabor, international makeup artist and founder of wow beauty, says many people believe you should apply blusher to the apples of your cheeks, which is incorrect as this can draw your face downwards. apply under-eye cream correctly: eva alexandrides, managing director and co-founder of 111skin, explains that the skin underneath the eye is a different structure to the rest of the face and thus is a lot more sensitive. the beauty blunders that are making you appear ten years older makeup is designed to make women look and feel their best - but a poor application technique could end up doing the opposite. karla advises avoiding gels and pencils - which can leave brows looking too harsh and ‘drawn on’ - and opt for a powder formula, which will give a much more natural finish. avoid dark eyes: celebrity facialist and makeup artist, nathalie eleni, says that dark kohl under the eye can look harsh if not blended so opt for a softer shadow and blend along for a softer finish. here, they share the beauty blunders that are making you appear ten years older - and reveal their top tips for ensuring your makeup works for you. avoid nude lipsticks: rupert believes this hue can make you look sallow and drained and women should choose colours with a fresher coral or peach undertone. always do your brows: brows tend to thin as we age, but having a structured brow can take years off of your face, instantly lifting and defining your eye area. don't skip the moisturiser: karla powell, mua and brand ambassador for mua cosmetics, says that applying make-up to un-moisturised dry skin can enhance your lines. 'instead, aim for a more dewy, moist look to the skin, it will help to soften those dryers areas where the fine lines can show up. stop using a heavy coverage foundation: rupert kingston, co-founder of delilah cosmetics, explains that high coverage foundations can really accentuate fine lines and wrinkles. 'rubbing and pulling at the skin as you apply the cream is a real no go and will make the bags appear worse and more visible. 'never go too dark as this can age you, aim to choose only a shade or two darker than your hair colour,' she adds. finally, give it about a minute or longer to absorb before you put any make up on top of it which will prevent any "caking" around the area.' so before applying your make-up pack on a rich moisturiser, which will leave your skin feeling nourished and smoother. if you still feel too shiny choose a micro fine loose powder and just apply to the centre of the face.' according to the top beauty gurus in the business, applying your foundation, blusher and concealer incorrectly can add decades to your looks. 'it's better to use a lighter, fresher foundation to make the skin look more natural,' he advises. 'you should actually brush blusher sparingly from your ear to halfway across your cheekbone, which will make your face look slimmer,' he said. stay away from pressed powders: rupert king maintains that they create a heavier, dryer look to the skin. 'use your ring or little finger when applying cream whilst only dabbing, tapping or softly massaging the area with sweeping strokes. 'just use concealer where you need it.'

it's logical to think that states with notoriously bad traffic would produce some of the nation's rudest commuters, and while states like new york, new jersey and the district of columbia fall in the top 10, the state with the absolute rudest drivers is tucked away in the rocky mountains: idaho. (more: the most beautiful states in the world) the study's runner-up rudest state is the nation's capitol: washington, d.c. a respondent who had relocated to the district of columbia from los angeles compared the attitude of driving to the town's politics: "self-serving, abrasive and unsafe." (more: 10 cities with the worst drivers) the survey concluded that idaho is made up of two main types of drivers -- "those who are moving so slowly that they're judged to be rude, and the aggressive drivers who speed around them and flip them off." another survey responder said that he thinks everyone in that state is just content to take their time on the roads and don't seem to have the same sense of urgency drivers in other states have. he argued that residents and seasoned drivers are familiar with the twists and turns and lack the patience for those who are navigating the state's roads for the first time. a recent study conducted by insure.com surveyed 2,000 drivers from across the country to determine once and for all which state has the rudest drivers of them all. what state has the worst drivers when ordinary conversation turns to driving, many are quick to declare drivers from their state the worst. another indicated that he wished he had a nickel for every driver who couldn't be bothered to signal when switching lanes. the imperfect marriage of these two driving types propels the gem state to the top of the list. eric leins of southern california posited that idaho's rural and mountainous terrain was to blame. rounding out the top five are new york, wyoming, massachusetts and vermont. one responder took a stab at explaining the strange dichotomy happening in the northwest. but which state can actually make that claim? and the results will surprise you.
sure, we create images in our heads of the stories we read –we engage with language, we sympathize with the characters in our books– but besides harry potter, which books should we be reading to maximize these cognitive benefits? the term "literary fiction" seems arbitrary, but kidd and castano explain that literary fiction merely denotes the level of complexity in stories and their characters (at least, that’s what it means in the context of their study). the conclusion of the study was that children who identified with harry as a character reacted to his sympathy for marginalized groups (such as "mudbloods") by becoming more sympathetic towards similar groups in contemporary society (such as the lgbt and immigrant communities). (in other words, human) versus stereotyped, simple..." through their research, they found that readers of literary fiction receive more of the empathetic benefits of reading than those who read pop-fiction or non-fiction. by engaging with a story, readers are temporarily placing themselves in a character’s shoes, therefore, the more stories you read, the more shoes you’ve tried on. and by placing yourself into the world of a great novel, you are given the chance to experience something new that could be informative in your interactions with other people. literature is not always easy, but by attempting to tackle harder books, we create new connections in our minds that we might not have otherwise. as castano explained to mic.com: "we believe that one critical difference between lit and pop fiction is the extent to which the characters are complex, ambiguous, difficult to get to know, etc. by no means are these characters simple or easy, but they do not evoke the same complicated and uncanny feelings that one experiences with nick carraway as he narrates the great gatsby. but this was only shown after these connections were explicated to the children and only if they identified with harry. the authors of another study, david comer kidd and emanuele castano, tackled this question, but also asserted that what you choose read is important! like opening a window to let fresh air into your home, literature opens up our minds to the myriad ideas that we wouldn’t be able to experience on our own! what science is saying about fiction readers will s. for most, the love of books starts in childhood. studies have been released in the past several years that have given scientists some interesting data about fiction readers and what type of fiction they should read! another experiment "conducted three studies to test whether extended contact through reading the popular best-selling books of harry potter improves attitudes toward stigmatized groups (immigrants, homosexuals, refugees)." by reading a challenging book, you’re not only becoming a smarter person, you’re also become more empathetic. but science has started looking into the effects of reading on the brain. studies are showing that readers of fiction are more empathetic towards others. your brain does amazing things while you’re reading, the breadth of which researchers are still defining. take a moment to analyze the experiences depicted as if they were your own. it’s a fascinating insight into the world of reading. and in choosing your next book, make it a tough one. reading in general helps with empathy, but literary reading amplifies this effect. they react to each other and to their environment. according to neuroscientist bob dougherty, "the right patterns of ink on a page can create vivid mental imagery and instill powerful emotions." this compassion was notably detected in children reading harry potter. for others, this love blooms later, eventually revealing the vibrant colors of a true bibliophile! they’ve done experiments, ran mris, polled, and surveyed, all to what end? in 50 shades of grey, for example, the characters are laid out. so after you finish your magazine or paperback thriller, reflect on its contents. what does this all mean? which book inspires you the most? in 2012, standford university did research into why this is. are you reading the wrong books? your brain will thank you. what has science concluded?
a video of her overdose went viral; after watching it, she has something to say it’s not an easy video to watch, a young woman falling unconscious in her car after overdosing on drugs. more than 750,000 people have watched video of the milwaukee, wisconsin, woman’s overdose since it was posted on tuesday by a man who said he wanted to show the reality of the opioid epidemic. it was especially hard for katrina henry, the woman who was captured in the viral video — and now she’s speaking out about it. cbs 58 though it’s difficult to watch, henry says the video forces her to finally admit that she’s an addict. after giving her several doses of narcan, also known as naloxone, a prescription medicine that blocks the effects of opioids and reverses an overdose, henry was revived. i can’t," said katrina, adding that she wants professional help to get clean. she’s waiting for a bed to open at an inpatient rehabilitation center to help follow through on her promise to turn her life around. as the drugs overwhelmed her, henry lost control and crashed into a parked car, unconscious behind the wheel. "it makes me sick," katrina henry told cbs affiliate wdjt in milwaukee. "i was acting like i could live two different lives and you can’t. luckily, no one was hurt, but henry knows it could have been much, much worse. but in the grip of her addiction, she did.
